Abstract: Respiration is crucial for identifying and diagnosing cardiovascular conditions such as sleep apnea, and other cardiovascular and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Despite the growing interest in deep learning models for comfortable respiration recognition during daily activities, current algorithms often prove complex and inefficient. Hence, there is a need for alternate, more sophisticated, and effective techniques. In this paper, a novel deep neural network (RespECG-Net) model is proposed to estimate respiration parameters using single-lead ECG signals. The experiment involved ten healthy subjects with no reported neurological and respiration disorders. Additionally, the proposed model was tested during three distinct self-paced breathing conditions (normal, fast, and slow) to evaluate its reliability and robustness. The obtained results were compared to the respiration rate (RR) measured using the gold standard commercially available sensor belt (SB). The average mean absolute error (MAE) of respiration rate using SB and RespECG-Net obtained across subjects are 1.44 +/- 1.59, 3.11 +/- 5.65, and 1.80 +/- 2.53 for normal, fast, and slow breathing conditions, respectively. The root mean square error (RMSE) between the RespECG-Net and SB across subjects in normal breathing was 2.21 +/- 1.26 bpm. Moreover, the proposed research also estimates the various temporal features associated with the respiration signal, which can aid in the diagnosis, treatment, and early prediction of cardiovascular and COPD diseases.
Article Title: Respiration prediction using single channel electrocardiogram signals and neural networks for healthcare applications

Abstract: Introduction: Taiwan will become a super-aged society by 2025, making degenerative disorders, including Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease (PD), an urgent health concern. PD is the second most common neurodegenerative disorder worldwide, whose prevalence is increasing annually. Early detection is important for further intervention; however, non-specialists commonly fail to distinguish between aging motor dysfunction, or a very early motor symptom of PD. Objectives: To develop a facial-based artificial intelligence model to assess the facial features of patients with PD and investigate how artificial intelligence (AI) could help neurologists improve the performance of early PD diagnosis. Methods: We collected 70 videos of facial expressions from "on" stage PD patients with continuing antiparkinsonian drugs and matched controls from the Show Chwan Memorial Hospital. An AI model was developed to perform masked face recognition, based on the acquisition and evaluation in the sizes and muscle movement between facial landmarks. Results: Our AI models achieved feasible and effective facial feature recognition sufficient to assist in on-stage PD diagnosis. The accuracy of PD diagnosis using all features reached 76.5%. The random forest model with costeffective features achieved an accuracy and sensitivity of 82.4% and 83.3%, respectively. Furthermore, the accuracy and sensitivity reached 94.1% and 99.9% for typical PD patients, respectively. Conclusions: Patients with PD commonly exhibit masked facial features. Videos of a facial feature recognition-based AI model can assist with PD diagnosis and has the potential to realize remote monitoring of a patient's condition, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Article Title: A facial expression-based artificial intelligence model to aid in screening for Parkinson's disease: Development and validation in a cohort study

Abstract: Pulmonary embolism (PE) is a life-threatening emergency, and early accurate diagnosis can reduce mortality. Although computed tomography angiography (CTA) is the gold standard for diagnosis, it faces challenges including risks of contrast agent allergy, contrast-induced nephropathy complications, and high healthcare resource costs. Radiologists' slice-by-slice analysis of vascular morphology using CTA relies heavily on clinical experience. and prolonged image interpretation is prone to result in missed diagnoses or misdiagnoses of microthrombi due to visual fatigue, which more easily exacerbates diagnostic delays in resource-constrained areas. This study develops PulmoNet, a framework that enables transmodal transformation from non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) to CTA-like images using a bidirectional generative network incorporating Transformer attention mechanisms, and integrates a multi-scale object detection module optimized by dynamic EMA attention and MPDIoU loss thereby forming an end-to-end automated diagnostic workflow encompassing "image transformation and lesion localization". Based on a dataset of 773 cases from four hospitals, the framework demonstrates effectiveness: the transmodal transformation achieves a structural similarity index (SSIM) of 0.906 f 0.015 in the internal test set and 0.892 f 0.018 in the external test set; the mean average precision (mAP50) of the detection module is 0.875 f 0.018 (internal) and 0.857 f 0.020 (external), with diagnostic accuracy exceeding 93.9 % for all PE subtypes, results consistent with radiologists' diagnoses based on CTA. The study shows that this framework provides a safe alternative diagnostic solution for patients with contrast contraindications and provides specific practical references for the implementation of AI technology in emergency imaging-assisted diagnosis.
Article Title: PulmoNet: a transmodal deep learning framework for automated pulmonary embolism diagnosis on non-contrast CT

Abstract: Electrocardiogram (ECG) analysis plays a critical role in cardiovascular disease diagnosis. However, traditional approaches to ECG classification and generation often rely on existent information, neglecting the integration of domain-specific knowledge. To address this limitation, we propose a novel multi-task learning architecture, MMS-Net, which simultaneously performs ECG generation and classification. The network predicts the complete lead signal from a sparse set of ECG leads and utilizes the generated signal to extract relevant features for classification. To improve disease pattern recognition, we propose an attention mechanism that highlights key leads and waveforms, focusing on the most informative ECG features. Additionally, we incorporate a multi-level feature extraction structure, capturing semantic information across multiple scales to improve the robustness and accuracy of classification. Experimental results show that MMS-Net significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both ECG generate and classification tasks. Moreover, the integration of generation and classification tasks leads to mutual performance enhancement, demonstrating the efficacy of the multitask framework in capturing more relevant information for both tasks. These findings highlight the potential of multi-task learning architectures for advancing ECG analysis in clinical settings.
Article Title: MMS-Net: A multi-task learning framework for 12-lead ECG reconstruction and disease classification from 3-lead inputs

Abstract: Mitosis nuclei count is an important indicator for breast cancer diagnosis and grading, currently relying on manual whole slide image review by pathologists, which is time-consuming, labor-intensive, and subjective. Due to extreme class imbalance of nuclei types, intra-class heterogeneity, and inter-class similarity in breast pathology images, these data challenges hinder mitosis detection, with inadequate handling of sample noise and hard samples further reducing robustness. In this paper, we propose a Difficulty-Aware Learning Paradigm (DALP) framework based on the nuclei patch level. First, the difficulty and quantity of data are balanced by the Negative Sample Search (NS). Then, Dynamic Memory Units (DMU) and Difficulty Level Evaluation (DLE) are used to select simple samples, eliminate noisy samples, and subdivide and validate the difficulty levels of hard samples to obtain a clean and refined dataset. Finally, Class-Stratified Difficulty-Guided Learning (CSDGL) aims to address the issues of intra-class heterogeneity and inter-class similarity and optimize the learning of hard samples. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on the ICPR2014, TUPAC2016, and MIDOG2021 datasets. Furthermore, it consistently outperforms a broad range of well-established detection algorithms on GZMH-V2, a newly released clinical dataset curated by our team. The proposed method in this paper is a plug-and-play framework that relies solely on point annotations with minimal labeling effort, highlighting its potential application for breast cancer mitosis detection. The source code has been available at https://github.com/antifen/DASC.
Article Title: Navigating challenges in mitosis detection: A Difficulty-Aware Learning Paradigm

Abstract: Leukemia, a fatal hematological disease caused by the abnormal proliferation of malignant white blood cells, relies heavily on microscopic image analysis of pathological samples for clinical diagnostic accuracy and efficiency. Although deep learning-based computer-aided diagnostic technologies have achieved significant progress, existing approaches still face technical limitations such as low detection efficiency, high miss rates, and high false detection rates when dealing with complex microscopic imaging scenarios involving high-density distribution and complex morphological features of white blood cells. To address these challenges, we propose an efficient diagnostic framework, the FCE-YOLO model. Built upon the YOLOv8 architecture, the model integrates two novel modules, C2f_Faster and CSP_PTB, which significantly enhance global feature extraction, nonlinear representation capacity and inference speed. Furthermore, by incorporating the EMASlideLoss loss function, the model leverages historical state information during training and places greater emphasis on hard-to-classify and imbalanced samples, thereby improving classification accuracy. Trained on a blood cell image dataset covering four clinical stages of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (Begin, Malignant Pre-B, Malignant early Pre-B, Malignant Pro-B), the model achieves an outstanding 99.3 % mAP@0.5 and 98 % detection precision, with an inference speed of only 2.1 ms. Compared with the original YOLOv8, it improves mAP@0.5 by 3.3 % and precision by 4.7 %, while reducing GFLOPs by 24 %. Validation on the BCCD dataset further demonstrates the model's strong generalization ability, outperforming YOLOv8 and other state-of-the-art detectors (e.g., YOLOv10, YOLOv11). Overall, the proposed model achieves high diagnostic accuracy while maintaining efficient inference, markedly enhancing the reliability and speed of ALL subtype detection. This advancement not only provides reliable technical support for optimizing clinical decision-making and capturing optimal treatment opportunities, but also contributes valuable insights for future research and applications in medical image analysis and computer-aided diagnosis.
Article Title: FCE-YOLO: A highly accurate and efficient model for acute lymphoblastic leukemia detection and classification

Abstract: During progression of gynaecological tumours, pelvic lymph node metastasis serves as a critical determinant of clinical staging, therapeutic decision-making, and prognosis. Its presence signifies disease progression to advanced stages, substantially elevating therapeutic complexity and mortality risks. However, due to the small size of lymph nodes and adhesion between lesions and surrounding tissues causing imaging contrast imbalance, the detection difficulty is greatly increased. Therefore, we propose a precise detection model for pelvic lymph node metastasis based on YOLO11. First, to enhance the expression of lymph node edge features, we design a Multi-scale Feature and Edge information extraction Convolution (MFEConv) module which improves backbone network feature extraction by combining multi-scale depthwise convolutions and differential convolution blocks. Secondly, the Feature Channel Selection aggregation Module (FCSM) is proposed, which uses the adaptive channel weight control mechanism to automatically select key information, so as to retain important discriminant features more accurately when fusing multi-scale features. Finally, to enhance the localization precision of lymph node detection, we construct the NWD-CIoU composite loss function. This function compensates for the positional sensitivity limitations of traditional IoU in small targets by incorporating the Normalized Gaussian Wasserstein Distance (NWD). Experiments on a dataset of 1,258 pelvic enhanced CT scans demonstrate that our improved model outperforms the baseline YOLO11, achieving a 6.6% increase in mAP@50, 8.5% higher precision, 1.3% improved recall, and 4.4% higher F1-score. This provides more reliable and efficient technical support for precise diagnosis and treatment of pelvic lymph node metastasis in gynaecological tumours.
Article Title: PLNM-YOLO: Pelvic lymph node metastasis detection algorithm in gynaecological tumours based on edge-aware and multi-scale feature fusion

Abstract: Although deep learning (DL) methods have shown tremendous potential in many medical image analysis tasks, their practical applications are limited due to the lack of sufficient annotated data samples. By noting that the clinical radiology examinations are associated with radiology reports that describe the images, we propose to develop a foundation model for multi-model head MRI by using contrastive learning on the images and the corresponding radiology findings. In particular, a contrastive learning framework is proposed, where a mixed syntax and semantic similarity matching metric is integrated to reduce the thirst of extreme large dataset in conventional contrastive learning framework. Our proposed similarity enhanced contrastive language image pretraining (SeLIP) is able to effectively extract more useful features. Experiments revealed that our proposed SeLIP performs well in many downstream tasks including image-text retrieval task, classification task, and image segmentation, which highlights the importance of considering the similarities among texts describing different images in developing medical image foundation models. Code is available at https://github.com/yangdong01123/SeLIP.
Article Title: SeLIP: Similarity enhanced contrastive language image pretraining for multi-modal head MRI

Abstract: Respiratory diseases are leading causes of serious illness and mortality globally. Rapid and accurate diagnosis is crucial for effective treatment. Cough analysis offers a simple, low-cost, and accessible solution for detecting respiratory diseases anytime, anywhere, with significant public health implications for early intervention. However, existing cough datasets for respiratory diseases are limited. Most studies focus on binary detection of specific diseases, with fewer exploring multi-disease detection. Additionally, single-feature input models have limited performance. To address these challenges, this paper constructs a respiratory disease cough dataset and proposes DiemaNet, a deep learning method combining temporal dimensionality reduction and attention mechanisms for automatic cough-based detection. The temporal dimension reduction module (DiffRes) enhances detailed information extraction with lower computational cost and improves attention to critical temporal frames. Efficient Multi-Scale Attention (EMA) further boosts performance by highlighting important channel and spatial information. To evaluate the performance of the proposed method, we constructed a cough dataset named Cough-Exp, which includes four types of cough data: Health, COVID-19, Asthma, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Experiments show DiemaNet achieves the best performance on the dataset, with precision, recall, F1 score, and accuracy of 86.2%, 85.6%, 85.9%, and 84.7%, respectively.
Article Title: DiemaNet: An automated detection model for three typical respiratory diseases

Abstract: Accurate pancreatic tumor segmentation remains challenging due to complex anatomical structures and diverse tumor appearances. This study presents a Knowledge-Driven Evidence Fusion Segmentation Network (KEFS-Net), a framework that systematically integrates radiological and anatomical knowledge from medical reports with imaging features to enhance segmentation accuracy. KEFS-Net consists of three key components: (1) a knowledge-driven attention network that leverages large language models, discrete information bottleneck, and cross-attention to enhance CT image segmentation performance by capturing informative features from medical reports, (2) an evidence fusion strategy based on Dempster-Shafer theory that optimizes segmentation results by evaluating the consistency between textual knowledge and image predictions, and (3) a masked learning approach that ensures robust performance in clinical scenarios with incomplete tumor descriptions. The framework was evaluated on both the Medical Segmentation Decathlon (MSD) dataset and an external clinical dataset from the First Affiliated Hospital (FAH) of Zhejiang University School of Medicine. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods, achieving Dice of 59.10% and 59.42% respectively for tumor segmentation on the MSD and external dataset. The approach shows particular strength in handling diverse tumor characteristics including size variations, boundary ambiguity, and complex anatomical locations. This knowledge-driven framework represents a significant advancement in leveraging domain knowledge through multi-modal integration for improved pancreatic tumor segmentation. Our code is available at https://github.com/Singlesnail/KEFS-Net.
Article Title: A Knowledge-Driven Evidence Fusion Network for pancreatic tumor segmentation in CT images

Abstract: This study introduces the application of the superlet transform (SLT) for time-frequency feature extraction from electroencephalogram (EEG) signals in diagnosing major depressive disorder (MDD). Based on SLT features and an SVM classifier, an interpretable classification model was developed, achieving accuracies of 97.57 % on the Multi-modal Open Dataset (MODMA) and 96.58 % on Mumtaz's dataset. Cross-dataset validation confirmed the model's classification performance and robustness. Notably, SLT features in the alpha and theta bands effectively captured characteristics of MDD patients, with alpha band features exhibiting notable stability across datasets. These findings suggest that SLT-based feature extraction enhances both the accuracy and interpretability of EEG analyses, offering promising avenues for developing biomarkers and guiding EEG-based neurofeedback interventions for depression treatment.
Article Title: Towards alpha and theta band superlet features as biomarkers for depression: Insights from a cross-dataset classification study

Abstract: Background: Biological age is a key concept in the development of biomarkers of health and disease. We develop a prediction of the functional autonomic age (FAA) from infancy to adolescence based on the ECG-derived tachogram recorded at the onset of N2 sleep. Methods: A cohort of ECG recordings from 1004 typically developing infants, children and adolescents (age range: 1 month to 17 years) was used to train feature-based and deep neural network-based regression models for the prediction of FAA. Weighted mean absolute error (wMAE) was used to define accuracy and evaluated with 10-fold cross-validation. Effect size was used to compare model accuracies and linear regression was used to evaluate confounds. The combination of FAA with an EEG-based estimate of functional brain age (FBA) was also tested. Results: A feature-based FAA had a wMAE of 1.78 years (95 %CI: 1.62-1.93, n = 1004) and was comparable to deep neural network regression (wMAE = 1.85 years, 95 %CI: 1.66-1.98). Accuracy was affected by age and age2 (t = -4.97, p < 0.001 and t = 9.66, p < 0.001, respectively) with smaller errors at younger ages, but not biological sex (t = -0.660, p = 0.510). Combining the FAA with a functional brain age derived from the EEG resulted improved accuracy, with neural networks-based methods superior (wMAE of 0.81 years, 95 %CI: 0.73-0.88, effect size D = 0.77, 95 %CI: 0.70-0.84, n = 1004). Conclusion: FAA derived from the tachogram accurately represents age from infancy to adolescence. The combination of FAA with FBA improves age prediction accuracy.
Article Title: Age prediction from infancy to adolescence at the onset of N2 sleep using an ECG-derived tachogram

Abstract: Securing copyright protection for retinal images is critical, as it safeguards intellectual property and ensures the integrity of sensitive digital medical content. This paper proposed a zero-watermarking system explicitly designed for retinal images by integrating Gradient Directional Pattern (GDP) based master share generation and a chaotic DNA cryptographic method. The master share, generated using GDP and designed with robustness and versatility through histogram-based gradient feature selection, enables accurate encoding of retinal image features and provides a dependable basis for copyright verification. The system utilizes chaotic DNA cryptography to strengthen watermark security, bringing higher complexity and greater resilience against different manipulations. It also maintains the visual quality and subtlety of retinal images while strengthening the robustness of copyright protection measures. The experimentation confirms the method's effectiveness in protecting medical images, highlighting its promise as an advanced and reliable solution for defending the copyright of retinal images against contemporary threats.
Article Title: Securing copyright protection for retinal images through watermark image encryption in a robust zero-watermarking system

Abstract: The choroidal vascularity index (CVI) has become a useful measure for monitoring ocular health in inflammatory and vascular disorders. It is also a valuable parameter to monitor the potential adverse effect of drugs that modulate choroidal blood flow. This research aims to automatically segment the choroid as well as the vessels for accurate CVI calculation in enhanced depth imaging-optical coherence tomography (EDI-OCT) images. For this, CVI-UNet, a multi-segmentation U-Net with a channel attention module (CAM) and a vessel enhancement block (VEB) is proposed. The proposed model has a common encoder that is shared between the choroid segmentation decoder and the vessel segmentation decoder. It is capable of automatically segmenting the entire choroid region, as well as the vessels present in the choroid simultaneously in an end-to-end fashion from the input OCT images. The segmentation performance of CVI-UNet is quantitatively assessed on a completely anonymized dataset. The proposed method yielded an accuracy, dice similarity coefficient and jaccard index of 97.04%, 96.83% and 94.25% respectively for choroid segmentation and 95.58%, 93.99% and 92.56% respectively for vessel segmentation. The reliability of the CVI values and the agreement of the CVI values computed using the manual and the automated methods are also evaluated. Our results indicate that the CVI-UNet can accurately and efficiently segment choroid and vessels from the OCT images, which will be helpful to quantify the CVI.
Article Title: CVI-UNet: A multi-segmentation U-Net for automated choroidal vascularity index calculation from EDI-OCT images

Abstract: Medical image segmentation has traditionally relied on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and Transformerbased models. CNNs, however, are constrained by limited receptive fields, while Transformers face scalability challenges due to quadratic computational complexity. To overcome these issues, recent studies have explored alternative architectures. The Mamba model, a selective state-space design, achieves near-linear complexity and effectively captures long-range dependencies. Its vision-oriented variant, the Visual State Space (VSS) model, extends these strengths to image feature learning. In parallel, the Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) enhances nonlinear expressiveness by replacing fixed activation functions with learnable ones. Motivated by these advances, we propose the VSS-Enhanced KAN (VKAN) module, which integrates VSS with the Expanded Field Convolutional KAN (EFC-KAN) as a replacement for Transformer modules, thereby strengthening feature extraction. We further embed VKAN into a U-Net framework, resulting in MedVKAN, an efficient medical image segmentation model. Extensive experiments on five public datasets demonstrate that MedVKAN achieves stateof-the-art performance on four datasets and ranks second on the remaining one. These results underscore the effectiveness of combining Mamba and KAN while introducing a novel and computationally efficient feature extraction framework. The source code is available at: https://github.com/beginner-cjh/MedVKAN.
Article Title: MedVKAN: Efficient feature extraction with Mamba and KAN for medical image segmentation

Abstract: The accurate classification of electrocardiogram (ECG) signals is crucial for the early detection and diagnosis of cardiovascular diseases (CVDs), which remain the leading cause of mortality globally. Traditional methods of ECG interpretation are often limited by their inability to simultaneously identify multiple co-occurring heart conditions, a challenge that is further complicated by the complex nature of ECG signals. In response to this, we introduce an innovative deep learning architecture that combines Efficient Channel Attention (ECA), Squeeze-and-Excitation Networks (SENet), and residual networks (Resnet) modules, specifically designed for multi-label ECG classification using the PTB-XL dataset. Our model not only excels in detecting and distinguishing between various cardiac abnormalities but also addresses the critical need for interpretability in clinical applications. By incorporating SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) and Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM), we provide transparent, explainable insights into the model's decision-making process, ensuring that healthcare professionals can understand and trust the model's predictions. Experimental results on the PTB-XL dataset demonstrate that the proposed model achieves Exact match, Accuracy and F1-score of 0.638, 88.27% and 91.81%, respectively, with substantial improvements in both sensitivity and specificity across various cardiac conditions compared to state-of-the-art methods. This work represents a crucial step toward more reliable, interpretable, and clinically applicable AI-driven diagnostics for cardiovascular health.
Article Title: Interpretable deep learning framework for multi-label ECG classification: Enhancing cardiac diagnostics through feature attention and explainability

Abstract: Accurate liver, COVID-19, and brain disease diagnosis is crucial for effective medical treatment and improved patient outcomes. In Computer-Aided Diagnosis (CAD) systems, segmentation is the foundational step, which plays a pivotal role in accurately delineating regions of interest for subsequent analysis. Among various techniques, multilevel thresholding segmentation is a specialized approach for processing medical images. However, its computational complexity and challenges in achieving satisfactory segmentation results limit its widespread application. To address these issues, this paper proposes an Enhanced Crested Porcupine Optimizer (ECPO) tailored for multilevel thresholding in medical image segmentation. The ECPO integrates two novel strategies: Enhanced Solution Quality (ESQ) and Gaussian Distribution, improving the exploration and exploitation capabilities of the original Crested Porcupine Optimizer (CPO). The optimization performance of ECPO is rigorously evaluated on 12 classical benchmark functions using CEC'2022 test functions, demonstrating superior results compared to CPO and other state-of-the-art algorithms. Subsequently, the ECPO is applied to segmenting medical images from three datasets focusing on liver cancer, COVID-19, and brain diseases. Utilizing Otsu and Kapur methods. Experimental results indicate that ECPO achieves the best segmentation outcomes in terms of fitness values, Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Structural Similarity Index (SSIM), and Feature Similarity Index (FSIM). The experimental results reveal that ECPO achieves the most accurate and effective segmentation outcomes across all datasets, outperforming other competitive algorithms. These findings underscore the potential of ECPO as a robust and efficient solution to the multilevel thresholding segmentation challenges in medical imaging.
Article Title: Multilevel thresholding segmentation of medical images using the Crested Porcupine Optimizer with Enhanced Solution Quality and Gaussian distribution: Applications to liver, COVID-19, and brain diseases

Abstract: Knee osteoarthritis (OA) is a common and debilitating joint disorder that severely affects mobility and quality of life. Traditional deep learning methods for diagnosing OA from 3D MRI often struggle, facing a tradeoff between the high computational cost and detail loss of 3D models, and the incomplete perspective of single-view approaches. To address these challenges, we introduce the Multi-View Multi-Instance (MVMI) network, an advanced framework that synergizes Multi-Instance Learning (MIL) with Multi-View Learning. This approach processes three parallel views (Coronal, Sagittal, and Axial) of knee MRIs, treating each 2D slice as an independent instance within a "bag". Central to the network's architecture is a custom Res-Squeez-Net, a lightweight and efficient convolutional neural network that incorporates residual and squeeze-and-excitation blocks for enhanced feature extraction. This MVMI strategy enhances the model's ability to identify and leverage distinct pathological features from all three anatomical planes, leading to a more robust and comprehensive analysis. Evaluated on an extensive dataset of 900 patients from the Osteoarthritis Initiative (OAI) database, our three-view MVMI network achieved a state-of-the-art AUC of 94.75%. Furthermore, the model's robustness was confirmed through cross-sequence validation on unseen MRI pulse sequences, demonstrating its potential for generalizable and accurate OA detection.
Article Title: MVMI: Multi-View Multi-Instance network for the detection of knee osteoarthritis

Abstract: Remote monitoring of cardiovascular diseases plays an essential role in early detection of abnormal cardiac function, enabling timely intervention, improved preventive care, and personalized patient treatment. Abnormalities in the heart sounds can be detected automatically via computer-assisted decision support systems, and used as the first-line screening tool for detection of cardiovascular problems, or for monitoring the effects of treatments and interventions. We propose in this paper CardioPHON, an integrated heart sound quality assessment and classification tool that can be used for screening of abnormal cardiac function from phonocardiogram recordings. The model is pretrained in a self-supervised fashion on a collection of six small- and mid-sized heart sound datasets, enables automatic removal of low quality recordings to ensure that subtle sounds of heart abnormalities are not misdiagnosed, and provides a state-of-the-art performance for the heart sound classification task. The multimodal model that combines audio and socio-demographic features demonstrated superior performance, achieving the best ranking on the official leaderboard of the 2022 George B. Moody PhysioNet heart sound challenge, whereas the unimodal model, that is based only on phonocardiogram recordings, holds the first position among the unimodal approaches (a total rank 4), surpassing the models utilizing multiple modalities. CardioPHON is the first publicly released pretrained model in the domain of heart sound recordings, facilitating the development of data-efficient artificial intelligence models that can generalize to various downstream tasks in cardiovascular diagnostics.
Article Title: CardioPHON: Quality assessment and self-supervised pretraining for screening of cardiac function based on phonocardiogram recordings

Abstract: Precise medical image segmentation is crucial in clinical diagnosis and pathological analysis. Most segmentation methods are based on U-shaped convolutional neural networks (U-Net). Although U-Net performs well in medical image segmentation, as a method based on CNN, its main drawback lies in the difficulty of establishing long-range pixels dependencies and has a constrained receptive field, which restricts segmentation accuracy. Many models address this issue by incorporating Transformer models into U-Net architectures to better capture long-range dependencies. However, these methods often suffer from simple feature fusion techniques and limited receptive fields for local features. To address these challenges, we propose a dual-encoder framework, named MDCT-Unet, which combines Swin-Transformer and CNN for enhanced medical image segmentation. This framework introduces a novel dynamic feature fusion module to better integrate of local and global features. By combining channel and spatial attention mechanisms and inducing competition between them, we enhance the coupling of these two types of features, ensuring richer information representation. In addition, to better extract multi-scale local features from medical images, we design a dilated convolution encoder (DCE) as the CNN branch of our model. By incorporating dilated convolutions with varying receptive fields, DCE captures rich local features at multiple scales, thereby enhancing the model's ability to segment challenging regions such as boundaries and small organs. We conducted extensive experiments on four datasets: Synapse, ISIC2018, CHASEDB1, and MMWHS. The experimental results show that our method outperforms most current medical image segmentation methods quantitatively and qualitatively.
Article Title: MDCT-Unet: A dual-encoder network combining multi-scale dilated convolutions with Transformer for medical image segmentation

Abstract: Pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) remains a major global public health challenge. Effectively distinguishing between active and inactive TB is crucial for disease treatment and transmission control. While deep learning models show potential, significant limitations persist in multi-center data scenarios. These limitations stem from intra-domain feature differences (such as individual patient variations and imaging processing changes) and inter-domain feature differences (such as variations in equipment and data distribution across medical centers). Current research has not fully addressed these challenges. To overcome this, we propose a novel model, DMTB-Net (a multi-scale convolutional network with domain generalization capability for tuberculosis diagnosis). DMTB-Net integrates a Multi-Scale Convolutional Fusion Block (MSCB) and a Gradient Reversal Layer (GRL). The MSCB module extracts features from different receptive field scales through parallel multi-scale convolutions, using feature fusion and reconstruction mechanisms to emphasize critical information and reduce redundancy. This enhances the model's ability to capture complex lesion morphologies and reduce the impact of intra-domain feature differences. The GRL module introduces adversarial training via gradient reversal, enabling the model to extract domain-invariant features and mitigate the impact of inter-domain feature differences.DMTB-Net was validated on multi-center TB datasets from three hospitals and further tested on publicly available lung-related datasets. The results show that DMTB-Net outperforms other methods, highlighting its strong classification performance and excellent generalization ability.
Article Title: Advancing automated diagnosis of active pulmonary tuberculosis in multi-center settings through domain generalization and multi-scale convolution fusion

Abstract: Deformable image registration is a pivotal task in medical image analysis, essential for applications such as surgical navigation, lesion localization, and treatment planning. However, the accuracy of registration is frequently constrained by the ability to analyze complex textural features, which impedes the capture of finegrained deformations and elevates surgical risks. To overcome these limitations, we propose the Multi-Scale Lipschitz Neural Fields Incorporating Frequency Decoupling (MLNFFD) framework, which reformulates the registration task as the correction of high-frequency residuals based on a low-frequency coarse registration foundation. Specifically, we employ a dual-branch architecture, comprising a band-limited U-Net low-frequency branch for coarse deformation estimation, and a Multi-Scale Lipschitz Neural Fields (MLNF) high-frequency branch dedicated to refining fine-grained deformation residuals. Through a complementary joint optimization strategy, the low-frequency branch provides an initial estimation that accelerates the optimization of the high-frequency branch, while the high-frequency branch refines the deformation field and enhances local details, fostering mutual reinforcement and improving registration accuracy. Additionally, the MLNF branch incorporates a Multi-Scale Implicit Dual-Domain Feature Representation (MIDFR), a deep similarity prior, and Lipschitz continuity constraints, enhancing the representation of complex textural features while ensuring the smoothness of the deformation field. Extensive experimental results on brain MRIs and cine cardiac MRIs datasets show that our proposed approach outperforms existing methods in terms of both registration accuracy and deformation field smoothness.
Article Title: Multi-scale Lipschitz Neural Fields Incorporating Frequency Decoupling for medical image registration

Abstract: Background: Recent theoretical and experimental developments have revealed that the shape of stimulation electrodes is influential in transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS), which can be regarded as a determining factor. Material and methods : For this study, it was of interest to investigate the structures of electrodes by utilizing regular star polygons, fractal structures and, last but not least, the extended fractal using the Van-Koch curve. We therefore analyzed the stroke patients and improved the focality and the electric field strength of the conventional tDCS. Following segmenting the collected Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) data from an ischemic stroke patient, we separated the five vital head layers. Once the electrodes were placed on the head, Finite Element Method (FEM) was used in order to simulate the electric field distribution of each segmented layer. Results: This allowed the conclusion that the fractal structures and star polygons can increase not only the norm of the average and maximum electric field distribution in different layers of the head but also the current density. Likewise, the same escalation can be expected in the average and maximum electric field of standard tDCS. Significantly superior results were achieved with our proposed model; for instance, the improvement index of the tDCS in all layers was virtually twice as high as the ordinarily used structures (rectangular and circular models). Conclusions: The proposed model has also substantial benefits in terms of enhancing the electric field in the target region regardless needing the electric-current augmentation.
Article Title: Effective shapes of tDCS electrodes in stroke patients: A modeling study

Abstract: Breast cancer is the most prevalent malignancy among women globally, with early detection playing a pivotal role in improving survival rates. However, ultrasound image interpretation remains a challenge due to noise, indistinct lesion boundaries, and the need for skilled radiologists, especially in resource-limited settings. This research introduces SwinEff-AttentionNet, a novel hybrid deep learning framework combining Swin transformers, EfficientNet layers, and Efficient Local Self-Attention (ELSA) modules to enhance breast ultrasound image analysis. Utilizing hierarchical feature extraction, the proposed architecture excels in segmentation and classification tasks. It was evaluated on two benchmark datasets: BUSI and Breast-Lesions-USG. For classification, SwinEff-AttentionNet achieved an accuracy of 98.50% and 95.84% on the BUSI and Breast-Lesions-USG datasets, respectively, outperforming state-of-the-art models such as ViT, DeiT, PVT, CrossViT and CvT. Similarly, segmentation performance yielded Dice scores of 92% and 87.82%, IoU scores of 88.7% and 83%, and AUC values of 91.38% and 89.72% on the BUSI and Breast-Lesions-USG datasets, respectively, underscoring its robustness across diverse imaging conditions. The dual-task nature of SwinEff-AttentionNet demonstrates its versatility, offering clinicians a reliable tool for both lesion localization and diagnosis. This study highlights the potential of advanced hybrid architectures in addressing the limitations of traditional imaging frameworks, paving the way for improved diagnostic accuracy and clinical decision-making in breast cancer care.
Article Title: SwinEff-AttentionNet: a dual hybrid model for breast image segmentation and classification using multiple ultrasound modality

Abstract: Denoising diffusion probabilistic models have become increasingly popular due to their ability for probabilistic modeling and the generation of diverse outputs. This versatility inspired their adaptation for image segmentation, where multiple predictions of the model can produce segmentation results that not only achieve high quality but also capture the uncertainty inherent in the model, which makes them especially interesting for medical data. Powerful architectures were proposed to improve the performance of diffusion segmentation. However, detailed analyses and discussions of the differences between diffusion segmentation and image generation are missing. Furthermore, thorough evaluations are lacking that distinguish the improvements of the utilized architectures for segmentation in general from their benefit for diffusion segmentation specifically. In this work, we critically analyze and discuss how diffusion segmentation differs from diffusion image generation, with a particular focus on training behavior. We assess how the proposed diffusion segmentation architectures perform when trained directly for segmentation and explore how different segmentation tasks influence the behavior of diffusion segmentation. Drawing from our analysis, we suggest a method for modifying the diffusion segmentation procedure for image segmentation across various medical datasets. We showcase the improvements achieved by implementing our suggested modifications across three different diffusion segmentation methods applied to three separate datasets. Our goal is to offer a comprehensive understanding of the dynamics of diffusion segmentation, which will enable improved designs and assessments of diffusion segmentation techniques moving forward.
Article Title: Analyzing and adapting diffusion segmentation behavior for medical images

Abstract: Accurate classification of lung nodules can significantly improve treatment outcomes and patient survival rates by enabling early detection and preemptive intervention in cases of suspected lung cancer. Due to the limited availability of sufficiently comprehensive chest X-ray (CXR) datasets, we utilized a composite dataset from the NODE21 challenge to classify nodules and non-nodules in chest radiographs. In this study, we propose a novel computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) framework that includes image standardization and advanced image enhancement techniques for improved quality. We integrated four state-of-the-art deep learning (DL) models such as DenseNet201, MobileViTv2-0.50, MobileViTv2-0.75, and ResNet152, into this framework. We also introduced our own proposed Self-DenseMobileNet, which was trained on four image-enhanced variants of our dataset. The prediction probabilities from this model were transformed into tabular form, and then eight classical machine learning (ML) models were trained. The top three performing classical models were subsequently combined using a stacking algorithm to create a meta-classifier. Finally, We used class activation mapping (CAM) to demonstrate the interpretability of the best-performing model. Our proposed framework achieved an accuracy of 99.28%, a precision of 99.60%, a recall of 99.47%, a specificity of 98.68%, an F1-score of 99.53%, and an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.99 on internal validation images using a Meta-Random Forest Classifier. When tested on a completely different dataset, the external validation results showed an accuracy of 89.40%, a precision of 90.08%, a recall of 92.58%, a specificity of 84.6%, and an F1-score of 91.31%, and an AUC of 0.90. The novel framework resulted in a significant performance enhancement in classifying CXRs with lung nodules. The classification reasoning of the models can also be explained by ScoreCam heatmaps, which further solidifies its robustness. Our proposed model will assist healthcare experts in making informed decisions regarding lung cancer.
Article Title: Self-DenseMobileNet: A robust framework for lung nodule classification using Self-ONN and stacking-based meta-classifier

Abstract: With advanced deep learning technology, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have made significant progress in brain tumor diagnosis. While CNNs excel at handling local features, they lack an understanding of global features. Hypergraph neural networks (HGNNs), on the other hand, can capture relationships between data from a global perspective, making them an effective approach to overcome the limitations of CNNs. However, using HGNNs for brain tumor image classification still faces two challenges: effectively modeling existing brain-tumor image features with hypergraphs and addressing the issue of overlooking the importance of different vertex features due to fixed weights in hypergraph convolution. We proposed a hypergraph dynamic attention network with CNN-driven features (C-HGDAT) to address these challenges. First, we extract hypergraph-oriented features (HoFs) from MRI images using a top-layer removal scheme (TLRS) truncated Network. Then, we introduced a self-attention-driven hypergraph generation (SAHG) algorithm that effectively models the extracted HoFs. Next, we proposed a hypergraph dynamic attention network (HGDAT) that dynamically updates the weights of vertices and hyperedges during training to aggregate high-order information from the hypergraph structure. Finally, the aggregated hypergraph is classified using a simple classifier. The proposed model was evaluated on a benchmark brain tumor dataset publicly available on the Figshare website. We evaluated the proposed model on the Figshare dataset using five-fold cross-validation, achieving an average classification accuracy of 98.22%, outperforming all state-of-the-art methods, and demonstrating our approach's significant effectiveness and superiority in brain tumor diagnostic tasks.
Article Title: C-HGDAT: Hypergraph dynamic attention network with CNN-Driven features for brain tumor classification

Abstract: Humans have the remarkable ability to focus on a single speaker's voice in a noisy environment, demonstrating the brain's sophisticated auditory attention mechanisms. However, accurately decoding this attention, particularly from complex and variable EEG signals, remains a significant challenge. Current models struggle to capture the dynamic multi-scale features of EEG signals across different cognitive states or tasks, often focusing on local features while neglecting global spatial correlations. To address these challenges, this study introduces a novel multi-scale fusion network integrated with advanced attention mechanisms, designed specifically to enhance the decoding of auditory attention from EEG signals by capturing both local and global multi-scale features while dynamically and adaptively fusing them. The approach combines Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) with Multi-Head Attention Graph Convolutional Networks (MGCN) to extract multi-scale features. Additionally, an Enhanced Multi-Aspect Attention Block (EMAAB) is introduced to prevent overemphasis on local features, ensuring the capture of global information in dynamic EEG signals. Finally, a Dynamic Fusion Module (DFM) leveraging Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) layers enhances adaptability to varying tasks. Experiments on the KUL and DTU public databases demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms existing methods in both recognition accuracy and generalization ability. For the 1-second decision window, it achieved peak accuracies of 97.03% on the KUL database and 90.69% on the DTU database under 10-fold cross-validation. Under the more challenging leave-one-subject-out (LOSO) setting, the model still maintained strong performance, reaching 74.66% on KUL and 61.04% on DTU, further confirming its robustness across subjects. Furthermore, this study also presents promising applications for real-time auditory attention recognition systems, such as brain-computer interfaces, hearing aids, and neurofeedback devices.
Article Title: Multi-scale fusion networks with enhanced attention mechanisms for auditory attention decoding from EEG

Abstract: Melanoma is the skin tumor with the highest mortality rate, and timely diagnosis based on dermoscopic images is an essential task in melanoma prevention and treatment. However, complex dermoscopic image morphology and unclear image edges affect the accurate diagnosis of melanoma. This study presents an encoder-decoder architecture (EFEMNet) to segment dermatologic lesions. First, residual concatenation is introduced in the encoder part to enhance the feature retention capabilities. Second, Coordinate Attention is utilized to identify and localize the target region more accurately for dermoscopic images with different morphologies. Third, an efficient feature extraction module (EFEM) is designed to improve up-sampling operations and to extract and fuse features efficiently. Finally, Global Attention Module (GAM) Attention is added to the output layer to integrate the dimensions in space and channels to solve the problem of unclear edges in dermoscopy images. The suggested method is evaluated on various datasets, such as ISIC 2018 and EFEMNet, and segmented skin lesions more accurately than some state-of-the-art network models, achieving 92.52% Dice, 86.81% IoU, 96.01% Accuracy, 93.86% Recall, and 92.92% Precision. The proposed method is shown to outperform other methods across all evaluation indices, and the effectiveness of the functional module is validated through a series of ablation experiments.
Article Title: EFEMNet: An efficient feature extraction multi-attention convolutional neural network for skin lesion

Abstract: This paper proposes a novel method, MCAGNN-GBA-ECG (Multi-Component Attention Graph Convolutional Neural Network optimized by the Gooseneck Barnacle Algorithm), for high-precision ECG arrhythmia classification. Initially, the data is taken from MIT-BIH Arrhythmia Dataset. Then the, data is pre-processed by using Trajectory Poisson Multi-Bernoulli Mixture Filter (TPMBMF) is utilized for Reduce Noise and enhance the quality of the signals. Then, the pre-processing data are fed to Segmentation process using Simple Contrastive Graph Clustering (SCGC) is used to segment the electrocardiogram (ECG) signals into individual heartbeats. Then, the Segmentation data are fed to extraction process using Random Quantum Circuits Transform (RQCT). It extracts the Waveform features such as P, Q, R, S, and T waves (PR interval, PR segment, QT interval, ST segment). Then, the extracted features are fed into the Multi-Component Attention Graph Convolutional Neural Network (MCAGNN) for detect and classify the ECG arrhythmia which classifies as Normal beat, Supraventricular ectopic beat, Ventricular ectopic beat, Fusion beat and Unclassifiable beat. The Gooseneck Barnacle Algorithm (GBA) is implemented to optimize the parameters of MCAGNN. The performance of the suggested (MCAGNN-GBA-ECG) accurately displays the outcomes of the classification. The proposed method is implemented and efficiency is estimated utilizing several performance metrics such as Accuracy, Recall, and precision, F1-score, specificity, confusion matrix and computational time is analyzed. Performance of the ENetB7-VCNN-HMOA-ECG approach attains 24.42%, 35.45%, and 25.23% higher Accuracy; 25.41%, 52.32%, and 23.32% higher Precision; 22.42%, 31.43%, and 53.23% higher Recall, When analyzed through existing techniques like ECG-ASC-LCCNN, CADRNN-ECG and ECG-AD-DNN respectively.
Article Title: A Multi-Component Attention Graph Convolutional Neural Network Optimized by the Gooseneck Barnacle Algorithm for High-Precision ECG Arrhythmia Classification in Sensor-Based Biomedical Systems

Abstract: Chest X-rays are valuable for diagnosing and monitoring various conditions such as pneumonia, COVID-19, and heart disease, to cite but a few. This study specifically focuses on X-ray image classification between nonpathological lung images (i.e., normal/healthy) and lung images affected by pneumonia. The latter category is further subdivided into common pneumonia (bacterial and viral) and COVID-19 pneumonia. In this paper, we experimentally compare state-of-the-art machine learning methods tackling this multi-class classification problem. Specifically, we design a comparative methodology to put to test six prominent Convolutional Neural Network architectures, including ResNet, AlexNet, VGGNet, SqueezeNet, DenseNet, and InceptionV3. Our work overcomes the issue that the existing proposals for tackling pneumonia classification based on Deep Learning are not directly comparable, due to considerable differences in their respective modeling pipeline. In this paper, we conduct a comparative evaluation based on a uniform pipeline, from data collection, curation, and all the way to model validation. We introduce a balanced, labeled dataset, including 6,939 X-ray images. In pursuit of high accuracy, we also integrate (in all six cases) the same data curation, transformation, and augmentation techniques. Key findings demonstrate VGGNet's superior performance, with an overall 97% accuracy, making it highly applicable to real-world clinical scenarios.
Article Title: An experimental comparison of deep learning models for pneumonia classification from chest X-ray images

Abstract: Accurate diagnosis of bladder cancer primarily depends on cystoscopic biopsy pathology, with Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor (TURBT) being the standard clinical approach. However, existing segmentation algorithms often struggle to distinguish tumors from healthy tissue due to indistinct boundaries and the complex morphology of bladder tumors. In this study, we propose FFB-Former, an advanced neural network architecture specifically designed for bladder tumor segmentation in white-light cystoscopic images. The model integrates a Flatten Transformer to enhance global feature extraction and improve tumor discrimination, while a restructured FastNet Conv Branch (FCB) is introduced to better capture fine-grained morphological details. Additionally, the incorporation of Partial Convolution (PConv) and Spatial and Channel Reconstruction Convolution (SCConv) enables more precise boundary refinement through multi-scale context aggregation. In collaboration with the Department of Urology at Anhui Medical University, we constructed a high-quality dataset, BC-DB, to support model development and evaluation. FFB-Former achieved superior segmentation performance with an mDice of 0.904 and mIoU of 0.842 on BC-DB, outperforming baseline methods by 2% and 3%, respectively. Furthermore, in cross-domain evaluations on the Kvasir-SEG and CVC-ClinicDB datasets, the model achieved mDice scores of 0.962 and 0.960, exceeding existing methods by 0.7%-2%. These results validate the robustness and generalization capability of FFB-Former for clinical bladder cancer image analysis.
Article Title: FFB-Former: Flatten Faster Branch Transformer for cystoscopy segmentation

Abstract: Electroencephalogram (EEG) signals have become critical in applications such as medical diagnostics and neurofeedback systems. However, its sensitivity makes it vulnerable to unauthorized access and the risk of data leakage. To address these challenges, this study proposes an EEG signal encryption method based on a dual composite Inverse Trigonometric Iterative Chaotic Map (IT-ICMIC) and adaptive non-uniform partition. To enhance the security of EEG signal encryption, the dual composite IT-ICMIC chaotic map is introduced, addressing the limitations of traditional single chaotic maps in complexity and unpredictability. Additionally, the adaptive non-uniform partition algorithm explores the intrinsic dynamic characteristics of EEG signals. Further, the mined features integrate with the fundamental properties of EEG signals to generate chaotic sequences, enabling efficient and robust encryption. Extensive experiments and security analysis demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior performance for EEG signal encryption, with an average NSCR of 100, a UACI of 33.36 highlighting its strong encryption effectiveness.
Article Title: An EEG signal encryption algorithm based on dual-composite IT-ICMIC chaotic and non-uniform

Abstract: Non-intrusive heart rate monitoring is essential in modern medicine and health surveillance. Traditional contactbased methods compromise user comfort, whereas the Ballistocardiogram (BCG) offers a non-invasive solution for measuring cardiac mechanical activity. This study introduces and evaluates a beat-to-beat BCG heart rate estimation method based on fuzzy weighted fusion (FWF). Initially, nine priori BCG templates are calculated. Heartbeat indices and their corresponding confidence scores are then determined through adaptive matching based on priori BCG templates, signal energy, and interval maximum peak prominence methods. These multiple heartbeat detection results are subsequently fused using a fuzzy weighted method, with the final heartbeat detection results refined through autocorrelation analysis. Furthermore, the proposed artifact detection and elimination method significantly enhances the accuracy of heart rate estimation during sleep. In standard resting state tests with five subjects, the FWF method achieved a mean absolute beat-to-beat interval error of 23.14 ms, a mean relative beat-to-beat interval error of 2.49 %, and a mean heart rate error of 0.87 bpm. In sleep state tests with five subjects, the FWF method yielded a mean absolute beat-to-beat interval error of 36.9 ms, a mean relative beat-to-beat interval error of 3.97 %, and a mean heart rate error of 1.6 bpm. Results from ablation analysis indicate that the proposed fusion strategy significantly enhances the robustness of individual heartbeat detection algorithms. In comparative experiments, the proposed method significantly outperformed existing techniques implemented across most evaluation metrics, and validation using sleep data further demonstrated the reliability of our method in real-world applications.
Article Title: Beat-to-beat heartbeat detection based on fuzzy weighted fusion in ballistocardiograms

Abstract: Diabetic Retinopathy(DR) is a leading cause of preventable blindness among diabetic patients, where early detection and accurate grading are crucial for effective intervention. Considering the demanding workload of ophthalmologists and the increasing prevalence of diabetes, there is a critical need for automated systems that can support and enhance the diagnostic process. This paper introduces a novel ensemble model combining deep convolutional neural networks (CNN) and Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) for precise DR diagnosis using color fundus images. Initially, the retinal images are processed through fine-tuned CNN models, including ResNet-50, DenseNet, 121, and EfficientNet-B0, each enhanced with Multi-Head Self-Attention (MHSA) blocks to capture both local and global dependencies. The model leverages the strengths of these enhanced CNNs, extracting features that are subsequently ranked and aggregated using the Technique for Order of Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS), an MCDA technique to ensure robust and reliable predictions. By embedding a cost-sensitive scheme that increases penalties with the distance between predicted and actual grades, the TOPSIS mechanism facilitates model selection that preserves the ordinal relationship among classes. Additionally, logit-level averaging is applied to further refine the final classification. This multi-stage approach enables comprehensive feature extraction and robust model selection, significantly enhancing the DR diagnosis performance. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of our method, achieving a Quadratic Weighted Kappa score of 91.85% on APTOS-2019.
Article Title: MHSA-enhanced CNNs with TOPSIS-driven ensemble learning for automated diabetic retinopathy grading

Abstract: The supervision of respiratory movements is undoubtedly an important tool for detecting respiratory diseases and functional abnormalities. The accuracy of respiratory diagnostics using respiratory motion depends to a large extent on the respiratory signal modeling. Hence the need for a realistic model that can reproduce the characteristics of the respiratory signal. The aim of this study is to provide an accurate analytical model that takes into account the random fluctuations of the amplitude and the cycle-duration of the respiration over several respiratory cycles. The proposed model, which by the way exhibits cyclostationary properties, is then validated by using it to fit a real-life respiration signal. Moreover, the cyclostationarity character is proven through a theoretical study. Finally, simulations on synthetic and experimental data are performed to confirm the effectiveness and the cyclostationarity property of the proposed respiratory model.
Article Title: Maxwell-Boltzman function based analytical modeling of the human respiratory signal

Abstract: Problem: Accurate segmentation of ischemic stroke lesions from brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) remains a challenging task due to the substantial variability in lesion size and shape, as well as the low contrast between lesion regions and surrounding brain tissues. Aim: This study aims to develop a robust and accurate segmentation method for ischemic stroke lesions that can effectively handle complex lesion characteristics and improve diagnostic precision. Methods: a novel multi-stage progressive feature fusion network (MPFF-Net) is proposed for stroke lesion segmentation in MRI. The network employs a coarse-to-fine, three-stage processing pipeline built on a multiresolution image pyramid. To enhance feature representation, a cross-stage encoding feature enhancement module is introduced in the encoder, which integrates complementary features from multiple stages. In the decoder, a progressive reconstruction image feature fusion module is incorporated, which aggregates multistage outputs to better preserve boundary details. Deep supervision is applied at multiple levels to guide the learning process using ground truth labels at corresponding scales. Results: Extensive experiments on two public datasets, ATLAS and BraTS2018, show that the proposed MPFF-Net outperforms several state-of-the-art methods in terms of segmentation accuracy. Higher Dice similarity coefficients, intersection-over-union (IoU), and recall scores were achieved, demonstrating superior generalization and robustness across diverse lesion presentations. Conclusion: The proposed MPFF-Net effectively addresses the challenges of ischemic stroke lesion segmentation by leveraging multi-scale feature fusion and cross-stage contextual enhancement. The method holds strong potential for improving clinical stroke diagnosis and treatment planning.
Article Title: A multi-stage progressive feature fusion network for Brain Stroke lesion segmentation

Abstract: In today's world, there has been a notable increase in the number of diverse forms of cancer among human population, resulting in a higher mortality rate for a significant number of individuals. The identification and diagnosis of cancer can greatly influence patient survival rates and contribute to in treatment expenses. Colon cancer has a high incidence rate worldwide, ranking second in terms of prevalence and fatality among cancers. Despite various diagnostic techniques, histopathological image analysis important role in the timely and accurate diagnosis of colon cancer. However, these images often suffer significant noise and contrast issues, affecting the reliability of automated diagnostic systems. To mitigate issues, we propose a two-stage image pre-processing framework combining Bayesian-Optimized Fourth Partial Differential Equation (BO-FPDE) filtering with wavelet-based image fusion. The BO-FPDE filter the image while preserving critical edge and texture information, and in the second stage, the wavelet module enhances the visual clarity of the image by integrating multi-scale features. The proposed framework is evaluated on the publicly available CRAG colon cancer histopathology dataset containing malignant benign images. The experimental results indicate that the proposed framework outperforms various the-art techniques, achieving a Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio of 43.25 dB, a Structural Similarity Index of 0.987, and a BRISQUE score of 44.31, reflecting significantly improved perceptual quality. processing framework greatly improves the quality of the input images, making tasks such as segmentation and classification more effective and accurate in the later stages.
Article Title: Bayesian-optimized fourth order partial differential equation filtering and wavelet fusion for denoising and enhancing the CRAG colon histopathological image dataset

Abstract: Accurate automated segmentation of bone fractures from computed tomography (CT) requires large amounts of annotated data to train deep learning models. However, obtaining such annotations presents unique challenges, as the process demands expert knowledge to identify diverse fracture patterns, assess severity, and account for individual anatomical variations. This makes the annotation process highly time-consuming and expensive. Although semi-supervised learning methods can utilize unlabeled data, existing approaches often struggle with the complexity and variability of fracture morphologies, as well as limited generalizability across datasets. To address these challenges, we propose an effective training strategy based on masked autoencoder (MAE) for accurate bone fracture segmentation in CT. The proposed method combines MAE-based anatomical structure learning from unlabeled data with cross-scale cascaded attention (CSCA)-enhanced fine-tuning that focuses on fracture-specific detail preservation. The method is evaluated on two CT datasets: 180 tibial plateau fractures (TPF) and 103 hip fractures (HF). It outperforms representative semi-supervised baselines, achieving high segmentation accuracy with only 20 annotated cases and demonstrating strong cross-site generalization. These results demonstrate that the proposed training strategy effectively improves the efficiency and accuracy of bone fracture segmentation while maintaining strong generalizability across anatomically distinct datasets. This makes the method well-suited for real-world clinical deployment, particularly in data-scarce or resource-constrained environments. The code is publicly available at https://github.com/yuepeiyan/ GeneralizableFractureSeg.
Article Title: Learning generalizable features for bone fracture segmentation using limited annotations

Abstract: Automatic tumor segmentation is a critical task in medical image analysis. Positron emission tomography (PET) and computed tomography (CT) are widely used in early cancer diagnosis because they provide complementary imaging information about anatomical structures. However, obtaining complete images from both modalities in clinical practice is often challenging due to constraints such as cost and physical limitations. Missing modality data can hinder multi-modal understanding and degrade the performance of automatic tumor segmentation models. Existing methods struggle to effectively exploit cross-modal correlations and capture essential semantic information. To address these challenges, we propose DMM-Net, an end-to-end Diffusion Mamba Multi-modal Network for incomplete multi-modal automatic tumor segmentation. DMM-Net optimizes performance by combining generation and segmentation in a synergistic manner. Specifically, DMM-Net consists of two key components:conditional missing modality generation and cross-modal spatial-channel interaction segmentation. In the first component, a score-based diffusion model generates the missing modality, leveraging the available modalities as conditional guidance to reduce semantic ambiguities. In the second component, we propose a cross-modal interaction Mamba and a cross-modal channel attention enhancement module. The interaction Mamba efficiently captures global contextual features from PET and CT images, facilitating cross-modal feature interaction. The channel enhancement module highlights essential channel features within the multi-modal representations, captures inter-modal feature correlations, and suppresses redundant information. Next, we validate the effectiveness of DMM-Net through comprehensive ablation studies and visualization experiments on three multi-modal datasets (STS, LMNCLC, and Hecktor 2022). Quantitative comparisons and segmentation results demonstrate that DMM-Net surpasses state-of-the-art methods, regardless of modality incompleteness.
Article Title: Robust tumor segmentation in incomplete multi-modal imaging via a synergy of diffusion and Mamba models

Abstract: Accurate lesion detection and analysis in medical imaging are vital for early diagnosis and effective treatment planning across a range of diseases. Despite advancements in artificial intelligence, existing frameworks often exhibit limited robustness and struggle to handle diverse lesion characteristics such as varying shapes, sizes, and textures. To address these gaps, this study introduces MedScope-LDx (Medical Scope for Lesion Detection and Analysis), a comprehensive framework leveraging advanced models and optimization techniques to deliver a seamless, high-precision workflow for automated lesion analysis. The workflow begins with robust preprocessing techniques, including Contrast-Limited Adaptive Histogram Equalization (CLAHE), Gaussian Filtering, and pixel intensity normalization, to enhance image quality and standardize the inputs. These steps ensure that the medical images are artifact-free and optimized for subsequent feature extraction. Feature extraction is achieved through Hybrid Attention DenseNet (HADN), which integrates spatial and channel attention mechanisms to prioritize lesion-relevant features, ensuring the precise and efficient representation of complex lesion characteristics. Segmentation is performed using the Segment Anchoring Model (SAM), a transformer-based architecture that tokenizes features into patches and applies self-attention mechanisms to accurately delineate lesion boundaries. For lesion detection, the Mamba Vision framework combines convolutional layers, Mamba Vision Mixers, and Transformer blocks to extract global and local patterns, thereby enabling an accurate lesion categorization. The Black-Winged Kite Algorithm (BKA), a novel nature-inspired optimization algorithm, is employed to fine-tune the parameters of preprocessing, feature extraction, segmentation, and detection, ensuring optimal performance and computational efficiency. Extensive evaluation of medical imaging datasets demonstrated the effectiveness of MedScope-LDx. On the lung CT dataset, the framework achieved an accuracy of 99.25 %, precision of 98.85 %, recall of 98.60 %, and F1 score of 98.90 %, with a Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) of 96.5 %. The kidney CT dataset delivered an accuracy of 99.6 %, precision of 99.4 %, recall of 99.2 %, F1 score of 99.3 %, and ((DSC) of 98.5 %. On the lung X-ray dataset, the framework achieved an accuracy of 98.80 %, demonstrating strong performance in this domain. Moreover, the inference time is significantly reduced to 55.8 ms for the lung dataset and 54.3 ms for the kidney dataset, highlighting the framework's computational efficiency. By addressing the challenges in lesion diversity and data variability, MedScope-LDx offers a scalable and clinically viable solution for early disease diagnosis and management, setting a new benchmark for automated medical image analysis.
Article Title: MedScope-LDx: A comprehensive approach for advanced lesion analysis in medical imaging

Abstract: Computer-aided diagnosis is increasingly applied to Alzheimer's disease (AD). However, multimodal deep-learning approaches that combine sMRI and FDG-PET still face several challenges. These include limited computational efficiency, loss of boundary information, and underutilization of frequency-domain features. To address these issues, we propose a Multi-Scale Spatial Structure Aware Fusion Network (MSSAFN), which incorporates a Structure-Aware Spatial (SAS) module at different scales and employs an adaptive fusion strategy to integrate spatial and frequency-domain information from sMRI and FDG-PET. Each SAS module employs a three-dimensional Dynamic Padded Window Attention (3D-DPWA) mechanism, which adaptively calculates symmetric padding based on the input feature map size, preserving the integrity of all voxels, including those at the boundaries. To overcome the limitations of purely spatial processing, the BNM block applies the FFT to project features into the frequency domain. It then enhances the real and imaginary components through dedicated convolution and attention operations, and then uses the IFFT to return to the spatial domain, where the results are fused with the original features, thereby extracting and amplifying frequency-domain characteristics to reveal subtle lesions. Experiments on the independent ADNI dataset, including comparative and ablation studies, demonstrate the effectiveness of MSSAFN in classifying AD and MCI, and confirm the necessity of its key modules. Interpretability analysis shows substantial overlap between the regions highlighted by the model and brain areas that are clinically recognized as pathologically relevant to AD and MCI. This underscores the model's potential clinical relevance and its alignment with known AD and MCI pathology distributions.
Article Title: MSSAFN: A multiscale structure-aware spatial fusion network for Alzheimer's disease classification

Abstract: Context: Brain tumor diagnosis is challenging due to their complex morphology, indistinct boundaries, and subtle variations in Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scans. Manual diagnosis is time-consuming and error-prone, making the need for automated systems crucial. Recent advancements in deep learning, particularly in transformer models, have led to improved accuracy and speed in medical image analysis. Objective: This research aims to develop an Artificial Intelligencee (AI) based framework that integrates the Pyramid Vision Transformer (PVT) for tumor classification and the SegFormer for tumor segmentation, thereby enhancing diagnostic accuracy, speed, and reducing human error in brain tumor detection. Methodology: The proposed framework, BrainDX, utilizes PVT to classify MRI images into tumor types (Gliomas, Meningiomas, Pituitary Tumors, and Healthy Brain), and SegFormer to segment tumor regions in real-time. The dataset consists of annotated MRI images that undergo preprocessing (normalization, resizing, and augmentation). The models are trained and evaluated based on performance metrics, including accuracy, Dice score, Intersection over Union (IoU), and segmentation time. Results: The framework was evaluated across three benchmark MRI datasets, achieving a classification accuracy of 94.0% and a Dice score of 0.87 for tumor segmentation. SegFormer demonstrated real-time segmentation, processing MRI images in under 50 ms. Both models maintained high efficiency while delivering robust performance, even in cases of irregular tumor boundaries. Future Scope: Future work will focus on further optimizing the model for real-time clinical use, improving generalization across diverse tumor types and MRI modalities. This AI-powered system has the potential to enhance diagnostic processes and improve patient outcomes significantly.
Article Title: BrainDx: a dual-transformer framework using PVT and SegFormer for tumor diagnosis

Abstract: Classifying brain tumors from MRI images is a crucial task in medical imaging, requiring efficient and accurate deep learning models. Convolutional Neural Networks capture local spatial features, while Vision Transformers excel at global dependencies. However, individual models face feature redundancy, high dimensionality, and computational inefficiencies. This research introduces a hybrid deep learning framework that integrates Convolutional Neural Networks, including ResNet18 and EfficientNetB0, with Vision Transformers (base) to enhance feature extraction. To further optimize performance, Particle Swarm Optimization and Ant Colony Optimization were employed for feature selection to reduce redundancy. The optimized features are then classified using both deep learning-based neural networks and machine learning classifiers, including the Weighted K-nearest neighbor algorithm, Fuzzy KNN, and XGBoost. ViT + ResNet + Particle Swarm Optimization achieved the highest accuracy (99%), highlighting the effectiveness of ResNet's residual learning. While Ant Colony Optimization occasionally outperformed Particle Swarm Optimization in accuracy, Particle Swarm Optimization proved superior in computational efficiency. Additionally, Weighted and Fuzzy KNN classifiers performed competitively alongside neural networks, demonstrating the relevance of optimized traditional machine learning methods. Experimental results demonstrate that feature selection significantly enhances classification accuracy while reducing computational complexity.
Article Title: An optimized hybrid deep learning based approach for brain tumor classification

Abstract: Spike sorting is a critical process in neurophysiology for analyzing single-neuron recordings, where its precision significantly affects the reliability of subsequent neural data analyses. Despite the effectiveness of existing methods, they often require manual intervention to adapt to complex neural recording conditions, particularly in high-noise environments.
