Recently, the introduction of vision transformers (ViTs) has significantly altered the landscape of deep segmentation models, due to their ability to capture long-range dependencies. However, we argue that the current design of the ViT-based UNet (ViT-UNet) segmentation models is limited in handling the heterogeneous appearance (e.g., varying shapes and sizes) of target objects that are commonly encountered in medical image segmentation tasks. To tackle this limitation, we present a structured approach to introduce spatially dynamic components into a ViT-UNet. This enables the model to capture features of target objects with diverse appearances effectively. This is achieved by three main components: (i) deformable patch embedding; (ii) spatially dynamic multi-head attention; (iii) multi-scale deformable positional encoding. These components are integrated into a novel architecture, termed AgileFormer, enabling more effective capture of heterogeneous objects at every stage of a ViT-UNet. Experiments in three segmentation tasks using publicly available datasets (Synapse multi-organ, ACDC cardiac, and Decathlon brain tumor datasets) demonstrated the effectiveness of AgileFormer for 2D and 3D segmentation tasks. Remarkably, our AgileFormer sets a new state-of-the-art performance with a Dice Score of 85.74% and 87.43 % for 2D and 3D multi-organ segmentation on Synapse without significant computational overhead. Our code is avaliable at https://github.com/sotiraslab/AgileFormer.
Article Title: AgileFormer: Spatially agile and scalable transformer for medical image segmentation

Abstract: Cardiovascular diseases, particularly arrhythmias, constitute a significant global health concern. Accurate and timely diagnosis of arrhythmias is essential for effective patient care. Traditional arrhythmia detection methods heavily depend on the expertise of clinicians, rendering the process time-consuming and prone to diagnostic errors. This study proposes a multimodal CNN-LSTM-based model augmented with a Cross Attention mechanism for arrhythmia classification. The model integrates multiple data streams, including raw ECG segments and their frequency features, and demonstrates superior performance in arrhythmia detection. The CNN module is designed to extract local features, the LSTM module captures sequential dependencies, and the Cross-Attention mechanism effectively fuses temporal and frequency domain data, enhancing classification performance. The proposed model was validated on the MIT-BIH Arrhythmia Dataset and the PTB Diagnostic Dataset. To address the issue of class imbalance in datasets, techniques such as SMOTE and Tomek Links were employed, significantly improving the model's ability to classify minority classes accurately. The proposed model achieved a classification accuracy of 98.97 %. Additionally, a clinical diagnostic support tool was developed to facilitate practical implementation. This tool provides functionalities for data visualization, model training, and arrhythmia diagnosis, offering a quick and reliable solution for clinical use and bridging the gap between advanced machine learning models and practical medical use.
Article Title: A multimodal cross-attention-based CNN-LSTM network for arrhythmia classification and clinical diagnostic support

Abstract: To address the challenges posed by the latent nature of facial behaviors and the temporal heterogeneity of depressive symptoms, a multi-scale spatiotemporal enhancement and multi-granularity temporal difference network (SETD-Net) is proposed for depression detection. The proposed SETD-Net consists of a multi-scale spatiotemporal enhancement subnet, a multi-granularity temporal difference subnet, and an adaptive fusion subnet. In the first subnet, a multi-scale enhancement structure (MES), which employs symmetric multi-scale convolution operations to perform bidirectional convolution on spatiotemporal contexts, meticulously captures fine-grained global spatiotemporal semantics of facial behaviors at different scales. In the second subnet, a multi-granularity difference mechanism (MDM), which utilizes first- and second-order temporal difference operations to encode the changing characteristics of facial movements, extracts dynamic difference semantics at different granularities. In the adaptive fusion subnet, a dual-stage attention strategy (DAS) is designed to effectively fuse the global spatiotemporal semantics and the dynamic difference semantics. Specially, to reduce computational complexity and adapt to small-sample depression datasets, a plug-and-play 3D inverted residual module (3D-IR), which leverages depthwise separable convolution to replace the full-channel convolution in the 3D-CNN, is constructed and embedded into the first two subnets. The experimental results indicate that the proposed SETD-Net achieves competitive performance with the MAE and RMSE of 6.06 and 7.60 on AVEC2013, as well as 6.03 and 7.59 on AVEC2014. Compared with other related methods, the proposed end-to-end network, which outperforms in terms of MAE and RMSE metrics, indeed enhances the performance of depression detection.
Article Title: SETD-Net: Multi-scale spatiotemporal enhancement and multi-granularity temporal difference network for depression detection

Abstract: Accurate and timely identification of bacterial pathogens is essential for effective clinical decision-making, particularly amid the growing challenge of antibiotic resistance. This study presents an alignment-free deep learning framework for classifying bacterial species from high-resolution microscopic images using a vision transformer (ViT) backbone. Unlike traditional approaches that rely on spatial alignment or region-specific preprocessing, our method operates directly on full-field images without positional standardization, enabling robust performance under diverse imaging conditions. The dataset comprises 871 images spanning six clinically significant bacterial species: Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Enterococcus faecium, and Acinetobacter baumannii. To address class imbalance and improve generalization, we implemented a dual-stage augmentation strategy. Offline augmentation was used to generate synthetic images and balance underrepresented classes. Online augmentation-including rotation, flipping, noise injection, and brightness adjustment-was applied during training to increase variability and enhance robustness. This strategy enabled the model to achieve strong performance despite its architectural simplicity. Our method achieved an accuracy of 98.51 %, precision of 97.91 %, recall of 99.17 %, F1-score of 98.52 %, AUROC of 0.9991, and AUPRC of 0.9964. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of combining alignment-free modeling with dual augmentation strategies. The proposed approach offers a scalable and clinically applicable solution for bacterial identification in medical laboratories, with potential for integration into clinical workflows. This study also contributes a high-quality, labeled dataset to the research community, supporting further advances in alignment-free bacterial identification technologies.
Article Title: Alignment-free bacterial pathogen identification using vision transformer and image augmentation techniques in high-resolution microscopy

Abstract: Background and Objective: Electrocardiograms (ECGs) are essential for diagnosing cardiac pathologies, yet traditional paper-based ECG storage poses significant challenges for automated analyses. Despite the growing interest in leveraging AI for ECG analysis, there remains a lack of accessible, fully automated tools for digitizing paper-based ECGs. Existing solutions are often incomplete, behind paywalls, or not suited for large-scale use. To address this gap, we present ECGTIzER: an open-source, fully automated tool that enables high-fidelity digitization of paper ECGs, ensuring long-term preservation of clinical data and unlocking their potential for modern AI-driven analysis. Methods: ECGTIzER employs automated lead detection, three different pixel-based signal extraction algorithms, and a deep learning-based signal reconstruction module. We evaluated ECGTIzER on two datasets: a real-life cohort from the COVID-19 pandemic (JOCOVID) and a publicly available dataset (PTB-XL). Performance was compared with two existing methods: the fully automated ECGMINER and the semi-automated PAPERECG, which requires human intervention. The tools' digitization performance was assessed in terms of signal recovery, the fidelity of clinically relevant feature measurement and downstream AI classification tasks on a third dataset (GENEREPOL). Results: Results show that ECGTIzER outperforms state-of-the-art methods, with its ECGTIzERFrag algorithm delivering superior signal recovery performance. While PAPERECG demonstrated better outcomes than ECGMINER, it also requires human input. Conclusions: ECGTIzER enhances the usability of historical ECG data and supports advanced AI-based diagnostic methods, making it a valuable addition to the field of AI in ECG analysis.
Article Title: ECGTIzER: An open-source, fully automated pipeline for digitization and signal recovery from paper electrocardiograms

Abstract: Background: The accurate classification of dental images is pivotal for precise dental diagnosis and subsequent treatment planning. Existing methods often struggle to fully capture the complex and subtle features within dental images. The purpose of this study is to revolutionize dental image classification by introducing an innovative approach that can overcome these limitations, thereby enhancing the reliability and efficiency of dental diagnostics. Methods: We integrate an Agent Attention mechanism into the Vision Transformer within the Conformer architecture. The Agent Attention mechanism is meticulously designed to adaptively direct the model's focus towards the most discriminative regions in dental images. This is achieved through a series of operations that enhance the model's ability to extract relevant features at different scales. Experiments were conducted on the DENTEX2023 dataset, which includes 1005 fully annotated panoramic X-ray images covering four dental conditions: caries, deep caries, periapical lesions, and impacted teeth. Results: The proposed model achieved a classification accuracy of 92.5% on the test set. It also demonstrated precision (90.2%), recall (91.8%), and F1-score (91.0%) for disease classes. Ablation studies confirmed that the Agent Attention mechanism is critical, with its removal leading to a 4.5% drop in accuracy. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art algorithms. Conclusion: In conclusion, this research presents a novel and effective approach for dental image classification. The proposed model not only fills the existing gaps in the field but also offers a promising solution for future dental diagnostic applications.
Article Title: Enhancing dental disease classification with agent attention infused vision transformer in conformer architecture

Abstract: Background: Ballistocardiogram (BCG), a vibration signal generated by cardiac ejection, demonstrates promising potential for blood pressure (BP) estimation. Existing data-driven models estimate BP from BCG as black-box predictors and therefore generalize poorly across populations while offering little physiological insight. Methods: Building on recent findings that BCG is a superposition of intra-aortic blood pressure waveforms (BP waveforms), we propose a B-spline based BP waveform decomposition (BPWD) to extract BP waveform features for BP estimation. By leveraging particle swarm optimization to refine B-spline control points, BPWD generates physiologically plausible BP waveforms whose superposition (generated-BCG) aligns morphologically with measured-BCG. However, between generated-BCG and measured-BCG, there is a scaling discrepancy (Sd) that affects BPWD. In our study, two BPWDs have been proposed: BPWD_avgSd uses the average Sd value of all measurements with known BP values; BPWD_optSd optimizes Sd in terms of both the pulse pressure difference calculated using a prior formula based on BCG waveform features and height and weight, and root-mean-square error between the generated BCG (scaled by Sd) and the measured BCG. Results: Based on 69 measurements from 23 participants, linear-regression models built on BP waveform features extracted by BPWDs outperformed the model built on BCG waveform features. The mean absolute error (mmHg) for diastolic/systolic/pulse pressure were BPWD_optSd-5.9/8.9/7.4; BPWD_avgSd-6.0/9.3/7.6; and BCG waveform features-6.5/11.5/8.7, respectively. Conclusions: BPWD effectively decomposes the BCG into BP waveforms whose features better support linear-regression BP estimation than BCG waveform features. The superior performance of BPWD_OptSd over BPWD_avgSd demonstrates that optimizing Sd further enhances BPWD performance.
Article Title: Accurate blood pressure waveform decomposition and feature extraction using Ballistocardiogram mechanism

Abstract: Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis is a common spinal disease that can be evaluated by calculating the Cobb angle. Manual Cobb angle calculation is subjective and time-consuming. However, automated Cobb angle prediction methods have limitations, such as prediction errors for vertebrae and inaccurate landmark detection. Accordingly, we propose an improved two-stage approach that first applies YOLOv7 to screen and segment each of the target vertebrae for landmark prediction. Subsequently, to improve landmark detection accuracy, the approach applies our developed multibranch network, denoted as Vertebra Centroid Radiation Landmark Detection Network (VCRLD-Net), which includes a Long-Range Squeeze Omnidimensional Attention (LSOA) module, for individual vertebra analysis. Experiments revealed that VCRLD-Net achieved a mean distance error of 8.82, a circular mean absolute error for angles of 2.38 degrees, and a symmetric mean absolute percentage error of 5.01%, outperforming previously proposed methods.
Article Title: Automatic spinal Cobb angle measurements from X-ray images using a novel vertebra centroid radiation landmark detection network

Abstract: Several radiological patterns associated with pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) have been identified on chest X-rays (CXR) used for screening purposes. As a result, several automatic computational tools have emerged for this purpose. We propose a new algorithm, two-dimensional multiscale symbolic dynamic entropy (MSDE2D), to develop a computational tool sensitive to these subtle patterns variations and noise robustness for evaluating CXR images from healthy and TB-diagnosed individuals. The one-dimensional SDE algorithm was previously shown to be more efficient in detecting amplitude variations and in computational calculations (compared to other entropy algorithms). Additionally, we also extracted first-order statistical parameters like standard deviation (SD), and mean of positive pixels (MPP), among others. These MSDE2D and first-order texture features were used to detect TB in each lung individually. The MSDE2D was validated using a synthetic dataset and optimized for the best set of parameters. We verified that, for both lungs, the MSDE2D values were significantly different between healthy and TB CXR images (P < 0.05), and the effect size was |d| >0.23. From the first-order parameters, only the mean, SD, entropy, and MPP were statistically different between both groups for the left lung (P < 0.05; |d| >0.22). For the right lung, all first-order features significantly differentiated TB patients (P < 0.05; |d| >0.28). Finally, we show that a multi-layer perceptron obtained 86.4 and 85.2% accuracy in detecting TB in the left and right lungs, respectively. The highest sensitivity values achieved in this study were 71.4% and 81.8% for the left and right lungs, respectively.
Article Title: Tuberculosis detection on chest X-rays using two-dimensional multiscale symbolic dynamic entropy

Abstract: Background: Keratoconus (KCN) is a progressive corneal disorder that leads to visual distortion and increases the risk of complications during refractive surgical procedures. Accurate and early diagnosis is critical for effective clinical management. Objective: This work presents a novel deep learning model for keratoconus classification from corneal topographic images. Problem: Conventional diagnostic models are based on corneal topography and biomechanical properties. These processes are time-consuming and prone to variability. Methodology: This work presents an optimization based Deep Learning (DL) model Grey Goose Optimization (GGO) based Convolutional Transformer (CT) model for KCN classification. The model considers the feature extraction capabilities of convolutional neural network (CNN) and the attention mechanism of transformers for enhancing classification accuracy. The GGO is integrated for fine-tuning the hyperparameters of the model and improving its robustness. Findings: The proposed approach is evaluated on a Keratoconus detection dataset and shown superior performance compared to conventional DL models. The outcomes shows the robustness of the suggested approach in correctly categorizing KCN by achieving accuracy of 99.2% and precision of 98.9% Conclusion: The proposed CT-GGO provides the way for automatic and reliable diagnostic tools in ophthalmology. Recommendations: Future research will demonstrate cross-center validation, larger data, and multi-modal inputs for improving model generalization and interpretability.
Article Title: Biomedical image-based keratoconus classification using convolutional transformers and grey goose optimization

Abstract: Today, the healthcare industry mostly uses the electronic record of the patient's health, also known as the electronic health record or simply EHR. However, since the health records contain highly confidential patient information shared across computerized systems, it is under threat from hackers and cybercriminals, data theft and unauthorized access. Healthcare information is sensitive, requires to be whole and accessible and this is a major challenge that needs strong security solutions. Here, we present the Contextual Polynomial-Based Data Protection Model (CPDPM), a new additive model designed to improve clinical data security through the use of advanced encryption and access control methods in conjunction with a polynomial-based data protection model, specifically developed for the healthcare context. The major issues we observed regarding clinical data protection are based around the issues of encryption strength as well as the consequences, such as the performance and utilization of resources. Furthermore, access restrictions and data integrity have to be dynamic and respond to changes of a system, especially if it involves multiple parties. Our approach handles these considerations since the proposed polynomial-based framework guarantees the security of the data as well as scalability to huge healthcare systems. We determined the performance of the proposed model by assessing restrictive access system, and the encryption and decryption time analysis, data security, through put, and network overhead analysis using real EHR datasets. In comparison with other models such CP-BDHCA, EHRC, B-IBE and HH-IPFS, our model gave better results. For example, CPDPM had higher performance than HH-IPFS by 9 % and then CP-BDHCA by 18 % in terms of Access Restriction Performance. For Encryption Performance, our proposed model was 8 % more efficient than B-IBE, and for decryption performance, the findings also reveal that our model is 14 % more efficient than HH-IPFS. Moreover, Security Performance indicated a coverage of at least 20 % in comparison to conventional data security, and throughput performance recorded improvement of 12 % responding to existing systems.
Article Title: Enhancing clinical data security with the contextual polynomial-based data protection model (CPDPM)

Abstract: Background and objective: Kidney abnormalities have emerged as a significant health concern in recent years. These abnormalities gradually diminish kidney functionality and can result in kidney failure if not addressed promptly. Therefore, early detection is crucial to prevent the loss of kidney function. Methods: This study aims to develop an automated diagnostic system (ADS) designed to identify kidney abnormalities at an early stage using 2-D clinical ultrasound images. The proposed method detects various kidney abnormalities, including tumors, stones, and cysts. The performance of the existing systems are poor with the noisy clinical ultrasound images, prompting the development of a robust ADS capable of detecting these abnormalities in both noisy and high-quality 2-D ultrasound images. The robust ADS utilizes a lightweight deep learning model as its base model, modifying the layers to create a fine-tuned network specifically for ultrasound images, named the Ultrasound Network (US-Net). This fine-tuned model extracts features from both high-quality and noisy ultrasound images. These extracted features are then fed into the Ensemble Classification Module (ECM). The ECM combines predictions from three different classifiers, ultimately generating a final prediction through a majority voting procedure. Results: The performance of the proposed system is evaluated with the quality and noisy ultrasound images. The proposed ADS have achieved 92.49% accuracy in testing with the quality ultrasound images. In the noisy environment, proposed ADS have achieved 86.96% accuracy in predicting different class of kidney abnormalities. From the experimental analysis, the presented system proved to be superior and robust against state-of-the-art methods in detecting kidney diseases from clinical ultrasound images. Conclusion: This study presents an automated method to detect the kidney abnormalities using proposed lightweight network. The proposed ADS will be useful tool for nephrologists to detect various kidney abnormalities from clinical ultrasound images.
Article Title: Automated diagnosis tool for clinical ultrasound image analysis in kidney disease identification

Abstract: Medical images provide critical visual information for disease diagnosis and surgical navigation in biomedical engineering. Recent progress has demonstrated that deep learning techniques play a pivotal role in addressing these challenges through powerful network architectures and meticulously designed loss functions. This paper proposes FusionDenoNet, a novel hourglass-structured architecture designed to efficiently encode discriminative features within high-resolution feature maps for Low-Dose CT (LDCT) denoising. The network processes input LDCT images through cascaded FusionAggr blocks comprising two key components: the Moga Block and Sobel Attention Block. The Moga Block, based on multi-order context aggregation, progressively enhances discriminative feature representations, ensuring preservation of original high-resolution information while creating complementary features across multiple spatial scales to extract both global and local information. The Sobel Attention Block dynamically adjusts input by incorporating edge-enhancement information, preserving important structural details during denoising. The model was evaluated on three public datasets and demonstrated superior performance compared to previous state-of-the-art models across various architectures. On the Mayo test set, FusionDenoNet achieved an average PSNR of 33.6836, SSIM of 0.9185, and RMSE of 8.4671. On the LDCT-and-Projection-data dataset, it recorded the lowest RMSE, outperforming its closest competitor UNAD by approximately 0.50% on head LDCT images and 0.80% on chest LDCT images. Visual quality tests using the LoDoInd dataset exhibited high-quality LDCT denoising, showcasing robust generalization capabilities while maintaining parameter efficiency and computational performance. Our approach proves competitive with advanced LDCT denoising techniques in both visual quality and quantitative performance, highlighting its potential to enhance medical image processing in biomedical engineering.
Article Title: FusionDenoNet: A novel hourglass-based deep learning framework for enhanced noise reduction in medical imaging

Abstract: Alzheimer's Disease (AD) is a progressive and irreversible neurodegenerative disorder that poses a significant global health burden. Early and accurate prediction of the conversion from Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) to AD is critical for timely intervention and personalized treatment planning. In this study, we introduce AlzFusionFormer, a novel transformer-based deep learning framework specifically designed to forecast the progression of MCI into either MCI non-converted (MCInc) or MCI converted (MCIc). Unlike traditional architectures, AlzFusionFormer employs a multi-branch transformer fusion architecture that simultaneously learns from multi-modal data-including neuropsychological assessments, volumetric features of Regions of Interest (ROIs), and 3D structural MRI scans. The framework is trained and validated using the ADNI-1 and ADNI-2 datasets, achieving validation accuracies of 81.62% and 88.67%, and prediction accuracies of 79.76% and 86.89%, respectively. Importantly, we integrate SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) and self-attention map visualizations to provide interpretable AI insights, revealing the relative importance of imaging and cognitive features in conversion risk. This interpretability supports clinically meaningful decision-making, enhancing trust and transparency in model predictions. Our results demonstrate that AlzFusionFormer significantly outperforms existing uni-modal and multi-modal baselines, showcasing the potential of transformer-based architectures in the early detection of neurodegenerative progression through context-aware, modality-sensitive representation learning.
Article Title: AlzFusionFormer: Integrating multiple transformers for early Alzheimer's disease detection from multi-modal data

Abstract: Lung cancer, a global leading cause of incidence and mortality, demands accurate detection. Current research primarily targets early nodule detection and distinguishing benign from malignant tumors, with limited focus on lung cancer classification. Identifying various lung cancer types is vital for tailored treatments, while challenges persist in localizing small lesions and early tumors. To tackle these challenges, we propose the framework integrated the Channel Equally-Divided (CED) and the Coordinate Attention Feature Pyramid Network (CAFPN). CAFPN, an innovative feature pyramid structure, integrates the Semantic Information Enhanced (SIE) module and Coordinate Attention. The SIE module filters redundant semantic information, enriches texture features through Coordinate Attention, emphasizes shallow semantic details, and amplifies trustworthy specifics for enhanced deep semantic information. Additionally, the CED module is devised to proficiently extract local contextual information across channels for more precise feature representations. The superior performance of our proposed method was empirically validated through comparative experiments on two mainstream datasets with Competition Performance Metric (CPM) scores and Mean Average Precision (mAP) values reaching 0.942 and 99.18%, respectively, outperforming current state-of-the-art approaches.
Article Title: Integrated Channel Equally-Divided and Coordinate Attention Feature Pyramid for subtype detection of lung cancer

Abstract: Computer-aided diagnostic methods for white blood cells (WBCs) help pathologists diagnose and treat various blood disorders and reduce the reliance on manual reviews. The paper addresses segmentation domain adaptation for enhanced white blood cell image classification. By leveraging cross-domain segmentation information, we boost the learning of intracellular representation for white blood cells without the interference of the backgrounds. The whole network training is composed of domain adaptation training and task training. While the first aims to learn segmentation information from the source datasets, the second aims to apply the segmentation domain knowledge to assist feature training for WBC classification. To fully utilize the encoder feature, we propose spatial co-occurrence feature embedding to enhance comprehensive information of the input image and boundary detection of the nucleus. To learn a better intercellular structure, a reconstruction loss is proposed to enforce the network to learn correct nucleus and cytoplasm shapes. During task training, a nuclear-cytoplasmic knowledge-aware classifier is trained based on the domain adaptation knowledge of nuclear and cytoplasmic features to mitigate background interference and achieve better WBC classification results. Our approach achieves a new state-of-the-art weighted average F1-score of 99.21% in the PBC dataset, outperforming the second best method by 1.83%. In the AML data set, our method achieves a weighted F1-score of 95.98% outperforming the second best method by 3.03% and obtains the highest F1-scores in 13 out of 15 categories, demonstrating strong generalization in morphologically diverse WBC types.
Article Title: Segmentation domain adaptation for enhanced white blood cell classification using spatial co-occurrence feature embedding

Abstract: Accurate polyp segmentation from colonoscopy images is pivotal for the early detection of colorectal cancer (CRC), significantly enhancing diagnostic efficiency and reliability in clinical practice. While recent methods have achieved notable progress, they often suffer from two critical limitations: (1) inadequate frequency and spatial feature representation, as most approaches remain biased toward spatial-domain learning and, even when incorporating frequency information, tend to overlook the hierarchical variability of frequency distributions across feature levels, resulting in suboptimal utilization of frequency cues; and (2) insufficient cross-level feature integration, limiting the ability to effectively capture both global semantics and fine-grained boundary details. To address these issues, we propose PSFS-Net, a novel dynamic frequency-spatial synergistic polyp segmentation framework that jointly leverages spatial and frequency domain information for hierarchical context refinement and cross-level fusion, which mainly includes Frequency-aware Cross-scale Fusion Module (FACFM), Dual-stream Global-Local Interaction Module (DGIM), and Dual Attention Cross-modulation Module (DCM). Specifically, FACFM is designed to extract frequency domain cues and adaptively decoupling high/lowfrequency components from full-spectrum information by employs Discrete Fourier Transform and an adaptive Dynamic Gaussian Filters. DGIM is introduced to enable mutual refinement between high-level semantic representations and low-level spatial details through dedicated global and local processing branches. DCM is presented to further aggregate global contexts with local details via dual-attention mechanisms, alleviating semantic gaps. Extensive evaluations on five public polyp segmentation datasets demonstrate that PSFS-Net delivers competitive and excellent performances. Our code is available at https://github.com/chljzh25/PSFS-Net.
Article Title: PSFS-Net: Dynamic frequency-spatial synergistic perception network for polyp segmentation via hierarchical context refinement and frequency-domain decoupling

Abstract: The intelligence of Traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) is a future trend in its development. TCM medical records are detailed accounts of a patient's condition, recorded by TCM practitioners using unique TCM terminology during consultation. They are personalized and lack standardized forms, making them more complex than Western medical records. TCM intelligence aims to learn from the diagnostic experiences of predecessors using advanced technological means. Therefore, using deep learning methods to perform named entity recognition on TCM medical records is of great significance for the development of TCM. In this paper, to addresses the poor comprehension ability of existing named entity recognition models for TCM texts, we propose the model combined by bidirectional encoder from Transformers, Multi-head Attention, bidirectional long-short memory, fusion and conditional random field (BERT-BiLSTM-MHA-FUSION-CRF) based on the BERT-BiLSTM-CRF model by introducing the multi-head attention mechanism and multiple fusion layers. In this model, BERT is used to encode and learn from the input text, passing the word vector sequence to the BiLSTM layer to extract multiple local features of the text. The MHA is then utilized to enhance the model's ability to capture different contextual information. As BERT and BiLSTM focus on different feature scales, the outputs from the BERT layer and the MHA are fused again to enrich the semantic sequence features, thereby making the CRF decoding predictions more accurate. We evaluate our method on CCKS2017, CCKS2019, CLUENER, and our self-built TCM medical records dataset TCMYIAN, compared to the current SOTA methods, our approach achieved accuracy improvements of 2.7 %, 2.38 %, 1.2 %, and 0.79 %, respectively.
Article Title: A method of named entity recognition in traditional Chinese medical cases by integrating BERT and BiLSTM

Abstract: Liver tumor segmentation, the intricate process of identifying and delineating tumor anatomical structures or pathological regions from medical liver images, plays a crucial role in assisting physicians with diagnosis and treatment planning. Automatic liver tumor segmentation is a highly complex task due to the low contrast of the target, its wide range of occurrences, and significant scale variations. Inspired by the intricate serial-parallel structure and information processing mechanism of the biological visual system, we propose the bio-inspired parallel pathway network (BPP-Net). In analogy to the parallel pathways of biological vision, BPP-Net consists of three parallel streams composed of antagonistic-Mamba modules at different scales, designed to extract target features across multiple scales. The antagonistic-Mamba module mimics the visual antagonistic properties of cells in the visual pathway, enhancing the network's ability to extract features from low-contrast regions. Furthermore, inspired by the multi-channel interaction characteristics of the bio-visual IT layer, we propose a dual-channel feature fusion decoder to progressively refine segmentation results. We evaluate our method on the LiTS2017 and BEIDC2024 datasets, and the proposed BPP-Net achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance with only 0.14 M parameters, demonstrating promising potential in the field of bio-computer vision.
Article Title: BPP-net: bio-inspired parallel pathway network for liver and tumor segmentation

Abstract: Early detection of hypertension is challenging due to the absence of overt symptoms. To address this, we developed an attention-based deep learning model for predicting hypertension risk, offering detailed interpretability and a comprehensive assessment of an individual's future disease likelihood based on electronic health records (EHRs). Our findings show that incorporating time series data significantly enhances the accuracy of hypertension prediction, achieving an AUC of 0.835 across the entire dataset. The model consistently surpasses traditional machine learning approaches and simple sequential model across various evaluation metrics, underscoring its potential for broad clinical application. The interpretability analysis, grounded in attention scores, effectively identifies decision thresholds for dynamic features and tracks individual risk trajectories. By aligning these risk thresholds with a causal diagram, our model supports clinicians in making informed decisions. This study provides a valuable platform for healthcare providers, aiding in the early identification of high-risk populations and improving long-term management of hypertension, thereby addressing the diverse needs of stakeholders.
Article Title: An interpretable deep learning approach for hypertension risk assessment in the elderly

Abstract: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a progressive disease that irreversibly transforms lung tissue into rigid fibrotic structures, leading to debilitating symptoms such as shortness of breath and chronic fatigue. The heterogeneity and complexity of this disease, particularly regarding its severity and progression rate, have made predicting its future course a complex and challenging task. Besides, traditional diagnostic methods based on clinical evaluations and imaging have limitations in capturing the disease's complexity. Using the Kaggle Pulmonary Fibrosis Progression dataset, which includes computed tomography images, and clinical information, the model predicts changes in forced vital capacity (FVC), a key progression indicator. Our method uses a proposed context-aware sequential-parallel hybrid transformer model and clinical information enrichment for its prediction. The proposed method achieved a Laplace Log-Likelihood score of-6.508, outperforming prior methods and demonstrating superior predictive capabilities. These results highlight the potential of advanced deep learning techniques to provide more accurate and timely predictions, offering a transformative approach to the diagnosis and management of IPF, with implications for improved patient outcomes and therapeutic advancements. Code Availability: GitHub
Article Title: Prognostic model for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis using context-aware sequential-parallel hybrid transformer and enriched clinical information

Abstract: Perforator flap transplantation is a common procedure for repairing large-area soft tissue defects. However, flap necrosis due to vascular crisis remains a major cause of surgical failure. Early detection of blood perfusion disorders is crucial for improving the success rate of flap transplantation. Current monitoring techniques include invasive methods, which carry risks and complexities, as well as non-invasive methods that require expensive equipment and expert evaluation. Bedside observation remains the primary clinical monitoring approach but is subjective and time-consuming. This study proposes an novel flap blood perfusion monitoring scheme based on remote photoplethysmography (rPPG) signals, which allows real-time evaluation of flap perfusion in a non-contact manner to improve monitoring efficiency and accuracy. The method integrates computer vision and signal processing technologies, enabling rapid and accurate assessment of flap blood flow status without additional invasive procedures. Our research aims to provide a more non-invasive and easy-to-use monitoring approach for flap transplantation, thereby enhancing clinical outcomes and increasing transplant success rates.
Article Title: Application of remote photoplethysmography for non-invasive flap blood flow assessment in perforator flap transplantation

Abstract: Efficient simulation of nonlinear soft tissue deformation is crucial for interactive medical applications, particularly for diagnosing and treating fibrotic diseases. A potential framework is provided by extended position-based dynamics (XPBD). However, current approaches frequently struggle to achieve real-time performance, high precision, and numerical stability all at once, which restricts their capacity to generate high-fidelity results. With an emphasis on use in pulmonary fibrosis, this work suggests a novel, optimized XPBD technique designed to overcome these drawbacks. The proposed method introduces three key enhancements to the traditional XPBD framework. First, during the initialization stage, an adaptive initial value strategy is introduced to compensate for external force terms, thereby aligning the simulation's starting position more closely with the ground-truth solution and improving deformation accuracy. Second, to improve the stability of the deformation process, constraint formulations based on the isoparametric element principle are used in the constraint-solving stage to transfer the deformation computation to a common reference coordinate system. Dynamic mode decomposition (DMD) is finally incorporated for reduced-order prediction at the state evolution stage, speeding up the deformation process. Nonlinear fidelity is maximally preserved by this separation of the core solution process from the time scale of reduced-order prediction. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method realistically simulates the deformation of fibrotic lung tissue, exhibiting significant advantages in terms of real-time performance, accuracy, and stability. Additionally, the method's usefulness and potential for clinical integration in medical simulations are shown by the good feedback provided by cooperating surgeons.
Article Title: Effective simulation of nonlinear soft tissue deformation for interactive medical applications: An enhanced XPBD technique

Abstract: Recently, although Transformer performs well in skin lesion segmentation, the inadequacy of its self-attention mechanism for localized feature capture and secondary computational complexity limit real-time applications. This paper proposed FastTrans-Net, a hybrid architectural model of Transformer for the high throughput requirements of skin images. First, Fast SkinAugment is proposed for the scarcity of skin lesion image datasets, which realizes efficient data expansion by decoupling pixel-level augmentation and spatial-level augmentation. Then, Efficient Convolutional Multiplexing ShuffleNet (ECR-ShuffleNet) is proposed to merge the local representation advantage of CNN with the global modeling capability of Transformer. In addition, the shift window hierarchical attention module (SWHA) is designed by combining shift window attention and initial structure (HAT) to capture multi-scale contextual information through the hierarchical windowing mechanism, and carrier token initialization (CTI) is introduced to achieve cross-window long-range dependency modeling, so that each window can be accessed to participate in both local and global representation learning. The experimental results show that Fast SkinAugment enables data diversity enhancement in ISIC2016, ISIC2017, and ISIC2018 datasets, and the FastTrans-Net segmentation effect is better improved compared with other deep learning models, with Dice metrics reaching 92.94 %, 88.72 %, and 88.97 %, respectively. The inference speed is improved by 2.1 times compared to the benchmark Transformer while maintaining competitive segmentation performance, reaching a real-time throughput of 50.22FPS.
Article Title: FastTrans-Net: Fusion network with shift window hierarchical attention in multi-level enhanced space for skin lesion segmentation

Abstract: Neurological disorders, including epilepsy, stroke, and autism spectrum disorder (ASD), significantly impair brain function, necessitating accurate diagnostic approaches. This study proposes a novel "Dynamic Functional Graph Metrics Stacked Convolutional Neural Network (DFGM-SCNN)" to enhance the classification accuracy of these disorders. Existing methods often struggle to address the dynamic nature of brain activity and the limited resolution of Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) data, which complicates the extraction of specific connectivity features. To overcome these challenges, the Multivariate Sliding Window Time-Frequency Dynamic Functional Connectivity (MSW-TFDFC) technique is introduced, enabling the isolation of complex, multi-region connectivity patterns while capturing the temporal dynamics of brain activity. This improves spatial resolution and accommodates the non-linear characteristics of brain function. Furthermore, the Hidden K-means Dynamic Graph Metrics are incorporated to model diurnal patterns and distinguish between connectivity changes driven by circadian rhythms and genuine neurological alterations. These advanced techniques are embedded within the hidden layers of a stacked Convolutional Neural Network, significantly enhancing robustness and classification accuracy. The proposed model achieves a classification accuracy of 99.3%, precision of 98.5%, recall of 98.3%, sensitivity of 98.8%, specificity of 99.2%, and a high AUC of 0.99, outperforming existing approaches. These results demonstrate the efficacy and reliability of the proposed DFGM-SCNN model in providing accurate and robust classification of neurological disorders.
Article Title: Efficient dynamic graph metrics stacked convolutional neural network for classifying the neurological disorder

Abstract: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is widely used in the pathological evaluation and early diagnosis of cervical cancer (CC). Conventional automatic report generation approaches are predominantly designed for single-image analysis, limiting their applicability to MRI sequences that inherently contain richer temporal and spatial information. Furthermore, sequence-based features may introduce redundancy and noise, challenging model robustness. In this study, we propose a CC Chinese report generation method (C3RG) tailored for CC MRI sequences. The proposed framework incorporates a feature refinement network (FRN) to suppress redundant channel information and enhance salient feature representation. In addition, a cross-modal memory network (CMN) and an interactive feed-forward network (IFFN) are integrated into both the encoder and decoder to facilitate efficient multimodal interaction and alignment between image and text modalities. The model is built upon a Transformer-based encoder-decoder architecture. To support training and evaluation, we construct a dedicated dataset consisting of CC MRI sequences and their corresponding Chinese diagnostic reports. Experimental results demonstrate that C3RG outperforms existing state-of-the-art models, achieving BLEU-1, BLEU-2, BLEU-3, BLEU-4, ROUGE-L, and CIDEr scores of 0.458, 0.319, 0.226, 0.165, 0.379, and 0.264, respectively. Ablation studies further confirm the contribution of each component. These results indicate that C3RG holds promise for clinical deployment in automated radiology reporting for CC.
Article Title: A cross-modal Chinese radiology report generation approach for cervical cancer

Abstract: Magnetic resonance (MR) images with a large amount of information, intensity inhomogeneities and weak boundary may cause serious misclassification in image segmentation when the existing soft subspace clustering (SSC) algorithms are used. As for this problem, this paper presents an improved SSC algorithm based on brain storm optimization (BSO) algorithm, called BSOSSC algorithm to segment MR images. In BSOSSC, we introduce an objective function in combination of relaxation boundary constraint and generalized noise clustering (GNC) to remedy the defect that the existing algorithms are sensitive to noisy data firstly. Then, we apply a new calculation method of membership degree to seek the subspace where the cluster class is located. Finally, we use the BSO algorithm to equipoise the local search and the global search and prevent the SSC algorithm from immersing in local optimum in the clustering process. The experimental results of BSOSSC are compared with those of algorithms such as fuzzy C-means (FCM), entropy weighting K-means clustering (EWKM), Minkowski metric weighted K-means clustering (MWK-means), fireworks algorithm-based soft subspace clustering (FWASSC) and subspace clustering via graph filtering based thresholding ridge regression (FTRR) on the UCI datasets, Berkeley Computer Vision images and Simulated Brain Database (SBD) show the superiority of BSOSSC in terms of antinoise, anti-intensity inhomogeneities and precision. Furthermore, the segmentation results of clinical breast MR images have validated the robustness of the BSOSSC algorithm.
Article Title: An improved soft subspace clustering for magnetic resonance images segmentation

Abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG) anomalies are sustained or transient deviations-such as epileptiform spikes, abnormal rhythmic bursts, or pathologically elevated beta power-from the statistical regularities observed in healthy cortical rhythms. We introduce EGDN-KL, a structure-learning graph neural model that couples an explicit Kullback-Leibler divergence term with attention-guided LSTM forecasting to pinpoint such deviations. Evaluated on two public datasets, EGDN-KL achieves Recall 89.4%, Specificity 97.7%, F1 88.3%, and Accuracy 87.3% using its optimal configuration (11 channels, Top-K=10). These results surpass Graph Deviation Networks (GDN), EGDN-Na & iuml;ve, ResCNN, BiLSTM-Attention and GCN baselines, whose best published accuracies range from 58.2% to 82.4%. By capturing both temporal dynamics and inter-channel connectivity, EGDN-KL delivers state-of-the-art anomaly detection while localizing the neural generators that underpin pathological activity.
Article Title: EGDN-KL: Dynamic graph-deviation network for EEG anomaly detection

Abstract: Emotion recognition from speech is essential for various applications in human-computer interaction, customer service, healthcare, and entertainment. However, developing robust and reproducible Speech emotion recognition (SER) systems is challenging due to the complexity of emotions and variability in speech signals. In this paper, we first define the concept of reproducibility in the context of deep learning models. We then introduce SpeechNet, a novel deep learning model designed to enhance reproducibility and robustness in SER. SpeechNet integrates multiple advanced components: speech recall, speech attention, and speech signal refinement modules to effectively capture temporal dependencies and emotional cues in speech signal. Additionally, it incorporates a pre-attention mechanism and a modified routing technique to improve feature emphasis and processing efficiency. We also explore effective acoustic feature fusion technique. Extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that the SpeechNet model achieves better performance and reproducibility compared to existing models. By addressing reproducibility and robustness, SpeechNet sets a new standard in SER, facilitating reliable and practical applications.
Article Title: Pre-attentive speech signal processing with adaptive routing for emotion recognition

Abstract: Objective: Downstream of noninvasive fetal electrocardiography (fECG) extraction, a post-processing signal enhancement step is generally required. To date, wavelet denoising (WD) was successfully adopted but typically parameterizations are largely empiric. This comprehensive review aims to systematize the knowledge by presenting and assessing WD algorithms for this application. Methods: 17 WD algorithms for fECG enhancement were identified, presented and quantitatively compared on the same public datasets. Overall performance, effectiveness in noise reduction and signal morphology preservation were separately assessed by using a novel methodology based on principal component analysis, to synthetize different performance metrics by a single unbiased index. Results: The comparison reveals different best solutions according to the different analyzed performance, which can be used for a reasoned selection of the right algorithm for a given enhancement problem. The proposed unbiased performance index was effective in supporting the analysis. Conclusions: WD represents a powerful tool for fECG enhancement, but the parameterizations severely affect the algorithm performance. Our findings can be used for a reasoned selection of an algorithm or for the proposal of new WD approaches. Significance: This review fills a knowledge gap by providing a comprehensive literature review for WD postprocessing of noninvasive fECG. Beyond presenting the state-of-the-art, it is also a ready benchmark for the development of new solutions and a guide for researchers in the field, as well as in other biomedical signal processing applications.
Article Title: Wavelet-based algorithms for noninvasive fetal ECG post-processing: A methodological review

Abstract: Medical image segmentation is an essential task in medical image analysis, playing a crucial role in improving the accuracy of disease diagnosis and the efficiency of treatment planning. Despite extensive research efforts and notable technological advancements of deep learning, its performance is often limited by the necessity for vast amounts of accurately labeled images, which are inherently costly and labor-intensive to procure. To mitigate this challenge, this study proposes a novel semi-supervised segmentation using Multi-Scale Consistency Adversarial Learning (MSCAL). By leveraging few annotated images, this method constructs a comprehensive data augmentation perturbation space, incorporating both image-level strong-weak perturbations alongside multi-scale feature perturbations. Furthermore, strong-weak consistency regularization and multi-scale adversarial learning strategies across diverse scales of the segmentation network are implemented. Furthermore, the method utilizes adaptive weighted pyramid consistency loss to encourage consistent predictions across scales, and emphasizes consistency in high-confidence regions through the confidence maps outputted by the discriminator. Finally, the advantages of our proposed model are rigorously evaluated on the ACDC and BraTS2019 datasets, where it is systematically compared against ten state-of-the-art semi-supervised methods. Experimental results demonstrate the model's superiority across DSC, HD95, ASD metrics and pvalue. Notably, with only 3 annotated samples, this method achieves at least 4.2%, 2.2%, and 1.6% gains in segmentation accuracy for the right ventricle, myocardium, and left ventricle, respectively. Ablation studies further corroborate this innovative framework enables the acquisition of richer feature representations and bolstering model robustness for semi-supervised medical image segmentation tasks.
Article Title: Semi-supervised medical image segmentation method using multi-scale consistency adversarial learning

Abstract: This study investigates the therapeutic potential of plasma-activated reactive oxygen and nitrogen species (RONS) in inducing apoptosis in LN229 glioblastoma cells, which are notably resistant to apoptosis. Plasmaactivated medium (PAM) was generated using a commercially available cold plasma jet and applied under controlled laboratory conditions. A full factorial experimental design was employed to optimize treatment parameters, identifying optimal conditions of 0.62 W plasma power, 3 L/min airflow rate, 210-second treatment duration, and a 2 cm electrode gap. MTT assays revealed that plasma treatment under these conditions reduced LN229 cell viability to 38.28 %, significantly lower than the model-estimated 57.60 %. Optical emission spectroscopy (OES) confirmed the generation of RONS, with elevated levels of H2O2, O3, and NO detected in the plasma-treated medium. Fluorescence microscopy demonstrated increased intracellular ROS expression, suggesting efficient uptake and hydroxyl radical activity within cells. Furthermore, gene expression analysis revealed that plasma treatment modulated the expression of apoptosis-related genes, including aquaporin 4 (AQP4), beta-catenin, and connexin 43 (Cx43), which are critical for water channel regulation and intercellular communication but remain underexplored in plasma cancer treatment. The findings indicate that plasmagenerated RONS function as intracellular signaling modulators to induce apoptosis without causing direct necrosis. A strong correlation was observed between RONS concentrations and reduced cell viability. Overall, this study highlights the promising application of cold plasma-generated RONS as a potential therapeutic approach for glioblastoma treatment and underscores the need for further investigation into plasma-based therapies for targeting apoptosis-resistant cancer cells.
Article Title: Impact of plasma-generated reactive oxygen and nitrogen species (RONS) on apoptosis induction in LN229 cells

Abstract: Early diagnosis of breast cancer can substantially improve patient survival rates. The Contrast-Enhanced Ultrasound videos effectively capture dynamic blood perfusion information and has become a common diagnostic tool for clinicians. However, the critical challenge inherent to breast ultrasound samples is the lack of class discriminability due to insufficient morphological feature distinctions. This study constructs an angular margin-based contrastive learning framework for breast ultrasound video diagnosis, aiming to enhance class discriminability. We employed a classical temporal segment network to extract video feature representations and utilized a teacher-student structure to enable video diagnosis training under both supervised and unsupervised conditions. More importantly, we proposed a novel variable angular margin-based contrastive learning loss function to optimize the distribution of representations. This loss function dynamically adjusts inter-class relationships to mitigate interference from easily confused classes. It also provides geometric interpretability and significantly enhances inter-class discriminability. Our method achieved a classification accuracy of 91.18%, with a sensitivity of 85.46% and a specificity of 95.65% on Contrast-Enhanced Ultrasound video dataset, surpassing other state-of-the-art approaches by a large margin. This study introduces inter-class angular margins and contrastive learning, significantly enhancing the class discriminability of breast nodules and offering valuable insights for medical applications suffering class confusion.
Article Title: The angular margin-based contrastive learning framework for breast ultrasound video diagnosis

Abstract: The diagnosis and treatment of Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) typically rely on accurate sleep staging. To address the issue of significantly reduced sleep staging accuracy caused by sleep fragmentation in OSA patients, we propose an innovative automatic sleep staging model for OSA based on spatio-temporal collaborative information extraction, named OSA-STNet (Spatio-Temporal Neural Network). The model incorporates the Multi-Scale Channel Interaction (MSCI) module to facilitate spatio-temporal information interaction across different spatial domains and extract spatio-temporal collaborative features. The Progressive Dual Convolution (PDC) module is designed to capture detailed, local, and global temporal information, amplifying temporal features to higher dimensions for high-precision sleep staging in OSA patients. The model's effectiveness was validated using five-fold cross-validation on the SHHS dataset and the SHHS-OSA dataset, achieving classification accuracies of 89.23% and 87.9%, respectively. Experimental results demonstrate that OSA-STNet leverages spatio-temporal collaborative information extraction to achieve high-precision sleep staging for both healthy individuals and OSA patients. Furthermore, we developed graded models to investigate changes in sleep architecture in OSA patients with varying severities, providing valuable insights for healthcare professionals in the diagnosis and treatment of OSA.
Article Title: OSA-STNet: An automatic sleep staging model for OSA based on spatio-temporal collaborative information extraction

Abstract: Accurately estimating aortic blood pressure (ABP) waveforms is crucial for cardiovascular health assessment and clinical intervention. However, direct measurement of ABP is challenging owing to its invasiveness and the complex arterial dynamics involved. To address this issue, we introduce a machine learning-based approach utilizing a cross-encoder with an autoencoder-hetero-decoder (AE-HD) architecture. This transfer function is designed to precisely convert radial blood pressure (RBP) waveforms into ABP waveforms. The training phase comprises an auto-encoding step to learn latent RBP representations and a hetero-decoding step to estimate the ABP waveform from the encoded RBP waveform. The proposed model was trained and evaluated on in silico datasets, achieving mean absolute errors of 0.53 f 0.37, 0.46 f 0.49, and 0.30 f 0.28 mmHg for the total waveform, systolic blood pressure, and diastolic blood pressure, respectively, and 2.14 f 2.25 % for the augmentation index estimation. Although the AE-HD model demonstrated high accuracy in these simulations, its generalizability to real-world clinical settings remains to be established. Further validation using real patient data and diverse clinical scenarios is planned. This research holds potential for improving non-invasive cardiovascular monitoring and enhancing patient care across clinical contexts.
Article Title: From radial to aortic pressure: In silico data-driven estimation using an autoencoder

Abstract: In the domain of computer-aided diagnosis, the automatic segmentation technology for medical ultrasound images holds substantial application value. However, the inherent low contrast and high noise characteristics of ultrasound images pose significant challenges to image segmentation. Recently, the Mamba, based on state space models, has garnered important attention for its exceptional long-distance dependency modeling capabilities and linear computational complexity. In this paper, we propose a hybrid network, termed HCMUNet, which seamlessly integrates the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with the Mamba. In the encoder phase, we synergize CNN with Mamba to facilitate the effective extraction of local features and the comprehensive mining of global contextual information. To enhance the semantic hierarchy of skip connection feature maps, we devise the Multiscale Hybrid Attention Fusion module, which amalgamates multi-scale semantic information via a hybrid attention mechanism. In the decoder stage, we incorporate the Attention Regional Feature Enhancement module to augment the regional information of key features throughout the upsampling process. Through validation using four publicly accessible medical ultrasound image datasets, the HCMUNet demonstrated superior experimental outcomes compared to other state-of-the-art methods. The notable advantages demonstrated in the experimental results not only corroborate the immense potential of the HCMUNet in ultrasound image segmentation but also introduce novel paradigms for employing SSM-based approaches in medical image analysis.
Article Title: HCMUNet: A hybrid CNN and Mamba network for medical ultrasound image segmentation

Abstract: Objectives: We aimed to develop a deep learning (DL) framework to predict standard-dose images from low-dose images for both reconstruction and projection domains in SPECT myocardial perfusion imaging (MPI). Methods: We retrospectively enrolled 359 patients who underwent SPECT MPI, to estimate standard-dose data, using half-, quarter-, and one-eighth-dose data. A CycleGAN integrated with self-attention mechanism and skip connection was employed to restore standard-dose SPECT images at different dose levels for reconstruction and projection domains. Quantitative metrics (structural similarity index metrics, SSIM; peak signal-to-noise ratio, PSNR; root mean square error, RMSE) and clinical parameters were calculated to evaluate the image quality. We first evaluated the predicted image quality by conventional PSNR, SSIM and RMSE, based on which, clinical parameters including left ventricular volume (LV), end-systolic volume (ESV), end-systolic volume (EDV) and ejection fraction (EF) were then adopted to assess the clinical feasibility. A commercially available software (PMOD) was adopted to assess the diagnostic accuracy. Furthermore, a comparison experiment was conducted to explore whether projection-domain denoising is superior to the reconstruction domain. Results: For non-gated cases, the lowest RMSE (1.56 f 0.56) and highest PSNR (44.63 f 1.69), SSIM (0.99 f 0.01) were achieved in half-dose reconstructed images. For gated data, the lowest RMSE (2.18 f 0.56) and highest PSNR (43.18 f 1.69), SSIM (0.99 f 0.01) were achieved. The proposed method achieved a performance that surpassed the advanced approaches with lowest RMSE (2.34 f 0.48) and highest PSNR (42.07 f 1.69), SSIM (0.99 f 0.01), maintaining the fastest inference speed. The quantitative performance of the projection domain is superior to that of the reconstruction domain at different dose levels with lowest RMSE (half: 1.24 f 0.42; quarter: 1.97 f 0.46; one-eighth: 3.86 f 0.62) and highest PSNR (half: 46.18 f 1.67; quarter: 45.57 f 1.52; one-eighth: 40.16 f 1.63), SSIM (half:0.99 f 0.01; quarter: 0.99 f 0.01; one-eighth: 0.99 f 0.01). The polar map analysis demonstrated the improved RMSEs (LAD: 2.02 f 0.37; LCX: 2.15 f 0.41; RCA: 2.02 f 0.35). Conclusion: The proposed method improves the quality of the estimated images in both reconstruction and projection domains. Projection-domain denoising surpasses the reconstruction domain for SPECT MPI.
Article Title: DuDoCS-Net: dual-domain and self-attention based CycleGAN for low-dose SPECT myocardial perfusion image enhancement

Abstract: A brain tumor is an abnormal growth of brain cells, some of which may develop into cancer. Timely detection and effective treatment significantly improve patient outcomes and life expectancy. MRI images are commonly used in clinical settings for non-invasive brain tumor detection. Classifying various brain tumor types is challenging due to their diverse characteristics. Deep learning (DL) models have been applied to classify brain tumors, but their accuracy still faces challenges due to complexity. This paper introduces ShallowMRI, a lightweight CNN model for classifying brain tumor categories in MRI images. The model features an innovative attention mechanism that improves its ability to focus on relevant features for accurate classification. Erosion and dilation techniques are used to identify optimal contours, removing unnecessary regions. Additionally, Local Binary Patterns (LBP) enhance image preprocessing by reducing computational costs and optimizing feature extraction. ShallowMRI's performance is evaluated against pre-trained models and existing methods using three benchmark datasets: Kaggle Multiclass, BR35H Binary, and Histogram Binary. The results show that ShallowMRI outperforms other models with accuracies of 98.24 %, 98.16 %, and 99.70 %, respectively, for the three datasets. It also maintains lower computational costs (25.4 G Flops), ensuring reliable performance across different MRI imaging scenarios.
Article Title: ShallowMRI: A novel lightweight CNN with novel attention mechanism for Multi brain tumor classification in MRI images

Abstract: Alzheimer's disease (AD) involves progressive cognitive decline and disrupted dynamic functional connectivity (dFC). Although music therapy is promising for AD, most studies use static analysis and overlook the timevarying nature of sound and brain responses. Therefore, this study used EEG-based dFC analysis and Phase Lag Index (PLI) to assess neural responses of healthy controls (HC), mild AD, and severe AD patients during a 60second Jasmine Flower music stimulus, focusing on the climax phase (20-45 s). A time-weighted dynamic network integrating time distance, path strength, and path number was constructed, and a novel Time-Global Weighted Efficiency (TGWE) metric was proposed to quantify compensatory mechanisms. Results showed enhanced prefrontal-parietal connectivity and improved global efficiency in AD patients during the climax, approaching HC levels. Network metrics under music stimulation correlated positively with MMSE scores (p < 0.01). Mild AD patients-maintained path number but showed reduced path strength, while severe AD patients exhibited deterioration across all parameters; TGWE correlated with disease severity (R2 = 0.55, p = 0.0056). Findings highlight music climax as a modulator of dFC and introduce a time-weighted framework for assessing spatiotemporal brain network plasticity in AD.
Article Title: Impact of musical stimulation versus resting-state on dynamic functional connectivity in Alzheimer's patients: a time-weighted network modeling study

Abstract: Hierarchical models have shown promise in EEG-based emotion recognition by capturing spatial relationships through the joint analysis of local and global brain activities. However, achieving finer-grained, emotion-specific spatial partitioning in the 2D EEG representation and effectively integrating local-to-global information remain significant challenges. To address these limitations, we propose the Hierarchical Spatial-Frequency Bi-Patch Mamba (HSF-BPM) network - a novel framework to adapt Mamba's state-space modeling for 2D EEG spatial pattern analysis. Our framework incorporates: (1) a Channel-wise Frequency Encoder (CFE) utilizing Fully Connected Networks (FCN) to model inter-frequency relationships and enhance spectral information per electrode; (2) a Local Spatial Feature Extractor (LSFE) combining dynamic convolution with Selective Kernel Networks (SKNet) to capture multi-scale, emotion-specific brain activity patterns; and (3) a Global Spatial Feature Extractor (GSFE) built upon the Mamba network with bidirectional patch partitioning to model full 2D spatial relationships in EEG data. Extensive experiments on SEED, SEED-IV and DEAP datasets demonstrate state-of-the-art performance. Our in-depth analysis has further identified the core collaborative mechanisms among all components, with particular emphasis on the pivotal role of the Mamba network within the architecture. The results demonstrate the superiority of our biologically inspired, Mamba-driven hierarchical approach in EEG emotion recognition, establishing a theoretical and methodological foundation for both affective computing and broader cognitive state recognition using EEG. The code is publicly available at https://github.com/lxy185/HSF-BPM.
Article Title: From local to global: A hierarchical spatial-frequency Bi-patch Mamba network for EEG-based emotion recognition

Abstract: The conventional electrode configuration that is generally used for electrooculography (EOG)-based gaze estimation comprises two bipolar channels, which are computed from the EOG signals recorded from two horizontally-aligned electrodes next to the outer canthi and two vertically-aligned electrodes attached superiorly and inferiorly to one of the eyes, respectively. While other unconventional electrode configurations have also been sometimes used in the literature, there are limited works on how these compare to the conventional configuration. Hence, the main contribution of this work is to analyse the flexibility in the electrode placement for EOG-based gaze estimation. Specifically, the gaze displacement estimation (GDE) performance obtained using different single-bipolar-channel and two-bipolar-channel configurations was analysed, and, in the case of the latter, the GDE performance was statistically compared to that obtained using the conventional configuration. In contrast to other comparative works reported in the literature, this work carries out an exhaustive analysis by systematically analysing all the different configurations that may be computed from a setup with 16 electrodes attached at equiangular positions around the eyes. Furthermore, the eye movements were carried out systematically in isotropic directions, and the EOG dataset used in this work is also being made publicly available. The results obtained demonstrate that the conventional horizontal and vertical bipolar EOG channels are not the only configuration that could be used for EOG-based GDE, but there are various other configurations with two bipolar channels that yield a performance that is statistically equivalent or even better than that of the conventional configuration.
Article Title: A systematic quantitative analysis on bipolar channel selection for EOG-based gaze displacement estimation

Abstract: Arrhythmia is a condition characterized by an irregular heart rhythm. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is a widely used technique employed for identifying arrhythmias, as it reveals the morphological changes in the ECG waveform associated with these irregularities. The aim of this work is to classify arrhythmias using a deep learning-based convolutional neural network (CNN) has been introduced that eliminates the need for manual feature extraction. The CNN architecture is carefully designed with a large kernel size to enhance its effectiveness in capturing relevant features. In addition, to this arrhythmia is further subdivided based on their physiological origin of rhythm disorder, premature contraction, and conduction disorder for better feature learning. In order to improve the model's generalization capability, a dataset classifier is proposed for three publicly available datasets: Chapman, CPSC 2018, and TNMG, each with different class distributions. This classifier is designed to account for variations in test sample distribution and dataset distributions, ensuring the model performs reliably across the datasets used in this study. The architecture is trained and tested on three publicly available datasets Chapman, CPSC 2018, and TNMG each with different class classifications. The CNN model extracts hierarchical features from the Lead II ECG signal. By utilizing publicly available datasets, the performance of the CNN model is evaluated and compared to existing state-of-the-art classification models. Experimental results demonstrate that the CNN model achieved an average F1-score of 98.00%, 96.25%, and 96.50% on the Chapman, CPSC 2018, and TNMG datasets, respectively. Additionally, the model achieved accuracies of 98.13%, 96.30%, and 96.88% on the Chapman, CPSC 2018, and TNMG datasets, respectively, outperforming other current models.
Article Title: A CNN-based classifier for detecting rhythm disorders, premature contractions, and conduction abnormalities from ECG

Abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is a significant health challenge arising from various anomalies within the gastrointestinal (GI) system. Despite recent advancements, existing polyp segmentation models struggle with limited generalizability, inadequate long-range contextual understanding, and poor utilization of unlabeled data-hindering their robustness in diverse clinical settings. This research introduces a new Spatio-Channel Attentive Residual Encoding-Decoding Network (SCAR-EDN) for automated colorectal polyp segmentation, addressing the critical need for accurate and efficient detection in CRC prevention. To overcome the inherent complexities of medical image variability and the scarcity of annotated data, a sophisticated pipeline-based augmentation strategy was developed, curating eleven non-conflicting transformations across three distinct pipelines, thereby enhancing data diversity while preserving crucial anatomical realism. The core innovation, SCAR-EDN architecture, integrates a self-attention mechanism within a residual encoder-decoder framework, enabling the model to capture long-range dependencies and essential contextual information for precise delineation of colorectal polyp boundaries. To mitigate the limitations of relying solely on labeled data, a semi-supervised learning approach was implemented, employing pseudo-labeling and a consistency loss to ensure prediction stability across augmentations and improve generalization. The efficacy of semi-supervised SCAR-EDN was validated through comprehensive self and cross-dataset experiments across five diverse colonoscopy image datasets. Demonstrating state-of-the-art performance on the augmented Kvasir-SEG dataset within a semi-supervised environment, SCAR-EDN achieved an accuracy of 0.9878, an Intersection over Union of 0.9526, and a Dice coefficient of 0.9620, all while maintaining a computationally efficient training time of 5,960 s. These findings underscore the significant advancements offered by SCAR-EDN in accurate and efficient colorectal polyp segmentation, marking a substantial step toward CRC screening and diagnosis.
Article Title: A spatio-channel attentive residual encoder-decoder network for semi-supervised colorectal polyp segmentation with pipeline-based data augmentation

Abstract: Early and accurate detection of human monkeypox is vital for timely intervention and outbreak control. Traditional diagnostic methods are slow, error-prone, and often struggle to distinguish monkeypox lesions from visually similar skin conditions. To address these challenges, it propose an Optimized Colony Weighted Hybrid Pooling Attentive ConvNet (OCWPC), a novel deep learning framework that integrates Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) for robust feature selection and a Weighted Hybrid Pooling Attention (WHPA) mechanism to enhance lesion-specific feature extraction. The approach leverages multiple preprocessing steps, brightness and contrast enhancement, median filtering, unsharp masking, and Otsu threshold segmentation, followed by Scale-Invariant Feature Transform (SIFT) and Gaussian augmentation to improve feature robustness and generalization. The model was trained and validated on publicly available Human Monkeypox datasets, achieving superior results with 99.49% accuracy, 99.49% precision, 99.49% recall, and 98.98% mAP. Comparative evaluation against state-of-the-art models confirms the effectiveness of OCWPC in minimizing misclassification and improving reliability. These findings highlight the model's potential for real-world clinical deployment and automated large-scale screening to strengthen monkeypox surveillance and management.
Article Title: Optimizing deep learning with attention techniques for improved detection of human monkeypox lesions

Abstract: In situ cartilage engineering aims to repair damaged cartilage within the body by using biomaterials such as hydrogels, often loaded with regenerative cells to support tissue formation at the injury site. Hydrogels are promising candidates for in situ cartilage repair due to their biocompatibility and tunable properties. Two major strategies have been explored to enhance their performance: mechanical reinforcement, through the incorporation of secondary structures to improve mechanical behavior and structural integrity; and growth factor delivery, to stimulate cell proliferation, differentiation, and extracellular matrix synthesis. This review first analyzes mechanical reinforcement and growth factor delivery separate, discussing their advantages, limitations, and gaps in the context of in situ applications. It then highlights the emerging opportunity to combine these strategies within composite, cell-laden hydrogels, and critically examines the current studies, alongside the additional challenges in clinical translation that arises. Finally, future directions are proposed to guide the design and testing of composite hydrogels for more effective and translatable in situ cartilage repair therapies.
Article Title: Mechanical reinforcement and growth factor delivery strategies for in situ cartilage repair

Abstract: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a severe neurodegenerative condition that predominantly affects the elderly. It can lead to memory decline, brain atrophy, and ultimately death.
