The mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is a transitional stage that may be progressive (pMCI), leading to AD, or stable (sMCI). Early AD diagnosis and MCI conversion are very crucial for timely treatment, slowing disease progression, and alleviating the financial burden on patients. Multimodal neuroimaging data offers complementary information and has been widely utilized to differentiate between AD and normal controls (NC), as well as to predict MCI conversion. Recent research has indicated that the inclusion of structural information could improve the performance of MCI conversion and AD diagnosis. Moreover, the pathological characteristics of AD have been demonstrated to be advantageous for its diagnosis. However, previous works only considered different ways to construct graphs to represent the structural information of samples and lacks efficient exploitation of structural information and AD pathological characteristics. In addition, the diagnostic accuracy of classifying MCI subtypes remains constrained. In this paper, we introduce a novel approach for feature selection, targeting the identification of robust neuroimaging features from magnetic resonance imaging and positron emission tomography data. Initially, we utilize the random forest method to calculate the similarity matrix for each modality. Subsequently, we integrate auxiliary data into the objective function and similarity information using the sparse regression method for feature selection. Then, we utilize the l2,1 norm regularization term to select the shared features from predictor data and auxiliary data. Lastly, we utilize a multi-kernel support vector machine to integrate multimodal data and perform classification tasks. Extensive experiments conducted on the ADNI dataset demonstrate that our method surpasses state-of-the-art approaches, achieving classification accuracies of 80.87%, 80.36%, and 81.78% for pMCI vs. sMCI, MCI vs. NC, and MCI vs. AD, respectively. Our source code is available at https://gith ub.com/Gone-boy/Improved-AD-diagnosis-using-multimodal-sparse-similarity-feature-selection-and-a uxiliary-data/tree/master.
Article Title: Improved Alzheimer's disease diagnosis using multimodal sparse similarity feature selection and auxiliary data

Abstract: Accurately interpreting cardiac auscultation signals is essential for diagnosing and managing cardiovascular diseases. However, the paucity of labelled data inhibits classification models' training. Researchers have turned to generative deep learning techniques alongside signal processing to augment existing data and improve cardiac auscultation classification models. However, the primary focus of prior studies has been on model performance rather than robustness. Robustness, in this case, is defined as both in-distribution and out-of-distribution performance by measures such as Matthew's correlation coefficient. One contribution of this work is to show that more robust abnormal heart sound classifiers can be trained using an augmented dataset. The augmented dataset includes both signal processing techniques and synthetic phonocardiograms conditionally generated using the WaveGrad and DiffWave diffusion models an approach that, to the best of our knowledge, is the first work of its kind. The efficacy of the proposed data augmentation approach is evaluated on an example convolutional neural network, trained on the original and augmented data. It is found that both the in-distribution and out-of-distribution performance can be improved over various datasets for neural networks trained with this augmented dataset. Results show significant performance improvements. Specifically, in-distribution accuracy, balanced accuracy, and Matthew's correlation coefficient (MCC) increased by 2.5%, 4.1%, and 0.066, respectively. The greatest out-of-distribution improvements were observed on one dataset, where accuracy, balanced accuracy, and MCC increased by 43.1%, 20.2%, and 0.297, respectively. These improvements across all metrics highlight that augmented datasets significantly address issues of imbalanced data, ultimately leading to more generalisable and robust classifiers.
Article Title: Generative deep learning and signal processing for data augmentation of cardiac auscultation signals: Improving model robustness using synthetic audio

Abstract: This paper focuses on the classification of lung sounds as can be instrumental in diagnosing respiratory diseases, that are one of the leading causes of death. We address two intrinsic challenges associated with the application of deep learning models to this task. The first one is the need of large databases annotated by expert medical staff. The second one is the presence of a strong class imbalance in the datasets primarily due to the predominance of non-pathological respiratory sounds. For overcoming these issues we propose a deep convolutional network model that is trained using the contrastive self-supervised learning paradigm. This technique is able to generate useful audio data representations from unlabeled data that can be effectively transferred to the target task employing a limited amount of annotated data. We have evaluated the developed systems on the well-known ICBHI dataset that contains respiratory cycles categorized into four different classes. Results show that our approach outperforms the conventional supervised learning model when the size of available labeled data is reduced. With 40% of annotated data, self-supervision achieves a relative improvement with respect to the baseline of 12.1%, 8.6%, 16% and 66.7% in score, accuracy, delta AUC and sensitivity respectively, while getting a reduction of 1.0% in specificity. Finally, to corroborate our findings, we have also assessed our system on the SPRSound database, confirming the same trends. We believe that the findings in this paper enlightens the path towards the use of unlabeled data in biomedicine alleviating the need of large annotated datasets.
Article Title: Leveraging unlabeled data for lung sound classification through self-supervised contrastive learning

Abstract: Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis (AIS) is a complex, three-dimensional spinal curvature deformity typically recognized by the Cobb angle and mostly affects adolescents or children. So, the curvature analysis is regarded as an effective tool for determining the severity of AIS. However, previous X-ray based Cobb angle calculations primarily focused on mild and moderate scoliosis cases, and it is undeniable that X-ray imaging is typically acquired for presurgical cases suffering from severe spine curves to avoid unnecessary ionizing radiation exposure. So, in this paper, an end-to-end system is developed for accurate spine curvature estimation from spine 3D X-ray images. Initially, the geometric data augmentation methods and Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) methods are used to increase the number of input images. Then, the vertebral region is segmented using a hybrid UDANet model, which is the combination of a hybrid U-net with a dilated convolutional layer and decoder attention module. The challenges of the learning process are addressed by utilizing the Inverse Polynomial Linear Unit (IpLU) activation function, which is augmented with adjustable parameters for controlling the gradient slope. From the segmental vertebral data, the vertebral compression ratio (VCR) is estimated for curvature evaluation. Finally, the Segmentation Coordinates based on the Cobb Angle Network (SCANet) is proposed for Cobb angle measurement to improve detection accuracy. From the analysis, it is verified that the proposed SCANet model obtains 98.65% accuracy in Cobb angle measurement, which is 2.06 % and 4.16 % higher than Deep Neural Network (DNN), as well as Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), respectively.
Article Title: SCANet: automated Cobb angle measurement using deep learning model in X-ray images for adolescent idiopathic scoliosis patients

Abstract: Background: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by altered neural connectivity and dynamic brain network organization. Although existing studies have employed EEG microstates or spectral characteristics to identify ASD, the millisecond-scale nonlinear transition patterns of microstate sequences and their spectral dynamics have been neglected. This has led to the inadequate sensitivity and interpretability of current biomarkers. Methods: This study sought to characterize the neurophysiological dynamics of ASD and evaluate the diagnostic value of a novel hybrid approach integrating EEG microstate analysis with Chaos Game Representation (CGR) and Frequency CGR (FCGR) as electrophysiological biomarkers. It applied two public EEG datasets (the University of Sheffield databases and the King Abdulaziz University) for performance comparison and better generalizability. Microstate features were extracted via the EEGLAB toolbox. Microstate sequences were then transformed into two dimension spatial patterns using CGR, from which spectral and time-frequency features were derived. Results: For ASD, there is a reduction in the stability and engagement of microstate C, as well as abnormal dynamic transitions among specific networks (the visual, attention, salience, and semantic networks). There are characteristics such as enhanced high-frequency neural oscillatory activities(Root Mean Square Frequency, RMSF), increased spectral dispersion(Centre Frequency, CF; Root Variance Frequency, RVF), and reduced overall power. Machine learning models based on CGR time-frequency features achieved 95% accuracy in classifying patients with ASD. Conclusion: These results demonstrate that the hybrid EEG microstate-CGR/FCGR approach reveals distinctive neurodynamic alterations in ASD and holds significant promise as a potential diagnostic biomarker.
Article Title: Diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder using EEG microstates and chaos game representation

Corrigendum to "Unified approach for accurate brain tumor Multi-Classification and segmentation through fusion of advanced methodologies". [Biomed. Signal Process. Contr. 100, Part A (2025) 106872. DoI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bspc.2024.106872]

Abstract: Detecting brain tumors and their boundaries is crucial for timely diagnosis and reducing patient mortality. Specialists determine these borders, but tumor swelling, tissue differences, and variability in shape and size across patients often result in irregular and indeterminate tumor borders. In recent years, the encoder-decoder framework, encompassing renowned architectures like U-Net, has demonstrated favorable outcomes in medical image segmentation tasks to overcome these obstacles. However, enhancing the quality of tumor segmentation and delineating precise tumor boundaries are immense challenges for effective diagnosis and treatment planning. To address these challenges, we propose a new model called SWATT U-Net that utilizes a Semi-Wavelet Attention (SWATT) module within the U-Net architecture. SWATT incorporates a semi-wavelet layer and its inverse, enabling multi-resolution analysis of input images by scaling the original image to focus on specific parts. The SWATT U-Net model is trained on the BraTS2020 dataset. The results demonstrate an improvement, with the Mean Intersection over Union (mean-IoU) increasing from 82.82% to 87.16%. Moreover, SWATT was applied to PSPNET, ResNet, SegNet, and DeepLabV3 models, resulting in significant mean-IoU enhancements ranging from 14.53% to 20.88% compared to those without SWATT. Additionally, the statistical analysis using t-tests confirms the superiority of the modified models incorporating the SWATT attention mechanism, leading to improved segmentation results. Finally, the SWATT U-Net model's results were compared with those of various new methods for brain tumor segmentation on the BraTS2020 dataset. It was found that the recommended model outperformed the competing models in the mean-IoU metric.
Article Title: SWATT: Semi-Wavelet Attention Module for Enhancing Brain Tumor Image Segmentation

Abstract: Although certain contributions have been made, existing kidney stone detection models generally train a specific model by permanently collecting and labeling all CT images from various views at once. When this model is retrained or fine-tuned to adapt to new view images, it may lead to catastrophic forgetting of the old view images. This paper proposes a position-aware and decision-guided domain incremental learning framework for multi-view kidney stone detection. The framework is a two-stage regularization-based framework. Regarding the initial learning stage, a position feature fusion module is proposed to capture and enhance spatial positional feature representation of kidney stones at the feature level, encouraging the model to treat these features as key determinants in the decision-making process. Regarding the incremental learning stage, a decision distillation loss is proposed to align the internal and external decision logic at the decision level, guiding the model to explore the decision logic that adapts to new view data based on the old view knowledge. Experiments conducted on a transverse dataset with 9401 images and a coronal dataset with 1799 images demonstrate that the proposed framework has achieved 12.96% incremental and forgetting rate, outperforming the well-performing LwF model by +5.49%. Furthermore, the proposed framework has achieved 95.74% accuracy on a multi-view dataset with 1362 transverse and coronal images, yielding promising results compared to existing updated methods. These results demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves performance comparable to multi-view models while mitigating the issue of catastrophic forgetting.
Article Title: Position-aware and decision-guided domain incremental learning framework for multi-view kidney stone detection

Abstract: Surgical automation represents a significant trend in the development of laparoscopic surgical robots, which is highly dependent on objects perception in surgical scenes, specifically, the accurate segmentation of surgical instruments and organs. However, in complex backgrounds, achieving accurate segmentation of multi-object, including multi-instrument and multi-organ, poses substantial challenges, particularly when it comes to small-scale objects. Moreover, coupled with blood pollution, smoke occlusion, high-light reflection and other interferences, achieving real-time accurate segmentation is more difficult. In this study, a lightweight multi-object segmentation network (LMS-Net) was proposed. Based on U-Net architecture, a multi-head channel attention perception (MCAP) module was designed to extract different channel features of complex backgrounds, multi-instrument, and multi-organ in multi-dimension for improving the segmentation accuracy of multi-object in complex backgrounds. In addition, to improve the segmentation performance of smallscale objects, a spatial channel multi-scale fusion (SCMF) module was constructed to simultaneously extract both spatial and channel features of segmented objects at multi-scale. Finally, evaluated on public datasets Endovis Robotic Scene Segmentation Challenge 2018 (EndoVis2018) and AutoLaparo, LMS-Net significantly outperformed the reported state-of-the-art method LSKANet in both accuracy and speed, achieving mean Dice (mDice) 0.91 (+5.8%) and mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) 0.86 (+4.9%) at 17 ms (77.3% faster) on EndoVis2018, and mDice 0.88 (+3.5%) and mIoU 0.85 (+3.7%) at 16 ms (81.8% faster) on AutoLaparo. This study provided an effective solution for multi-object recognition in laparoscopic surgical scenes, advancing the field towards more reliable and efficient surgical assistance systems.
Article Title: LMS-Net: Light-weight multi-object segmentation network for laparoscopic surgical scene segmentation

Abstract: Deep learning has been widely used in the field of medical image classification due to its strong learning capability, applicability and automatic feature extraction. However, it has not been reported that loss function can be derived from variational information bottleneck and Dirichlet distribution to improve model performance, while hyperparameters can be changed to balance computational complexity and performance. Therefore, we propose a deep learning model, which is called Dirichlet variational information bottleneck (DirVIB). DirVIB is based on the variational information bottleneck framework and introduces the Dirichlet distribution to derive a loss function for model training. First, chest X-ray images are fed into the encoder to generate parameters for constructing the Dirichlet distribution. Then, the Dirichlet distribution is sampled to obtain latent variable. Finally, the latent variable is fed into the decoder to output the prediction of the chest X-ray. The ablation experiments not only confirm that the proposed loss function can improve the model performance, but also verify that the complexity and performance of the model can be balanced by changing the internal parameters. The results of classification experiments on three chest X-ray datasets show that the complexity and performance of DirVIB are better than the related models compared in this paper, which suggests that DirVIB is more suitable for the classification of chest X-ray images, which provides a new strategy for medical image classification.
Article Title: Dirichlet variational information bottleneck: A flexible model for chest X-ray classification

Abstract: The accurate and early detection of brain tumor types, such as gliomas, meningiomas, and pituitary tumors, is crucial for effective treatment planning and improving patient outcomes. However, advanced Computer-Aided Diagnosis (CAD) systems often face significant limitations in resource-constrained healthcare settings due to their high computational demands. State-of-the-art deep learning models often require substantial computational power and storage due to their complex architectures, large number of parameters, and model size which limits their practical applicability in such environments. To address this, we present Deep-Fusion, a novel lightweight model that maintains high accuracy while significantly reducing computational overhead, making it ideal for resource-constrained environments. Our proposed model leverages the strengths of two lightweight pre-trained models, MobileNetV2 and EfficientNetB0, integrated through the Feature Fusion Module (FFM), which is further enhanced by the Lightweight Feature Extraction Module (LEM), Cross-Stream Attention (CSA), and an Attention Prediction Head (APH). These components work together to optimize feature representation while preserving computational efficiency. We evaluated Deep-Fusion on two brain MRI datasets, Figshare and Br35H, achieving outstanding accuracies of 99.19% and 99.83%, respectively. Additionally, the model demonstrated exceptional performance in precision, recall, and F1-score metrics, recording 99.19%, 99.11%, and 99.15% on the Figshare dataset, and 99.83% across all metrics on the Br35H dataset. These findings establish Deep-Fusion as a reliable and efficient tool for medical image analysis, particularly in environments with limited computational resources.
Article Title: Deep-Fusion: A lightweight feature fusion model with Cross-Stream Attention and Attention Prediction Head for brain tumor diagnosis

Abstract: Signal quality assessment is essential for biomedical signal processing, analysis, and interpretation. Various methods exist, including averaged numerical values, thresholding, time-or frequency-domain analysis, and nonlinear approaches. The aim of this study was to evaluate the quality of electrocardiographic (ECG) signals, seismocardiographic signals (SCG), and gyrocardiograms (GCG) based on symmetric projection attractor reconstruction (SPAR) with Takens delay coordinates with fit five classifiers: random forest, gradient boosting, random forest XGB, and support vector machines (SVM) with various number of decision tree-based estimators (100-10,000) and various kernels (linear, radial base function, and polynomial), respectively. The analysis was carried out on a public dataset "Mechanocardiograms with ECG reference" containing 29 concurrent ECG, SCG, and GCG signal recordings. The highest values without SMOTE were observed for ECG signals, SVM with fourth order polynomial kernel (accuracy of 0.6897, PPV of 0.6019, sensitivity of 0.5306, and F1 score of 0.4952), and after applying SMOTE were observed for Gradient Boosting in ECG signal (200 estimators, accuracy 0.7500, PPV of 0.7747, sensitivity of 0.7500, and F2 score of 0.7747 respectively). These findings suggest that the SPAR-based approach is a promising method to accurately assess the quality of cardiovascular signals, including seismocardiograms and gyrocardiograms.
Article Title: Assessment of quality of electrocardiograms, seismocardiograms, and gyrocardiograms based on features derived from symmetric projection attractor reconstruction in healthy subjects

Abstract: Nuclei instance segmentation is one of the most challenging tasks and is considered the first step in automated pathology. The challenges stem from technical biological variations, and high cellular density that lead adjacent nuclei to form perceptual boundaries. This paper demonstrates that a multi-aperture representation encoded by the fusion of Swin Transformers and Convolutional blocks improves nuclei segmentation. The loss function is augmented with the curvature and centroid consistency terms between the growth truth and the prediction to preserve morphometric fidelity and localization. These terms are used to panelize for the loss of shape localization (e.g., a mid-level attribute) and mismatches in low and high-frequency boundary events (e.g., a low-level attribute). The proposed model is evaluated on three publicly available datasets: PanNuke, MoNuSeg, and CPM17, reporting improved Dice and binary Panoptic Quality (PQ) scores. For example, the PQ scores for PanNuke, MoNuSeg, and CPM17 are 0.6888 +/- 0.032, 0.634 +/- 0.003, and 0.716 +/- 0.002, respectively. The code is located at https://github.com/Siyavashshabani/MACA-Net.
Article Title: MACA-Net: Multi-aperture curvature aware network for instance-nuclei segmentation

Abstract: Deformable image registration (DIR) is a technique that finds all matching spatial correspondences as a dense vector field (DVF). DIR is gaining popularity in follow-up studies and radiotherapy planning, which are based on matching labeled images to targets. Although many studies have been proposed to solve the DVF regression problem, most of them utilize intensity-based metrics due to the difficulty of obtaining ground truth vectors. In addition, the problem of large deformation hinders accurate registration results, especially in abdominal CT images. In this paper, we propose a novel registration network designed to address large deformations through coarse-to-fine DVF regression combined with efficient self-and cross-attention. We also propose an effective 2D multiview adversarial learning technique that provides fine-grained supervision and mitigates noise and unrealistic results common in intensity-based metrics and transformer architectures. To validate our approach, we performed registration experiments on abdominal CT, brain MRI, and head & neck CT. In the abdominal CT in particular, our registration network outperformed the previous DIR method by 11.7% in terms of Dice Score Coefficient. We also demonstrated the effectiveness of the proposed adversarial learning technique with quantitative and qualitative measures.
Article Title: Deformable medical image registration via multiview adversarial learning

Abstract: Diabetic Macular Edema (DME) is a prevalent difficulty associated with diabetes, which, if left undetected and untreated in its early stages, can result in visual impairment and eventual blindness.Conventional DME detection techniques are inconsistent among individuals. Deep Learning (DL) replicas have exposedpossible in medical imaging tasks; however, they can have difficulty predicting DMEs due to data shortages, processing resources, and comprehension issues. An attention-based weighted Gated Recurrent Units (AB-WGRU) model is proposed for predicting DME using OCT (Optical Coherence Tomography) imaging data. The AB-WGRU model combines weighted Gated Recurrent Units (GRU) with attention mechanisms to capture local and global contextual information from OCT images. Due to data redundancy and noise, the obtained OCT images require pre-processing using filtered data. This indicates that the filtering process employs the 2D Fourier transform (2DFT). Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is used to extract pertinenttopographies from the improved data, and Modified Genetic Algorithms (MGA) are employed to produce the best combination of features. The proposed technique demonstrates performance across several evaluation metrics. Specifically, it obtains an accuracy of 0.98, precision of 0.98, recall of 0.98, and F-measure of 0.98. The AB-WGRU model outperforms existing methods. This research improves eye disease identification and may aid healthcare providers in early intervention and patient care.Although validation and incorporation into medical care are required, this research establishes the basis for the creation of a helpful diagnostic tool that has the potential to assist in early intervention and reduce the risk of vision impairment in individuals with diabetes.
Article Title: A novel deep learning-based prediction of DME in eye diseases

Abstract: Ovarian cancer (OC) presents significant diagnostic challenges due to its asymptomatic progression and limited early detection capabilities, resulting in high mortality rates. To address the scarcity of annotated data and the complexity of cancerous tissues, this study proposes a novel unsupervised framework for segmenting these kind of regions in histopathological images. The framework utilizes a modified EfficientNetB1 architecture augmented with custom top layers and a soft-attention mechanism, optimized through stratified nested cross-validation to ensure generalizability. The model achieves outstanding performance, with a training accuracy of 99.87% (+/- 0.15), testing accuracy of 99.49% (+/- 0.21), training loss of 0.45%, testing loss of 1.79%, and a ROC-AUC of 99.948%. To improve interpretability, we integrate the Score Weighted Class Activation Mapping (ScoreCAM) algorithm with a novel class activation map aggregation strategy, followed by bicubic interpolation and Otsu thresholding for precise segmentation. Ablation studies highlight the roles of the soft-attention mechanism and the proposed aggregation method in enhancing segmentation quality. Expert's validation confirms a high concordance between the predicted and actual region of interest. The proposed framework not only offers high diagnostic accuracy and robustness but also provides visual interpretability. This makes it particularly valuable for deployment in resource-constrained clinical environments. This work marks a significant advancement in automated histopathological image analysis by effectively integrating deep learning (DL), unsupervised learning, and explainable AI.
Article Title: Unsupervised attention-based framework for cancerous region segmentation with explainable post-hoc thresholding in histopathological images

Abstract: In clinical diagnosis and treatment, accurate identification of brain tumor types is crucial for the timely formulation of patient treatment plans. However, traditional manual diagnosis based on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is not only time-consuming but also likely to miss early subtle lesions. Therefore, developing an efficient, accurate classifier suitable for multi-type brain tumor classification is of great significance. To address this issue, we propose a novel model named RFENet, which adopts a three-branch parallel architecture to extract complementary features: Branch 1 captures tumor edge and texture features based on the Stage 1 residual blocks of ResNet50; Branch 2 achieves lightweight fine-grained feature extraction using the Stage 2 Fused-MBConv blocks of EfficientNetV2-B0; Branch 3 takes EfficientNetB0 as the backbone and extracts high-dimensional semantic features through MBConv blocks. Meanwhile, the SwishReLU activation function is introduced and applied to the fully connected layers. To tackle the problems of insufficient sample size and class imbalance, differentiated data augmentation is implemented on the training set (the "No Tumor" class is expanded 11-fold, and the other tumor classes are expanded 6-fold), and Test-Time Augmentation (TTA) is adopted on the test set to improve the robustness of predictions. The results show that the RFENet model achieves excellent classification performance, with a Macro-Average Accuracy of 98.32%, Macro-Average Precision of 96.90%, Macro-Average Recall of 96.92%, Macro-Average F1score of 99.91%, and Macro-Average AUC of 99.67%.
Article Title: MRI brain tumor classification using RFENet Three-Branch model with SwishReLU

Abstract: A wide range of ocular diseases poses significant risks to visual health, with retinal vessel changes often indicating various eye disorders. Fundus imaging, which captures the retinal vessel structure, plays a crucial role in diagnosis. Automated retinal vessel segmentation has become a prevalent approach in computer-aided diagnosis, but manual annotation is time-consuming and costly, hindering the creation of large labeled datasets. To address this, we propose CrossVesselNet, a one-shot vessel segmentation model based on few-shot learning, using just one sample as the support set. CrossVesselNet can achieve accurate segmentation and strong cross-domain generalization even with limited training data. The proposed model adopts an encoder-decoder architecture. In the encoder, we introduce a novel QS Cross-Window Block designed for few-shot learning. This block incorporates window attention in small-sample scenarios and integrates it with convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to further enhance the overall framework. In addition, we propose the QS Calibrated Score, a metric that effectively leverages support set samples by computing the similarity between the support set and the query set, thereby achieving efficient fusion of the two sets. In the decoder, support set information is fully exploited through concatenation, and traditional deconvolution is replaced by Pixel Shuffle technology, which significantly improves image quality during the reconstruction phase. Trained on the DRIVE dataset, our model can consistently produce accurate segmentation results on other datasets, such as CHASE-DB1, STARE, HRF, even with few labeled samples, demonstrating strong cross-domain adaptability.
Article Title: CrossVesselNet: A one-shot retinal vessel segmentation Net

Abstract: A convolutional concatenated network (AT-CPN) based on affine transformation is proposed to address the unavoidable problem of manually recognizing Hep-2 cells. Firstly, due to the small amount of HEP-2ANA sample data in the existing dataset, high-quality data enhancement is performed by deep convolutional generative adversarial network to enable the model to learn more robust features. Then the dataset is placed on the ConvNext-RegNet concurrent network model that introduces affine transformation units for learning and training, and finally, the features obtained from the two types of network branches are spliced and fused to obtain the classification results. The experimental results show that compared with other deep learning models, this network effectively improves the efficiency of clinical medical diagnosis with fewer parameters, and has the advantages of high classification accuracy and model robustness, which can be applied to the task of Hep-2 cell classification.
Article Title: Cell classification based on affine transformed convolutional parallel networks

Abstract: Background: Four-dimensional cone-beam computed tomography (4D CBCT) plays an important role in moving target localization and therapeutic dose accumulation in radiotherapy. However, 4D CBCT images suffer from severe artifacts due to the extremely sparse projection data. This study aims to develop a novel spatiotemporal structure-aware neural network capable of generating high quality 4D CBCT images. Methods: We proposed a Spatial and Temporal Adaptation based Model (STAM), which fine-tunes the image encoder of a pre-trained SAM model by incorporating Adapter modules in both spatial and temporal branches. To construct a paired dataset for training and testing, we utilized 4D CT images from 25 patients to simulate degraded 4D CBCT images. In addition, real 4D CBCT images from 5 clinical patients were tested. The tumor contours of clinical patients on STAM predicted images were delineated by a physician to evaluate tumor localization accuracy. Results: The proposed STAM outperformed other methods on all indexes, achieving an mean absolute error (MAE) of 22.85 HU, root mean square error (RMSE) of 36.28 HU and structural similarity (SSIM) of 0.9673 for simulated patient data. For clinical 4D CBCT evaluation, the tumor areas delineated on STAM predicted images were similar to the reference image, with Dice coefficient exceeding 0.9 at all selected phases, significantly higher than those of the average phase images (P < 0.05). Conclusions: The proposed STAM method delivers superior results in artifacts reduction and details preservation compared with other state-of-the-art methods, and may offer a practical solution to enhance the image quality of clinical 4D CBCT.
Article Title: A spatiotemporal structure-aware neural network for 4D CBCT images enhancement

Abstract: Objective This study aimed to assess the effectiveness of tortuosity and discrete compactness metrics in analyzing the amygdala's morphology to differentiate healthy control individuals from patients diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment using magnetic resonance imaging. Methods The analysis included a total of 74 participants, comprising 37 healthy control subjects and 37 mild cognitive impairment patients. Imaging data were sourced from the ADNI database. The amygdala regions (both hemispheres) were segmented, and measurements for volume, normalized volume, discrete compactness, and tortuosity were computed. Statistical tests and automatic classifier training of Support Vector Machines, K-nearest Neighbors, Randon Forest and Artificial Neural Network were conducted to identify significant group differences. The machine learning algorithms were trained with the proposed metrics with a partition of 60-40 subjects for training and testing. The training consisted of hyperparameter optimization with a 5-fold cross validation. Results The statistical analysis revealed significant differences (p < 0.01) across all evaluated metrics, with the most pronounced alterations observed in discrete compactness and tortuosity within the right hemisphere. The application of the previously described algorithms demonstrated that the proposed biomarkers-tortuosity and discrete compactness-offered greater discriminative power compared to traditional volume-based measures. When incorporated into the classification models, these features enhanced performance, yielding a test accuracy of 82.14 %, area under the curve values between 88.27 % and 91.33 %, and F-scores ranging from 81.48 % to 83.87 %. These findings underscore the potential of tortuosity and discrete compactness as sensitive and robust imaging biomarkers for the early detection of mild cognitive impairment. Conclusions These findings demonstrate that tortuosity and discrete compactness are more sensitive than conventional volume-based metrics in capturing morphological alterations of the amygdala in mild cognitive impairment. When integrated into machine learning models-Support Vector Machines, K-nearest Neighbors, Random Forest, and Artificial Neural Networks-these features enhanced classification performance, achieving a test accuracy of 82.14 %, area under the curve values between 88.27 % and 91.33 %, and F-scores ranging from 81.48 % to 83.87 %. Significance The results suggest that tortuosity and discrete compactness may serve as robust and informative imaging biomarkers for the early detection of mild cognitive impairment. Their ability to outperform traditional morphological metrics in both statistical discrimination and machine learning classification highlights their potential for clinical application in computer-aided diagnosis systems.
Article Title: Tortuosity and discrete compactness biomarkers for machine learning-based classification of mild cognitive impairment

Abstract: Since the analysis of erythrocytes and spirochaetes is highly relevant to human health, their automated detection is of significant importance in both medical and computer vision research. However, publicly available datasets in this domain remain scarce. To address this gap, we present the Darkfield Microscopy Image Dataset for Erythrocytes and Spirochaete Detection (DMID-ESD), which consists of 11,794 fully annotated images with labels containing categorical and localization information. We perform comprehensive benchmarking experiments on DMID-ESD to evaluate its utility in tasks such as image classification, object detection, and feature extraction. The results demonstrate that the dataset serves as an effective benchmark for method evaluation. The DMID-ESD dataset is freely available for non-commercial use at: https://figshare. com/articles/dataset/DMID-ESD_zip/22179311.
Article Title: DMID-ESD: A Benchmark Darkfield Microscopy Image Dataset for Erythrocytes and Spirochaete Detection and Classification

Abstract: Diabetes has become a severe and widespread chronic disease, making its early prediction crucial for effective intervention and management. With its rising global incidence, the development of robust and efficient predictive models is essential for timely diagnosis and accurate prediction. Despite the availability of numerous predictive models, existing methods often struggle with class imbalance, suboptimal and biased classification performance, and limited interpretability. To overcome these issues, this study proposes a trustworthy and patient privacy-aware framework for early and precise diabetes prediction. Firstly, the class imbalance issue in the dataset is mitigated by the proximity-weighted synthetic oversampling technique, which minimizes biased classification. Later, a novel deep learning model named Deep Residual Network (DRNet) is proposed to improve predictive performance by identifying complex patterns in the data. Experimental results demonstrate that DRNet outperforms baseline models, achieving improvements of 4.54% in accuracy, 3.48% in precision, 7.69% in Cohen's Kappa, 6.33% in Matthew's correlation coefficient, 2.28% in area under the receiver operating characteristic curve, 2.28% in precision-recall area under the curve, and 1.06% in recall. DRNet also exhibits a significant reduction in log loss with 30.43% and Hamming loss with 30%. The reliability of DRNet is confirmed using 10-fold cross validation and the Friedman test to assure consistency and robustness. Finally, explainable artificial intelligence techniques, such as local interpretable model-agnostic explanations and Shapley additive explanations, offer insights into the most contributing features both locally and globally, which leads to better interpretability and explainability. This framework aligns with the rising need for responsible AI solutions in healthcare, where transparency, trust, and data privacy have become necessary for patient-focused innovation.
Article Title: A trustworthy and patient privacy-conscious framework for early diabetes prediction using Deep Residual Networks and proximity-based data

Abstract: Lung cancer is a potent condition that impacts the mortality rate. The conventional assessment of lung cancer includes microscopic biopsies. The process comprises a labor-intensive visual assessment that is subjective and necessitates the expertise of a professional pathologist. However, noise typically affects the readable features in the low-resolution digital biopsy images. Moreover, the incidence of noise affects both inter- and intra-observer interpretations by pathologists. To overcome these issues, a novel enhanced RetinaNet (ERNet) has been proposed to detect and classify the lung abnormalities in a single framework. The proposed ERNet integrates a convolutional block attention module for the refined feature extraction. Additionally, the proposed ERNet employs a generalized intersection over union bounding box loss function to precisely localize abnormalities. The proposed method utilizes LC25000 lung histopathological images for its development. To improve, and denoise the lung biopsies image datasets, ant colony fourth-order partial differential equation has been applied. The comparative qualitative, and quantitative study has been presented with respect to existing methodologies such as faster regional convolutional neural network, single shot detector, RetinaNet and detection transformer. The quantitative assessments are evaluated in terms of accuracy, true positive rate, true negative rate, precision, Fscore, Jaccard index, and Dice coefficient. The following values are obtained: 98.73%, 98.04%, 98.45%, 0.98, 0.98, 0.99, 0.98, 0.98, and 0.99, respectively. The results of qualitative, quantitative with ablation analysis exhibit that the proposed method surpasses the outcomes of the other pre-existing methods.
Article Title: ERNet: A deep framework for detection and classification of lung cancer from histopathological images

Abstract: This study is directed at the essential task of patient treatment classification, which is essential for personalized and optimal healthcare. The overall aim is to optimize the accuracy of classification models in order to allocate treatments correctly and avoid the risk of misdiagnosis or ineffective treatments. In pursuit of this aim, the research compares different machine-learning models with the aim of improving the present classification models. The approach involves the assessment of widely used models like Gradient Boosting, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and support vector machines (SVM) using an electronic health record (EHR) corpus. By extensive training, cross-validation, and testing, the research compares the performances of each model in patient treatment classification. The results present notable disparities in the performances of the models, with the emphasis being the necessity of the selection of the optimal model for the process. The applied value of the research is significant. By ascertaining the optimal machine learning model for patient treatment classification, the results can be used directly to optimize the accuracy and trustworthiness of healthcare models, ultimately contributing to improved patient results. This research is unique in the extensive assessment of multiple machine-learning models specifically for patient treatment classification. It establishes the optimal model with the foundation for the creation of more trusty and resilient classification models in healthcare.
Article Title: Enhancing patient treatment classification in healthcare: A comparative analysis of machine learning techniques on electronic health record data

Abstract: The identification of hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia is paramount in diabetes care, facilitating prompt interventions to mitigate potential health complications. A novel method is introduced for identifying glycemic states using deep learning from facial images generated by artificial intelligence (AI). Specifically, the EfficientB0 model-a pre-trained convolutional neural network (CNN)-is employed, utilizing the transfer learning technique to leverage its learned features for glycemic state classification. The proposed method offers a non-invasive and remote monitoring solution, allowing for convenient glycemic status assessment without the need for invasive procedures or continuous glucose monitoring devices. The experimental results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed method. The achieved accuracy rates, recall rates, and F1-scores validate the model's ability to accurately identify individuals at risk of glycemic abnormalities. The integration of deep learning techniques with facial image analysis holds promise for personalized healthcare solutions tailored to individuals with diabetes, facilitating early detection and intervention for improved glycemic control. By leveraging AI-driven facial image analysis, individuals with diabetes can benefit from early detection and prediction of hyperglycemic and hypoglycemic events, enabling timely interventions and adjustments in treatment regimens. This approach holds promise for improving glycemic control, reducing the risk of acute complications, and enhancing overall quality of life for individuals with diabetes. The non-invasive approach for detecting glycemic states presented in this paper has the potential to revolutionize healthcare management for individuals with diabetes.
Article Title: Detection of hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia using deep learning from facial images obtained with an AI image generator

Abstract: Atomic Force Microscopy is widely used for surface imaging at the nanoscale. However, we need slower scanning speeds to obtain high-quality images, which often introduce noise and sample drift, causing distortion. In addition, the large-scale scanning of high-resolution images by AFM consumes a lot of sample resources and time. Although the traditional bicubic method can achieve the generation of high-resolution images, it cannot restore the details of the image well, and even the obtained image is basically different from the original high-resolution image. Here, in this paper, we propose a fast imaging method that combines the scanning data acquisition and the image super-resolution algorithm of the deep learning model, which can quickly generate high-quality images with little noise interference and small drift. High-resolution scans of viral samples in a clean-room environment were combined with higher-order degradation modeling to generate low-and high-resolution paired images. To address the time and cost limitations of HR scanning, we optimize the Real-Enhanced Super-Resolution Generative Network by incorporating a lightweight Dynamic Local and Global Self-Attention Network. In addition, we replace L1 Loss with Smooth L1 Loss to accelerate the convergence and improve the performance. Validation using novel coronavirus and influenza virus samples shows that our approach reduces imaging time by approximately 20-fold while maintaining high-resolution quality. The resulting super-resolution images preserve fine viral morphology with improved clarity and accuracy. It provides help for the classification and image detection of various viruses in the later research.
Article Title: Accelerating biological imaging of atomic force microscopy by deep-learning

Abstract: To improve the accuracy of bone age estimation from left-hand radiographs, this manuscript proposed a twostage bone age assessment framework based on cross-modal learning. In the first stage, the bone age range (1-228 months) was categorized into interval segments according to the GP Radiographic Atlas, resulting in 25 categories for males and 21 for females. A GP-CLIP network was designed for coarse-grained bone age classification, which leveraged collaborative learning between hand radiographs and structured textual descriptions from the GP Atlas, including bone age characteristics of carpal, metacarpal, phalangeal, and radius/ulna bones. This approach achieved 88.00 % classification accuracy for both genders on the RSNA pediatric bone age dataset and 86.67 % for males and 91.53 % for females on the RHPE dataset. In the fine-grained prediction stage, the system dynamically selected specifically optimized ResNet18 sub-models (each trained for a particular bone age interval) based on the coarse classification results, enabling more precise age estimation. Experimental results demonstrated that our method achieved a mean absolute error (MAE) of 2.03 months for males and 2.38 months for females on the RSNA dataset, and 1.87 months for males and 1.42 months for females on the RHPE dataset.
Article Title: GP-CLIP: A two-stage bone age assessment method based on cross-modal learning

Abstract: Objective: Enhancing the decoding accuracy and information transfer rate (ITR) of steady-state visual evoked potential (SSVEP)-based brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) while addressing inter-subject variability remains a significant challenge for practical applications. Despite recent advances in deep learning, current BCI systems are constrained by their reliance on hand-crafted features and complex preprocessing pipelines, limiting their widespread deployment. This paper presents BrainWaveDecoder, an end-to-end deep learning architecture that processes raw EEG signals directly for SSVEP frequency recognition. Methods: BrainWaveDecoder implements a unified end-to-end architecture that combines convolutional neural networks with bidirectional gated recurrent units (Bi-GRU) for direct spatiotemporal processing of raw EEG signals. This approach enables integrated feature extraction and classification optimization, bypassing traditional multi-stage preprocessing and manual feature engineering. Results: BrainWaveDecoder achieved 95.2% mean accuracy (ITR: 192.04 bits/minute) on a 40-class dataset, surpassing even models augmented with transfer learning techniques. The model also demonstrated 99.2% mean accuracy on a 12-class dataset with 1-s signals. Systematic evaluation across signal lengths (0.2 s-1.0 s) showed robust performance with graceful degradation at shorter durations. These achievements demonstrate BrainWaveDecoder's effectiveness in direct raw EEG processing, advancing the development of more accessible and reliable SSVEP-based BCI systems.
Article Title: BrainWaveDecoder: From raw EEG to SSVEP-BCI target selection via end-to-end deep learning

Abstract: Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI)-related post-operative complications remain significant clinical challenges, and current in-silico simulations fall short in predicting them accurately, limiting their clinical applicability. This scoping review evaluates the state of the art in TAVI computational modeling, identifying methodological gaps and proposing directions for refinement to enhance translational impact. Following PRISMA-ScR guidelines, 40 studies were included, with data extracted and summarized by evaluated outcomes. A quality assessment was performed using a 14-item rubric. Most studies focused on predicting paravalvular leak (65%) and conduction disturbances (20%). This review reveals substantial heterogeneity in modeling approaches, with limited standardization and varying degrees of validation. To improve clinical relevance, future efforts should prioritize model standardization, rigorous validation following ASME V&V guidelines, increased automation, and improved interpretability for clinical users. By ensuring robustness, efficiency, and clinical accessibility, in-silico models could transform TAVI outcome prediction and support personalized treatment planning, ultimately enhancing care standards in structural heart interventions.
Article Title: Predicting procedural outcomes in transcatheter aortic valve implantation: a scoping review of numerical patient-specific simulations

Abstract: We present a feasibility study of continuous blood pressure (BP) estimation using deep learning models applied to forehead-based near-infrared spectroscopy-photoplethysmography (NIRS-PPG) data collected via the FlexNIRS device. Data were recorded during carotid endarterectomy (CEA) surgery, where significant BP variations provided a robust training set. Using a combination of long short-term memory (LSTM) and convolutional neural network (CNN) layers-with brief training periods (15-30 % of each individual's data)-our model achieved a mean absolute error (MAE) of 4.0 + 3.8 mmHg, with a Pearson correlation coefficient of 0.91 and a limit-ofagreement of +10.5 mmHg. These findings demonstrate the feasibility of subject-specific BP monitoring using forehead NIRS-PPG, with potential applications in post-surgical and home care settings where continuous, noninvasive BP measurement may be beneficial.
Article Title: Continuous, noninvasive blood pressure estimation using forehead NIRS-PPG and LSTM-CNN deep learning

Abstract: The electrocardiogram (ECG) artificial intelligence faces challenges in collecting ECG data, imbalanced training data, and data privacy issues. Deep generative models can generate high-quality synthetic ECGs to alleviate these challenges, but current models often require extensive conditional information, which limits their effectiveness. This study introduces RDiffGAN-ECG, a personalized R-peaks conditional denoising diffusion GAN that integrates structured state space sequence model (S4) and selective state space model (Mamba) within its generator. The generator of RDiffGAN-ECG uses S4 to capture the temporal dynamics across diffusion time steps and R-peaks information for ECG reconstruction. Mamba integrates diagnostic annotations with S4 features, enhancing the generation of high-quality 12-lead ECGs with accurate R-peak position and diagnostic relevance. This model is trained to generate 12-lead ECGs for five classes diagnoses with specific R-peaks information. RDiffGAN-ECG was compared with several existing generative models through qualitative and quantitative analysis, and heart rate analysis. On the PTB-XL test set, it achieved better quantitative results (RMSE = 0.2245, FD = 5.6795, DTW = 68.1109) than existing models. On the CPSC2018 dataset, it demonstrated superior generative performance for different R-peaks, showing its generalization capability, with the results of RMSE = 0.2293, FD = 4.3552, and DTW = 52.2489. Ablation studies confirm the importance of the GAN framework and the combined use of S4 and Mamba in enhancing ECG generation quality. In summary, the RDiffGAN-ECG exhibits significant advantages in improving the quality of the generated ECG, and achieving specific R-peaks ECG generation. It provides substantial value for ECG-related research and clinical applications.
Article Title: RDiffGAN-ECG: High-quality specific R-peaks conditional ECG generation using denoising diffusion generative adversarial network with state space models

Abstract: Digital technology has advanced along the way, and this has had an important impact on how well we can find oral disorders, which frequently correspond to poor cleanliness and changes in hormones. It's very important to have an early diagnosis because untreated illnesses that could be cancerous can lead to mouth cancer. The lack of personal monitoring tools makes it even more clear that we need smart diagnostic systems. We came up with the Meta-SAM model (MetaAcon Separable Attention Model), a new deep learning architecture that is meant to help in classifying the MOD (Mouth and Oral Diseases) dataset. This proposed model adds some architectural improvements that are primarily meant to fix the main problems with classic Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), especially when it comes to classifying medical images in excessive detail, including finding mouth and oral diseases (MOD). Also, standard CNNs can be very difficult to compute, which makes them hard to scale and use in real time. To solve these limitations, the model used depth-wise separable convolutional layers. This reduced the number of parameters and the cost of computation by breaking standard CNNs down into depth and point operations. Also, a custom MetaAcon activation function is utilized because standard MetaAcon still has some problems, such as limiting how flexible it can become in terms of representation. Custom MetaAcon is a learnable activation function that adaptively highlights important features while ignoring unimportant ones. It solves problems like bad feature selectivity and noise in medical images. With a blending value of 0.9, the improved MetaAcon combines adaptability with smooth gradient learning, making learning more stable and efficient. Thus, it speeds up convergence, stops gradients from vanishing, and makes deep feature representation stronger, which is very important for accurate MOD classification. Also, standard CNNs sometimes have problems with vanishing gradients and losing features in deeper layers. Residual connections assist solves these problems by making gradient flow more stable and speeding up convergence. Standard CNNs also treat all features the same, which can mean that important diagnostic clues are missed. To fix this, the model uses squeeze-and-excitation (SE) blocks to show how important each channel is. It also uses self-attention with many heads to find long-range and spatial relationships, which helps make up for CNNs' restricted ability to take in information. The suggested model gets 99.7% of the classifications right, which is better than the usual CNN (96.2%).and demonstrates its effectiveness in diagnosing complex oral diseases. These results highlight the potential of the proposed architecture as an effective and scalable solution for automated diagnosis in medical imaging, especially for diseases of the mouth and oral cavity. The Link to work is https://github.com/Aminaalr /Meta-SAM-A-Novel-Deep-Learning-Architecture-for-Oral-Disease-Classification.
Article Title: Meta-SAM: a novel deep learning architecture for oral disease classification

Abstract: Hand gesture recognition is an important part of the automation of sign languages. Capturing long-range dependencies (LRDs) in image recognition tasks is ill-suited in existing models to recognize the visually similar hand gesture images with high recognition accuracy. This paper proposes SignViT, a model best-suited for capturing LRDs, which has a strong backbone based on the vision transformer (ViT) to address the issue of visual similarity. Processing the images' features through the attention mechanism of the transformer's encoder block and a novel enhanced feedforward neural network classification head in our framework makes it highly accurate for recognizing all hand gestures, including visually similar gestures. To evaluate the model's performance, we assessed it on four hand gesture datasets representing three distinct sign languages, including Urdu, American, and Arabic. In our evaluation, we find that SignViT achieves state-of-the-art results on both similar-looking gestures and overall datasets compared to baseline ViT, convolutional neural network approaches, and other models. The overall accuracies achieved by SignViT on four datasets are 99.70%, 99.44%, 99.90%, and 99.52%.
Article Title: SignViT: An enhanced vision transformer framework for Attention-Based sign language hand gesture recognition

Abstract: Faced with the current limitations in cardiac tissue regeneration and transplants, this study proposes an approach by applying artificial intelligence to redefine paradigms in regenerative medicine. Utilizing pre-trained convolutional neural networks, ResNet50 and ResNet101, the present research unveils the untapped potential of decellularizing rat hearts, illustrating a superior method for assessing the structure of the extracellular matrix (ECM). The results demonstrate remarkable diagnostic accuracy, substantially surpassing the limitations of conventional histological evaluations and establishing a new standard in the analysis of decellularized tissues. By exploring the performance and efficiency of ResNet50 and ResNet101 in detail, our work not only validates the applicability of these AI (Artificial Intelligence) models in the complex context of decellularization but also provides an innovative vision for improving tissue regeneration processes. Advancing the frontiers of knowledge, the research makes a significant contribution to the field of tissue engineering, offering promising strategies for overcoming barriers in organ transplants and personalized regenerative therapies. This work not only marks significant progress in integrating AI technologies into regenerative medicine but also lays a solid foundation for future research, anticipating a new era in the intelligent application of science for human health.
Article Title: Translating biomedical images into clinical insights: Evaluating the impact of pre-trained neural networks in rat heart decellularization

Abstract: Mental workload (MWL) represents the cognitive resources used during task engagement. MWL varies as per task complexity and individual capacity to complete a task. Assessment of mental workload is crucial due to its direct impact on human performance, safety, and overall well-being in various contexts like healthcare, aviation, multitasking in everyday life, etc. Main challenge in EEG-based MWL classification is the lack of standardized validation methods, leading to unreliable performance comparisons. To address this, we rigorously assess five distinct validation schemes-such as random cross-validation (RCV), K-fold cross-validation (KCV), leave-one-subject-out (LOSO), subject-wise classification (SWC), and cross-session validation (CSV)-using a 1D-CNN model and a cross-session mental workload dataset. The results revealed a notable performance gap of approximately 20 % between SWC (37.50 %) and CSV (35.58 %) compared to RCV (57.34 %), KCV (55.47 %), and LOSO (58.59 %), highlighting the impact of limited training data in the SWC and CSV schemes, where only single subjects' data is used. Transfer learning was employed to further evaluate the cross-dataset transferability, the trained 1D-CNN model was frozen, two new dense layers were appended, and the model was trained on another COG-BCI dataset. This transfer learning approach significantly improved performance, achieving an accuracy of 99.94 %. Furthermore, Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP) analysis was performed to interpret the model and identify the most important channels contributing to the model's performance. The novelty of this work lies in proposed deep learning framework that not only achieves high classification performance but also offers interpretability through the SHAP analysis and generalizability across datasets by transfer learning.
Article Title: Investigation of various validation and testing schemes for classification of cross-session mental workload to match real-life expectations of BCI: A transfer learning and XAI approach

Abstract: Background: Accurate and efficient brain tumor diagnosis is a persistent challenge in medical imaging due to the complexity and variability of tumor structures. Deep learning has demonstrated strong potential; however, balancing diagnostic performance with computational efficiency remains a significant barrier to real-world deployment, particularly in resource-limited clinical settings. Proposed Method: This study introduces a novel hybrid framework combining a pruning-enhanced Effi-cientNetV2B3 model with metaheuristic-based feature selection and traditional machine learning classifiers. Multiple state-of-the-art CNN architectures were initially evaluated, and EfficientNetV2B3 was selected as the most effective model. A sparsity-driven threshold-based pruning strategy was then applied, reducing parameters by approximately 78% (from 12.9M to 2.86M) while retaining competitive classification accuracy. Feature vectors extracted from the pruned model were refined using Genetic Algorithm, Particle Swarm Optimization, and Lion Optimization Algorithm. Results: The pruned EfficientNetV2B3 model maintained high performance, achieving 97.70% +/- 0.11 accuracy. Among all evaluated classifiers, Random Forest combined with genetic Algorithm-selected features yielded the best results: 98.64% +/- 0.25 accuracy, 98.67% +/- 0.24 precision, and 98.66% +/- 0.26 F1-score. Additionally, visualization techniques such as t-SNE and Grad-CAM were used to confirm feature separability and enhance model interpretability. Conclusion/Impact: The proposed hybrid framework demonstrates that significant model compression can be achieved without compromising diagnostic accuracy. It offers a computationally efficient and interpretable solution suitable for deployment in real-time and low-resource clinical environments.
Article Title: A novel pruning-enhanced hybrid approach for efficient and accurate brain tumor diagnosis

Abstract: Confocal laser scanning microscope enables non-invasive ocular Demodex screening but faces field-of-view (FOV) limitations. Although image stitching can theoretically expand FOV, traditional methods only achieve approximately 60% success rate due to low illumination, weak textures and repetitive patterns. To address these challenges, we propose an unsupervised deep learning-based image stitching framework with dual-stage alignment and generative adversarial network (GAN)-based fusion. Our dual-stage alignment network combines homography matrix and Thin Plate Spline (TPS) transformations to accommodate tissue deformation during imaging, supported by a Non-Maximum Suppression Feature Displacement Layer that simultaneously considers both long-range and short-range dependencies, yielding more accurate results with reduced memory consumption. To achieve smooth and seamless image fusion, we employ a GAN framework where the generator is designed to produce fusion probability maps that eliminate noticeable blending seams and fusion artifacts. This is an innovative attempt to apply deep learning for precise image stitching in confocal superficial eyelid image, demonstrating 40% higher success rate than traditional methods. Quantitative evaluations show 13.37% and 3.25% improvements in mPSNR and mSSIM over the state-of-the-art model, with 11.29% and 3.76% reductions in NIQE and PIQE metrics.
Article Title: Unsupervised confocal superficial eyelid image stitching: Flexible, accurate and smooth

Abstract: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the recommended imaging modality for breast cancer diagnosis; however, classifying benign and malignant breast lesions using multi-sequence MRI remains a significant challenge. This is primarily due to the heterogeneity and complexity of breast lesions, along with the substantial imaging data provided by each sequence of MRI. These factors place high demands on the expertise of clinicians, and the processing of extensive MRI scans is both costly and prone to error. Different sequence MRI reveals diverse characteristics of the lesions, and joint analysis of multi-sequence data has greater diagnostic value for breast cancer. In recent years, some studies have attempted to employ deep learning methods for multi-sequence MRI fusion to enhance diagnostic performance. However, existing approaches often lack robust strategies for feature learning that are specifically tailored to the distinct characteristics of each sequence MRI. Additionally, they have not fully leveraged the relevant information from multi-sequence MRI during modeling, limiting the effectiveness of the model. Inspired by the diagnostic workflow of radiologists, an Attention-driven Feature Learning and Fusion (AFLF) framework was proposed to classify benign and malignant breast lesions using multi-sequence MRI. Our framework employs an attention-based encoding network to learn attention-aware representations for each sequence MRI, enabling the model to focus on the unique lesion characteristics in each sequence. Furthermore, an adaptive attention learning fusion module facilitates the interaction and fusion of these representations, ensuring the relevance and representativeness of the features from different sequences are fully leveraged to achieve efficient breast cancer diagnosis. Experiments on MRI scans from 318 patients demonstrate that the AFLF outperforms existing state-of-the-art algorithms, achieving a classification accuracy of 93.75% and an AUC of 98.89%1.
Article Title: Attention-driven multi-sequence MRI representations for breast cancer diagnosis

Abstract: Nasal Septal Deviation (NSD) is a common anatomical variation that, if left untreated, can significantly affect patient quality of life and overall health. Therefore, early assessment of NSD is essential for timely intervention planning. Computed tomography (CT) scans are a critical imaging modality, providing detailed visualization nasal anatomy and allowing precise measurement of deviation angles. However, the current level of automation in the diagnosis of NSD remains low, with the screening heavily based on manual assessment, and no intelligent diagnostic tools specifically designed for NSD have been developed. To address this problem, this study presents an automatic NSD evaluation method (NSD-Net) that leverages patient CT imaging data to accurately quantify the extent of septal deviation. First, we incorporate an attention mechanism to enhance the model's learning capacity, guiding it to concentrate on the nasal septum region. Second, we integrate an Image Warping Augmentation Module to strengthen the model's predictive robustness for rare and challenging cases. Finally, a multi-task learning-based Landmark Refinement Module is introduced to further refine landmark localization accuracy, ensuring higher precision. Due to the lack of an existing public dataset for this task, we constructed the first dedicated dataset for NSD assessment. Extensive experiments on this dataset demonstrate that proposed method achieves an evaluation accuracy comparable to that of expert clinicians.
Article Title: NSD-Net: An automatic assessment framework for nasal septum deviation based on landmark detection

Abstract: Wearable electrocardiogram monitors equipped with edge-end classifier is a transformative tool for managing cardiovascular diseases. Whereas, electrocardiogram pattern variations have posed difficulties in obtaining robust accuracy among different individuals. To address this issue, this paper proposes a novel neural network architecture, resembling the diagnosis procedure of cardiologists while utilizing the robustness of artificial intelligent models. Also, this work introduces a quantization-aware-training algorithm that enables weight and activation quantization within recurrent neural network layers, which has traditionally been difficult due to their temporal dependencies and complex internal structure. Evaluated on a widely used public electrocardiogram dataset, it shows over 96.4% inter-patient classification accuracy across 43 subjects, which is superior to other state-of-the-arts. The quantized model maintains accuracy with only a 0.1% loss while reducing model precision to 4-bit integer weights and 6-bit integer activations. When deployed on a field-programmable gate array, the proposed classifier consumes 24 mW at a maximum clock frequency of 40MHz with a latency of 420ms. Compared to the full-precision counterpart, the hardware resource usage is significantly reduced, including reductions of 47.2% in look up tables, 45.5% in flip-flops, 78.9% in block memories, and 93.0% in digital signal processors. The source code is available at https://github.com/xinziXu/ CardioLike-Net.git.
Article Title: CardioLike-Net: An edge-end inter-patient arrhythmia classifier with quantization-aware-training for wearable ECG applications

Abstract: Medical image segmentation with deep learning has demonstrated considerable potential, but remains challenged by the limited availability of annotated data. Traditional supervised approaches are constrained by the need for extensive expert-labeled datasets, particularly for 3D images where annotation is time-consuming and resource-intensive. We propose TRIM (TRansductive-Inference-based Model), a novel transductive learning framework that leverages both labeled and unlabeled data to enhance segmentation performance. TRIM first generates pseudo-labels from test data using a pre-trained model, then iteratively refines itself through self-training. To address computational constraints, we introduce complementary data distillation (DD) and weight distillation (WD) mechanisms, which significantly reduce training and inference overhead while maintaining accuracy. Our approach secured 1st place in the competitive CHAOS multi-modal segmentation challenge, achieving a mean Dice score of 94.95% across five tasks and outperforming established methods. A comprehensive evaluation on diverse 3D medical imaging modalities (MR, CT, and US) demonstrated the robustness and performance of our method, while requiring significantly fewer parameters and computing resources.TRIM enables accurate medical image segmentation with minimal expert input by combining transductive inference and efficient distillation, providing a practical solution for diverse medical imaging applications.
Article Title: Leveraging distillation in transductive learning for improved medical image segmentation

Abstract: 18F-labeled fluoro-2-deoxyglucose (18F-FDG) positron emission tomography (PET) is highly sensitive to metabolic activity, while computed tomography (CT) provides high-resolution anatomical information. Effectively fusing these complementary imaging modalities can significantly improve the accuracy and reliability of earlystage diagnoses. In recent years, CT/PET hybrid imaging has been increasingly employed for the early diagnosis of endometrial cancer; however, deep learning-based fusion techniques specifically tailored for this task remain underexplored. To bridge this gap, we propose a novel Multi-Scale Residual Dual-Stream Network (MSRD-Net) for CT and PET image fusion, designed to provide comprehensive and clinically meaningful diagnostic information for endometrial cancer. Specifically, cross-modality features are first extracted through a dedicated feature extraction encoder, followed by a decomposition-and-integration process within a feature integration decoder. The fusion process is further guided by an equivariant imaging loss function to enhance consistency and robustness. Extensive experiments demonstrate that MSRD-Net produces high-quality fusion results for endometrial cancer imaging and generalizes effectively to other tasks, including infrared-visible and multimodal medical image fusion. Furthermore, reliability experiments validate the interpretability and practical potential of the proposed method.
Article Title: MSRD-Net: a multi-scale residual dual-stream network for Multi-Modality image fusion in CT/PET

Abstract: This research introduces a revolutionary palm vein authentication mechanism that achieves a significant level of accuracy and privacy. To achieve accuracy, a novel mix of preprocessing techniques (ROI, modified adaptive filter, Histogram equalization, skeletonization) are applied on various classification models (Decision tree, Random Forest, Principal Component Analysis-Support Vector Machine (PCA-SVM), Principal Component Analysis- Random Forest (PCA-RF), Partial Least Square-Regression (PLS-R)). The experimental findings demonstrate that PLS-R outperforms other models. For further improvement, PLS-R model is expanded and iterated over several components to find the best performing model based on certain criteria (e.g., accuracy, variance explained). To attain privacy, distance matrix of optimized PLS-R model is calculated during the training phase and generated secured template for authentication. Compared with state-of-the-art technique, our technique can ensure accuracy and privacy in biometric authentication by using feature reduction, distancematrix computation, and threshold-based decision making for identity verification. Overall, the proposed model provides a secure authentication mechanism with high accuracy, and the privacy preservation of biometric traits.
Article Title: EPVM: An efficient privacy-preserving palm vein model for user authentication

Abstract: Many countries are still facing with the challenges posed by malaria, it is a persistent threat to health systems. Early identification is crucial in avoiding severe health consequences. In this study, the authors proposed a novel approach that integrates Yen's Iterative Thresholding (YIT), Kernel Spectral Clustering (KSC), and Graph Attention Networks (GATs) for the detection and segmentation of malaria-infected cells in thin blood smear images. YIT, a form of adaptive thresholding, partitions the foreground (cells) and the background (non-cell components) based on adaptive thresholds that are driven by intensity patterns within the image. KSC then clusters similar regions based on their descriptive higher-dimensional features, capturing subtle differences in cells. Finally, GATs are used to spatially reason about the cells in a more structured way using graphs. This approach achieved a remarkable 96% accuracy with a loss of 0.25 when tested on a dataset of 25,000 labeled images. This approach also outperformed standard segmentation techniques, particularly in difficult imaging conditions. The automated framework is tailored for low resource clinical settings, enhancing its practicality for use in automated malaria screening tests.
Article Title: A hybrid image processing and graph neural networks for malaria detection in blood smears

Abstract: Problem: Arthritis is an autoimmune disease with rising global incidence, particularly among the elderly. Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most prevalent form, with cases projected to approach 1 billion by 2050. In India, rheumatoid arthritis (RA) occurs at a higher rate than the global average. Accurate assessment of arthritis severity often relies on detecting inflammation, which can be effectively visualized through thermal imaging as temperature-elevated hotspot regions. Precise segmentation of these hotspots is essential for diagnosis. Aim: This study aims to develop a robust and accurate segmentation methodology for detecting inflammation hotspots in thermal images to improve arthritis diagnosis. Methods: We propose an ensemble-based segmentation approach specifically tailored for thermal imagery. Edge features are enhanced using the Area Morphological Scale Space (AMSS) algorithm, and multiple segmentation maps are generated using various clustering techniques. A variation of information (VOI)-based consensus technique is employed to combine these maps, followed by refinement using a Greedy Iterated Conditional Modes (ICM) algorithm. Results: The proposed method was evaluated on three thermal datasets, demonstrating a significant improvement in hotspot detection accuracy. The algorithm achieved an average accuracy of approximately 97% across all datasets. Conclusion: The ensemble-based approach effectively addresses the limitations of traditional methods, providing precise and reliable hotspot segmentation in thermal images, which can aid in the accurate assessment and diagnosis of arthritis.
Article Title: Cluster ensemble based semi supervised ROI segmentation in thermal images

Abstract: In the rapidly advancing field of Alzheimer's disease (AD) intelligent diagnosis, longitudinal and multimodal data are essential for accurately characterizing the disease's dynamic progression.
