However, the frequent absence of medical data in clinical practice presents a major challenge for current diagnostic methods. Traditional techniques for handling missing data often introduce bias, and many existing studies overlook AD's continuous progression, relying instead on single-timepoint imaging data. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a Missing-Aware Attention Network (MANet), which leverages the complementarity of multimodal and longitudinal data for early AD diagnosis. Specifically, we design an Index-Missing Bernoulli (IMB) module that dynamically generates an index matrix to simulate diverse missing-data patterns encountered in real clinical settings. This ensures an unbiased contribution from each modality's features, and enhances the model's generalization and robustness when handling incomplete inputs. In addition, we introduce a Cross-Dimensional Shared Attention (CSA) mechanism, which jointly optimizes spatial and channel attention, establishes cross-dimensional dependencies among feature maps, and improves the model's adaptive integration of heterogeneous multimodal information. Experimental results on an independent test set demonstrate that the proposed network outperforms existing methods, achieving an area under the curve (AUC) of 97.12% and an accuracy of 95.70%. By integrating multimodal information, the model effectively captures subtle pathological features that are difficult to detect using single-modality data, further improving diagnostic performance to an AUC of 99.90% and an accuracy of 97.71%. These findings highlight the model's considerable potential as an advanced tool for AD diagnosis.
Article Title: MANet: A missing-aware attention network for early Alzheimer's disease diagnosis using longitudinal and multimodal data

Abstract: Lung cancer remains a leading cause of cancer-related deaths globally, with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) accounting for approximately 85% of cases. The tumor microenvironment (TME) plays a crucial role in lung cancer progression and treatment response. Multiplex immunofluorescence (MIF) technology provides a unique perspective for analyzing spatial relationships within the complex TME. However, existing methods for processing MIF pathological images often process each image in isolation, overlooking both intra-patient multi-image complementarity and inter-patient pathological similarities. To address these limitations, we introduce the Hypergraph Aggregation Contrastive Learning Network (HACLN), which constructs a hypergraph to jointly model intra-patient multi-image features and inter-patient pathological relationships. HACLN aggregates features from multiple MIF images per patient, decomposes them into specialized subgraphs, and integrates them to enhance feature discrimination. We validate HACLN using an immunofluorescence image dataset from the First Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou Medical University, demonstrating its effectiveness in capturing microenvironmental features and modeling patient-to-patient similarities. Here, we show that HACLN achieves a C-index of 0.7023, outperforming existing methods, providing a new direction for future research in lung cancer prognostic prediction based on the tumor microenvironment. Code is available at: https://github.com/ sujuKyukyu/HACLN_code
Article Title: Hypergraph aggregation contrastive learning network for lung cancer prognostic prediction based on tumor microenvironment

Abstract: Lung cancer is a predominant cause of cancer-related deaths globally, and early detection is essential for improving patient prognosis. Deep learning models with attention mechanisms have shown promising accuracy in detecting lung cancer from medical imaging data. However, privacy concerns and data scarcity present significant challenges in developing robust and generalizable models. This paper proposes a novel approach for lung cancer detection, 'FVCM-Net', integrating federated learning with attention mechanisms and ensemble learning to address these challenges. Federated learning is employed to train the model across multiple decentralized institutions, allowing for collaborative model development without sharing sensitive patient data and minimizing the risk of such sensitive data being misused. Furthermore, this approach enables the development of more accurate and generalized models by leveraging diverse datasets from multiple sources. We employed ensemble learning to produce more accurate predictions than a single model. For interpretability of the lung cancer identification model, we employ XAI (Explainable Artificial Intelligence) techniques such as SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) and HiResCAM (High-Resolution Class Activation Mapping). These techniques help us understand how the model makes its decisions and predictions. This study utilizes a diverse collection of lung CT scan images from four datasets, including LIDC-IDRI, IQ-OTH/NCCD, a public Kaggle dataset, and additional online sources. Experimental results revealed that the proposed method achieved higher performance in lung cancer detection with 98.26% average accuracy and 97.37% average F-1 score. The high performance of FVCM-Net and ensemble learning has the potential to significantly impact medical imaging, helping radiologists make better clinical decisions.
Article Title: FVCM-Net: Interpretable privacy-preserved attention driven lung cancer detection from CT scan images with explainable HiRes-CAM attribution map and ensemble

Abstract: Automatic depression detection (ADD) from multimodal interviews offers unobtrusive mental-health screening, yet current systems often miss faint behavioral cues, suffer under noisy inputs, and rely heavily on annotated data. We propose MSCDV, a transformer-based framework where three tightly integrated mechanisms form a unified learning loop. A multi-scale encoder captures local facial, vocal, and lexical nuances while maintaining global context; a perturbation-based consistency loss enforces alignment between clean and noised views, improving robustness; and a dual-view stepwise schedule presents complementary modality subsets in alternation, enhancing generalization under data scarcity. Because all components are co-optimized, improvements in one propagate through the system, producing features that are fine-grained, noise-aware, and data-efficient. On the DAIC-WOZ and E-DAIC benchmarks, MSCDV achieves mean F1-scores of 0.87 and 0.82, respectively, outperforming a wide range of state-of-the-art baselines without requiring additional supervision. Extensive ablations confirm that removing any single component results in performance degradation, underscoring their synergistic contribution to robust, real-world ADD.
Article Title: A multi-scale transformer framework with consistency and dual-view for depression detection

Abstract: Objective Electrocardiogram (ECG) classification models face limitations due to reliance on large labeled datasets, which are scarce owing to patient privacy and annotation costs. This study addresses this challenge of reducing the reliance on labeled data without compromising diagnostic accuracy. Methods The proposed framework utilizes unlabeled ECG data to mine intrinsic data representations as self-supervised signals through pretext tasks, thereby improving model's feature extraction capabilities. Specifically, a novel global-local self-supervised contrastive learning framework is proposed, which performs contrastive learning at both the sample and element levels to enable the pre-trained encoder to learn richer feature representations. Results In the downstream tasks, 20 % of the labeled training data was used to fine-tune the pre-trained encoder, and its performance was evaluated on the full test set. Compared to fully supervised learning using the same proportion of training data, the proposed method achieved statistically significant improvements in performance metrics on the CPSC2018 downstream tasks: AUC, Acc, F1-score and Kappa increased by 1.46, 1.03, 2.42, and 2.00 %, respectively. Similarly, for the PTB-XL downstream task, AUC, Acc, F1-score and Kappa improved by 1.68, 1.67, 2.68 and 2.56%, respectively. Conclusions This method significantly reduces dependency on annotated data while maintaining diagnostic accuracy, demonstrating its clinical potential. By enabling effective training with limited labeled data, it lowers barriers to developing ECG analysis tools in resource-constrained environments and accelerates automated arrhythmia detection.
Article Title: Self-supervised contrastive learning achieves 12-lead ECG classification

Abstract: Brain tumor classification is one of the most challenging tasks in clinical diagnosis and treatment within medical image analysis. Errors during the diagnostic process can significantly impact patient outcomes, making accuracy paramount. However, many existing techniques overlook critical features that hold substantial relevance for classification, focusing instead on extracting deep but less discriminative features. Deep learning-based categorization of brain tumors using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has emerged as a vital research area. This paper introduces an automated deep learning model and an optimal information fusion framework for brain tumor classification from MRI images. The dataset used in this study was imbalanced, posing a significant challenge for training deep learning models, as it biases classifier performance toward the majority class. To address this, we designed a sparse autoencoder network to generate synthetic images, effectively resolving class imbalance. Subsequently, two pretrained neural networks were fine-tuned, with hyperparameters optimized via Bayesian optimization for enhanced training. Deep features were then extracted from the global average pooling layer, yielding a refined set with minimal irrelevant information. To further optimize feature selection, we propose a novel Quantum-Inspired Adaptive Feature Selector (QIAFS) algorithm, which identifies the most discriminative features from both networks and fuses them using a serial-based approach. The fused feature set is then classified using neural network classifiers. Our framework was evaluated on an augmented Figshare dataset, achieving an accuracy of 98.9%, a sensitivity of 99.83%, a false negative rate of 17%, and a precision of 99.73% in average. Comparative and ablation studies demonstrate the significant improvement in performance over existing methods.
Article Title: Quantum-inspired adaptive feature fusion for highly accurate brain tumor classification in MRI using deep learning

Abstract: Electromyography (EMG) offers a natural and non-invasive interface for human-computer interaction, and machine learning (ML) is increasingly used to recognize gestures from recorded EMG signals. However, the statistical distributions of EMG show high inter-person variability, making cross-subject interpretation unreliable. Calibration phases with guided exercises are currently used in commercial devices to address this issue. Modern solutions rely on unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) methods which align the sample distributions of different subjects without requiring tedious calibration exercises. However, when a real concept shift occurs (e.g. a similar signal pattern corresponds to different gestures in different subjects), these alignment methods are inefficient. This paper presents a novel linear and shallow UDA method based on Linear Discriminant Analysis and K-Means to address cross-subject calibration. To better handle real concept shifts, this parsimonious and easy-to-use method is non-conservative, meaning that it relies only on target samples and initial pseudo-labels rather than performing domain alignment. We perform in-depth evaluation against state-of-the-art deep-learning methods across multiple datasets and feature extraction pipelines and emulate a realistic system using streamed EMG to show the significant potential of our method. Our findings show that our approach significantly improves cross-subject accuracy compared to existing methods, effectively closing the accuracy gap between intra-subject and cross-subject classification. It requires only a few gesture repetitions to converge to accurate decision boundaries and remains robust to variations in data characteristics.
Article Title: Linear non-conservative unsupervised domain adaptation for cross-subject EMG gesture recognition

Abstract: Sleep is crucial to human health, and in recent years, automatic sleep stage classification based on polysomnography(PSG) has become a hot topic in sleep science research. With the rapid development of artificial intelligence technology, especially the wide application of deep learning methods, the research on automatic sleep stage classification has made significant progress. However, existing methods mainly focus on time-frequency feature extraction and channel selection of signals, often ignoring the deep impact of biological mechanisms such as neuronal impulses on sleep stage classification. To this end, we propose a deep learning model called SPSNet, which innovatively introduces the impulse mechanism of a spiking neural network(SNN) and the structure of relational graph based on the transformation of the Watts-Strogatz(WS) small-world network into the epoch-level multi-channel sleep feature fusion process. This design not only achieves efficient sparse computation through SNN, but also enhances the interaction between neurons and improves the overall model performance through the relational graph structure. Experimental results on three public datasets(UCD, SleepEDF-78, HMC) show that SPSNet significantly improves the classification performance while effectively reducing network complexity and energy consumption compared to the baseline model approach, the accuracy(ACC) on the three datasets were 0.772, 0.807, and 0.775, the F1-score(MF1) were 0.761, 0.758, and 0.756, and the Cohen's Kappa(kappa) was 0.703, 0.739, and 0.706, representing improvements of 0.3% to 1.8% over the respective best baseline models. Overall, our work provides a new way of thinking for automatic sleep stage classification that combines spiking neural networks with relational graph structures.
Article Title: SPSNet: A spiking neural network with relation graphs for sleep stage classification based on polysomnography

Abstract: This study critically evaluates the methodological approach employed by Nayak et al. in COVID-19 CT scan classification using their Dense-Res-Inception Ensemble Network with PCA dimensionality reduction. We demonstrate fundamental limitations in applying PCA to nonlinear biological imaging data, where key mathematical assumptions-including linearity, meaningful correlations, and homoscedasticity-are frequently violated. Using the MNIST dataset as a benchmark, we comparatively assessed three dimensionality reduction techniques: PCA, High Variance Gene Selection, and Feature Agglomeration (FA). Results confirm that FA significantly outperforms PCA (92.79% vs 83.76% accuracy) by preserving crucial spatial relationships within image data. This performance disparity highlights the critical importance of methodological alignment with data characteristics in medical imaging analysis. We propose that nonlinear dimensionality reduction approaches better accommodate the complex relationships inherent in biological systems, potentially enhancing both computational efficiency and diagnostic reliability in clinical applications requiring rapid assessment.
Article Title: Limitations of principal component analysis in COVID-19 CT image classification

Abstract: Nuclei in cell images are characterized by small size, high quantity, and high density, often with overlapping phenomena. This makes interactive methods such as contour-based approaches unsuitable for interactive cell nucleus image segmentation tasks. To improve the segmentation accuracy of nuclei, this study proposes a singleclick interactive cell nucleus image segmentation method based on enhanced exclusion map and refinement segmentation. The proposed method employs a simple single-click interaction mechanism to alleviate the user's interaction burden. It introduces an enhanced exclusion map module and a Refinement Segmentation Module based on focused interaction to improve the quality of interactive cell nucleus image segmentation. The code is available at https://github.com/AICFStar/IClick.
Article Title: Single-click interactive cell nucleus image segmentation: Boosting accuracy with enhanced exclusion map and refinement segmentation

Abstract: Accurate quantification of retinal vessel morphology is critical for both clinical decision-making and advancing the understanding of various diseases. Accurate classification of retinal arteries and veins (A/V) is fundamental to vessel morphology analysis. However, in ultra-wide-field (UWF) fundus imaging, this task remains challenging due to significant variations in vessel scales and spatial confusion in A/V classification. In this paper, we propose a novel network, NeiRNet, to segment and distinguish arteries and veins in UWF images simultaneously. Specifically, we propose a multi-receptive field perception module to enhance the model's ability to capture multi-scale vessel structures, thereby improving the recognition and segmentation of small vessels. To further ensure the topological continuity of the segmented A/V, we propose a neighborhood connectivity regularization layer, which strengthens the model's capacity to infer vessel topology by predicting the connectivity between a pixel and its neighboring pixels. Additionally, we design a local connectivity consistency loss term to explicitly enforce the regularization layer's effectiveness in accurately modeling pixel-to-pixel connectivity within vessel structures. Extensive experiments conducted on seven datasets, comprising four UWF datasets and three color fundus photography (CFP) datasets, validate the effectiveness of the proposed NeiRNet model. The results highlight its superior performance in A/V segmentation and its robust cross-modal generalizability between UWF and CFP imaging modalities.
Article Title: NeiRNet: Neighborhood regularized network for retinal artery and vein classification in ultra-wide-field imaging

Abstract: Cell micronuclei, key indicators of chromosomal damage, have broad applications in environmental toxicology, radiation research, and drug safety testing. Existing deep learning based micronuclei detection face numerous challenges including morphological similarity between micronuclei and cell nuclei, large size differences, and loss of detail information during multi-scale feature fusion. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an innovative cell micronucleus detection method termed YOLO-MN based on prior knowledge and frequency domain perception. We designed a wavelet feature enhancement (WFE) module based on two-dimensional discrete wavelet transform, which extracts multi-scale features through wavelet decomposition and enhances edge and chromatin texture information of micronuclei during feature fusion. Next, we designed a micronucleus attention module (MAM) and improved CSP feature extraction network (C2f_MAM) based on biological prior knowledge of micronuclei, focusing on shape features and capturing spatial relationships between micronuclei and the main nucleus. Finally, we designed an MNIoU loss function incorporating micronucleus prior knowledge to accelerate model convergence and further improve detection accuracy. Experimental results show that YOLOMN achieved 91.7% Precision, 93.4% Recall, 94.7% mAP@50, and 59.1% mAP@50-95 on the cell micronucleus dataset, the model's generalization capability was further validated on the SRCHD and LISC datasets.
Article Title: YOLO-MN: High-Throughput cell micronucleus detection based on prior knowledge and frequency domain perception

Abstract: The identification and phenotyping of scarred myocardium using cine magnetic resonance imaging (cine-MRI) play a pivotal role in the diagnosis and treatment of cardiovascular diseases. Myocardial motion tracking has garnered widespread attention for cine-MRI analysis. However, the complex myocardial motion motion-related deformations limit the performance of existing methods. In this paper, we present a relative motion representation and learning framework. Our relative motion descriptor focuses on two aspects: static features and dynamic features. Particularly, we first project rays at specific angles from the geometric center of the blood pool in each frame, intersecting with the endocardium and epicardium. Subsequently, we represent the myocardial motion features based on the displacement and curvature of intersection points relative to the geometric center point in different frames. To further explore the motion features, we introduce a Multi-Orientated Spatio-Temporal Multi-Layer Perception (MOST-MLP) for myocardial motion encoding. The proposed MOST-MLP is evaluated on one private dataset comprising 450 subjects and public datasets (ACDC and M&Ms), with its strong performance across these benchmarks demonstrating method's effectiveness and superiority. Our code and pre-trained models are available at https://github.com/ gaoningn/MOST-MLP to facilitate reproducibility and further research.
Article Title: Deep relative motion analysis for the identification and phenotyping of scarred myocardium using cine-MRI

Abstract: The precise classification of breast cancer (BC) is essential for prompt diagnosis and efficient treatment. Deep learning (DL) methodologies have shown considerable promise in BC diagnosis utilizing histopathological images; nonetheless, the impact of image magnification and magnification fusion on model efficacy remains inadequately investigated. This study resolves this deficiency by performing an exhaustive assessment of twenty sophisticated DL architectures, comprising ten Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and ten Vision Transformers (ViTs), employing two datasets: BreakHis, which encompasses images at various magnifications (40x, 100x, 200x, and 400 x ), and BACH, which concentrates on a singular magnification (200 x ). The approach includes two categorization scenarios: individual image magnification and image magnification fusion. Our results indicate that image magnification fusion improves performance in binary (malignant vs. benign) and multiclass classification relative to higher image magnifications (200 x and 400 x ) for the majority of models. Nonetheless, lower magnifications, especially 40x, generally attained greater accuracy, indicating their appropriateness for DL-based BC identification. Our methodology, which compares single image magnifications with image magnification fusion, surpassed earlier research that was restricted to either individual or fused magnifications. Utilizing the BreakHis dataset, the top-performing models attained 100 % accuracy in binary classification and 97.00 % in multi-class classification with ViT structures, confirming their superiority over CNNs. Using the BACH dataset, Tiny ViT-21 m outperformed CNN with a multi-class classification accuracy of 96.25 %. These findings highlight the significance of incorporating magnification parameters in DL model building and indicate that lesser magnifications, such as 40x, may yield optimal performance. This investigation establishes a basis for future research to successfully incorporate multi-magnification information, hence enhancing BC classification accuracy.
Article Title: Impact of magnification on deep learning approaches through comprehensive comparative study of histopathological breast cancer classification

Abstract: Surface Electromyography (sEMG)-based gesture recognition is a rapidly evolving field with significant implications for human-machine interfaces. However, the inherent complexity of sEMG signals, characterized by high dimensionality and temporal variability, poses challenges for accurate classification. Traditional methods often rely on time-domain features, which may overlook the rich frequency-domain information contained in sEMG signals. Recent advancements in deep learning have shown promise in addressing these challenges, yet many existing models are computationally intensive and lack interpretability. To overcome these limitations, a lightweight Depthwise Separable Residual Attention Network (DSRANet) is designed for sEMG gesture recognition. DSRANet employs Depthwise Separable Residual Blocks (DSRBlocks) to efficiently extract discriminative features while minimizing computational complexity. The architecture incorporates Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT)-based time-frequency representations to capture dynamic spectral shifts, grounded in the physiological insights of muscle activity. A novel Multi-Axis Channel Attention (MACA) mechanism is proposed to emphasize informative features across channels and time-frequency dimensions. Evaluated on the NinaPro dataset, DSRANet achieves state-of-the-art results with accuracies of 92.13% on DB2, 75.65% on DB3, and 91.00% on DB4, which correspond to improvements of 4.1%, 5.07%, and 1.57% over existing best methods, respectively. Furthermore, the proposed DSRANet has a low number of parameters (only 0.46 million), compared to existing models, whose parameters range from approximately 0.80 million to 4.03 million, demonstrating its efficiency. This work addresses the challenges of accuracy and computational efficiency in sEMG gesture recognition, paving the way for advancements in prosthetics, rehabilitation, and interactive systems. The code of this work is available at https://github.com/hdy6438/DSRANet.
Article Title: DSRANet: A lightweight Depthwise Separable Residual Attention Network for sEMG gesture recognition

Abstract: This paper introduces a novel Brain-to-Speech system that advances the state of EEG-based speech decoding through a phoneme-centric and cognitively aware architecture. Departing from traditional word-level decoding frameworks, this proposal leverages phoneme-level recognition to support open-vocabulary generalization, enabling the system to reconstruct unseen words by learning the fundamental speech sound units. A core innovation of this work lies in its multi-stage preprocessing pipeline, which integrates spatially constrained Independent Component Analysis with a neural preservation function to selectively suppress artifacts while preserving phoneme-relevant oscillations. Complementary feature extraction techniques, including Short-Time Fourier Transform, Hilbert-Huang Transform, and Phase-Amplitude Coupling, are fused and reduced in dimensionality. In addition, the system incorporates dedicated ocular and muscular artifact-sensitive electrodes to enhance artifact removal by spatially localizing eye-blink and muscle-induced noise. Furthermore, the model introduces an imagined speech discrimination module to effectively differentiate word-related cognition from non-linguistic mental noise, significantly improving decoding reliability. A self-supervised learning pipeline is trained to extract high-level phoneme-discriminative embeddings, which are then used for real-time phoneme prediction. The system is deployed within an IoT-compatible edge architecture, ensuring low-latency processing and high inference efficiency. Experimental validation on benchmark sentence datasets demonstrates superior performance across multiple evaluation metrics. The proposed model achieves the highest post-processing SNR with an improvement of over 26 dB, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art EEG and ECoG systems. The proposal records the lowest word, phoneme, and out-of-vocabulary error rates, while maximizing the accuracy of similar-sounding words. These advancements accelerates the development of real-world neural communication technologies, including thought-to-speech prosthetics and silent telephony.
Article Title: Real-time artifact-resilient brain-to-speech conversion via adaptive EEG feature learning and phoneme-level reconstruction

Abstract: Sleep staging is crucial for assessing sleep quality and diagnosing sleep-related disorders. Despite advancements in automatic sleep staging methods using multimodal signals, significant limitations remain in effectively addressing key challenges. These challenges include inconsistent contributions from various physiological modalities, efficient modeling of long sequences, and class imbalance. To address these challenges, this paper proposes SleepRWKVNet, a novel multimodal sleep staging network. The method first extracts deep features from multimodal signals using a two-branch feature learning module. These features are subsequently input into the Bi-IFM, the core component of SleepRWKVNet, which effectively addresses inconsistent modality contributions, the unidirectionality of classical RWKV, and long sequence processing efficiency. It achieves this through bidirectional processing and an efficient modal interaction mechanism, ultimately producing fused feature representations. The fused features are refined by a main modal feature enhancement module and then passed to a classification layer for sleep stage prediction. During training, SleepRWKVNet employs PS-Loss, an innovative dynamic sequence-aware loss function based on individual physiological priors. By integrating subject-specific Markov transition probabilities between sleep stages and dynamically adjusting sample weights based on sequence context and physiological plausibility, this loss function effectively mitigates class imbalance and enhances the modeling of physiological transitions. Extensive experiments on three public sleep datasets demonstrate that SleepRwkvNet significantly outperforms representative methods across all evaluation metrics, offering a novel solution for efficient and accurate automated sleep staging.
Article Title: SleepRWKVNet: A multimodal sleep staging network integrating bidirectional interactive RWKV and physiological prior-driven sequence-aware loss

Abstract: Accurate brain tumor detection models are critical to saving thousands of lives. While deep learning methods have advanced significantly in this domain, they often fail to capture the subtle inter-class differences among tumor types and are constrained by the limited diversity of tumor categories in existing datasets. To address these challenges, we propose a new real-time brain tumor detector called YOLO-BT. First, we design a Rep-Ghost Cross-stage Enhanced Lightweight Aggregation (RGCE) module , effectively reducing feature redundancy during feature extraction while maintaining detection accuracy. Second, we redesign the neck network and propose a Feature-Focused Adaptive Diffusion Mechanism (FFADM) to enhance information refinement and utilization in multi-scale feature fusion. Furthermore, a lightweight shared convolutional head is introduced to minimize model parameters. Finally, we develop a novel loss function to overcome the limitations of conventional loss functions in brain tumor detection. Experimental results on our proprietary brain tumor dataset demonstrate that the proposed algorithm reduces computational complexity by 21.0% and parameter count by 32.1% compared to the baseline YOLOv8n. The model achieves mAP50:95 (mean Average Precision) values of 72.7%, 74.6%, and 39.0% on our self-built dataset, Brain Tumor Detection 2020, and Ultralytics Brain Tumor Dataset, respectively. The proposed algorithm outperformed the latest YOLOv12 across all three evaluation datasets.
Article Title: YOLO-BT: A novel brain tumor detector with gradient-guided feature diffusion

Abstract: Prior research have not extensively explored potential categorical differences in mental fatigue induced through various methods. In this study, mental fatigue was induced through two methods: continuous cognitive tasks (CCT) and sleep deprivation (SD), with data on EEG and eye movement modalities collected before and after fatigue induction. Using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) algorithm with an attention mechanism, we classified the multimodal data to identify the presence of mental fatigue. The results demonstrate that multimodal features significantly outperform unimodal features in fatigue recognition, with CNN model achieving superior classification performance compared to other machine learning models. In classifying different types of mental fatigue (CCT or SD), CNN model still worked effectively. However, CNN's performance was akin to random guessing in categorizing different durations of sleep deprivation (24 or 36 h). These findings suggest that the CNN algorithm based on attention mechanism optimization in detecting neurophysiological signals between fatigue and non-fatigue is quite effective, and the mental fatigue generated by the two induced modes is indeed quite different, while the neurophysiological responses of different durations of sleep deprivation show considerable similarity with 36 h.
Article Title: Detecting neurophysiological differences in mental fatigue: A multimodal approach with CNN analysis based on attention mechanism

Abstract: Cardiovascular diseases are the leading cause of death worldwide, therefore precise and timely diagnosis improves patient outcomes while lowering medical costs. Effectiveness of classification models is still limited by the challenges associated with managing high-dimensional medical datasets, despite advancements in machine learning. Traditional feature selection strategies are often ineffective due to the data dimensionality and complexity. This study improves feature selection and classification accuracy in cardiovascular disease datasets by utilising the Mayfly Algorithm (MA), a novel meta-heuristic optimisation technique inspired by mayfly mating behaviour. The MA is used in the study to find the best features using five real-time cardiovascular datasets. The chosen features are evaluated using classifiers such as Random Forest (RF), K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN), and Support Vector Machine (SVM). Traditional optimization techniques, including Genetic Algorithm (GA), Particle Swarm Optimisation (PSO), and Ant Colony Optimisation (ACO), are examined and contrasted. With a large reduction in feature space and good classification accuracy, the MA showed superior performance in feature selection. Compared to previous approaches, which varied between 80% and 85%, the classification accuracies projected to be attained are in the range of 90% to 95% across the five datasets. Significant gains in classification accuracy and feature reduction were attained by the MA's consistent selection of the most pertinent features. The Mayfly Algorithm's potential for medical data analysis is demonstrated by this work, especially for highdimensional cardiovascular datasets. When it comes to real-time disease classification, MA outperforms other optimization strategies in terms of accuracy and effectiveness. The higher accuracy and reduced feature set demonstrate the efficacy of machine learning, pointing to potential wider uses in medical diagnostics.
Article Title: Enhanced cardiovascular disease classification using the mayfly algorithm and real-time data

Abstract: Various methods have been introduced for restoring upper limb function in stroke patients, among which Motor Imagery-Based (MI-based) neurofeedback is highly effective, as it involves a complete cognitive process that ultimately leads to motor execution (ME). One of the impactful stages in MI-based EEG neurofeedback is the selection of EEG channels so that this small number of channels contains important information relevant to movement. It is preferable for these channels to have common features of both MI and ME. By considering this assumption in healthy subjects, it is possible to identify channels that can also be utilized in patients, leading to ME after treatment. Therefore, investigating the relationship between these two modalities can assist in selecting channels for neurofeedback treatment and provide a deeper understanding of the neural network mechanism underlying these motor activities. In this study, twelve effective connections, named SC, are selected using multivariate Granger causality (MVGC). They are obtained between subjects with a repetition threshold level of 80%, using EEG signal with 29 physiology-based channels of 109 healthy subjects from the Physionet dataset, during upper limb MI/ME. Subsequently, the MVGC values of ME are estimated using the corresponding MI values of the SCs through regression analysis. Finally, 4 of these SCs showed the best results in terms of R2 and rho (regression parameters) for estimated and observed MVGC values of ME, which led to the selection of 6 effective channels. In the following, the usefulness of these channels in left and right hand classification was also shown.
Article Title: A novel approach to EEG channel selection: Integrating physiological insights and the MI-ME relationship

Abstract: Paper-based electrocardiograms (ECGs) remain widely used in many hospitals and contain essential diagnostic information. When these ECGs are digitized through scanning, the resulting images are often high-noise gray-scale ECGs, making them difficult to use directly in intelligent diagnostic models. Traditional denoising approaches typically rely on ECG redrawing, which may alter the waveform and compromise diagnostic accuracy. To address this challenge, we propose a Noise Prediction-based ECG Denoising method (NPED), which directly removes noise from grayscale ECG images without redrawing the waveform. NPED is trained using an adversarial learning strategy to predict background noise and subtract it from the original image, thus preserving the true waveform structure. To evaluate the effectiveness of NPED, we constructed three datasets: a synthetic denoising dataset for training and testing denoising performance; a heart failure diagnostic dataset (HFDD) and an atrial fibrillation diagnostic dataset (AFDD) to assess the impact of denoising on diagnostic model performance. Experimental results show that NPED outperforms existing denoising methods across multiple metrics and enhances the performance of downstream diagnostic models, demonstrating its practical value in denoising paper-based ECGs.
Article Title: A noise prediction method for paper-based grayscale ECG denoising

Abstract: Patients routinely generate diverse clinical data, particularly radiological images and their corresponding reports. Integrating these heterogeneous modalities enhances diagnostic accuracy and facilitates the practical application of artificial intelligence in clinical settings. However, the complexity of medical tasks and the specificity of domain knowledge present challenges for deep learning models in effectively leveraging cross-modal information. To address this, we propose the Multi-Modal Multi-Scale Transformer Fusion (MMTF) model, which captures lesion features at multiple spatial scales through complementary cross-modal fusion mechanisms. To further align visual and textual representations, MMTF incorporates two generative tasks during training that help learn the underlying relationships between images and reports. Notably, even with minimal supervision, MMTF outperforms state-of-the-art pre-trained models on four benchmark X-ray datasets. Interpretability analyses show that MMTF accurately highlights lesion regions, supporting clinical decision-making and demonstrating strong potential for real-world deployment. The code is available on GitHub at https://github.com/GUESSZERO4/MMTF.git.
Article Title: Multi-modal multi-scale representation learning via cross-attention between chest radiology images and free-text reports

Abstract: Ultrasound imaging has become one of the primary methods for diagnosing breast cancer in women. The YOLOv9e network, a real-time algorithm balancing speed and accuracy, is widely used in breast imaging analysis requiring efficient processing. However, the YOLOv9e network suffers from a high parameter count and model complexity. To address this, we removed the original model's CBLinear and CBFuse modules, constructing a new lightweight network, YOLOv9-AGMA, to reduce computational resource consumption. Furthermore, this paper proposes a novel module, AGMA (Adaptive Gated Multi-scale Attention Module), to further enhance accuracy. This module dynamically adjusts the adaptive association of features across different scales after channel splitting in the original network. Integrated into the neck layer, it optimizes the feature representation capability for learning global contextual semantic information across spaces, thereby reducing information loss caused by unreasonable channel combinations and further improving precision. Secondly, a dense prediction-based Channel-Wise Knowledge Distillation (CWD) method is employed to enhance the model's robustness to noise, enabling the student network to learn key feature knowledge from the lesion foreground regions of the teacher network. Subsequently, the LayerCAM method is used for model introspection, enhancing the interpretability of AGMA's ability to precisely locate sensitive regions. Experimental results show that the model's precision is improved by 9.9%, while the proposed architecture has only 3.17% of the original model's parameter size and 3.81% of its model complexity, significantly reducing computational demands.
Article Title: YOLOv9-AGMA: An enhanced knowledge distillation network for breast ultrasound image classification

Abstract: Depression is a mental disorder that, if untreated, might lead to self-harm or suicidal thoughts. One of challenges that psychiatrists or neurologists face is selecting the best course of treatment for depression therapies. Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) and repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) are widely prescribed depression therapies. However, their response rate is only around 50%, which relatively low. In this study, a computer-aided decision (CAD) system is introduced to predict the effectiveness of depression therapies and recommend the most suitable treatment for depressed patients. The CAD system utilizes a novel feature extraction technique called nonlinear dynamical pattern of bits (NDPB), which is based on the nonlinear fusion of variations in the pattern of sixteen consecutive bits. The multichannel EEG signal is decomposed using a tuned Q-wavelet transform into its subbands, followed by the application of NDPB to the subbands to decode the hidden, complex, and nonlinear patterns in the EEG data. The neighborhood component analysis approach is employed to select the optimal set of features, and a feed-forward neural network is utilized for classification. The results indicate that the proposed CAD system achieves accuracy levels of 96.83% and 99.32% in predicting the outcomes of SSRI and rTMS depression therapies in a 10-fold cross validation strategy, respectively. Under a leave-one-subject-out cross-validation strategy, the CAD system also achieves outstanding accuracy levels of 99.00% and 95.65% for SSRI and rTMS therapies, respectively. The proposed CAD system might be utilized as a potential tool for neurologists in selecting the best course treatment for depression therapy.
Article Title: Predicting the outcome of depression therapies using a pattern of sixteen consecutive bits of EEG signals

Abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG) is vital in brain signal analysis, with mobile EEG (mo-EEG) extending its utility to movement scenarios. However, mo-EEG is highly susceptible to motion artifacts, degrading signal quality. This study introduces Motion-Net, a subject-specific CNN-based framework for removing motion artifacts from EEG signals. Unlike prior generalized or simulated approaches, Motion-Net is trained and tested separately per subject using real EEG recordings with ground-truth references. The model incorporates visibility graph (VG) features, providing structural information that improves performance with smaller datasets. Across three experimental setups, Motion-Net achieved an average motion artifact reduction percentage (eta) of 86% +/- 4.13, a SNR improvement of 20 +/- 4.47 dB, and a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 0.20 +/- 0.16. These results show that VG features enhance model learning and stability, and establish Motion-Net as the first subject-specific deep learning framework for robust motion artifact removal in mobile EEG.
Article Title: Motion Artifact Removal from EEG Signals Using the Motion-Net Deep Learning Algorithm

Abstract: Processing electrophysiological signals often necessitates blind source separation (BSS) due to the nature of mixing source signals. However, computational demands make real-time BSS challenging. Here, we develop an advanced, real-time BSS framework- constrained online recursive source separation (CORSS)-suitable for processing electrophysiological signals. In this framework, a stepwise recursive unmixing matrix learning rule, as the key of online recursive independent component analysis (ORICA), is adopted to enable real-time updates of the unmixing matrix with minimal computational cost. On this basis, a constrained ORICA (CORICA) module was further designed by incorporating prior information of target sources to optimize the cost function, thus rendering the separated signals more likely to converge to the target sources. To validate the performance of this framework, we applied it to both surface electromyogram (sEMG) decomposition task and respiratory intent monitoring task (separating weak diaphragmatic sEMG from strong electrocardiogram interferences). The CORSS method achieved a matching rate of 96.00 +/- 2.04 % and 98.12 +/- 1.21 % for both tasks, respectively, and it exhibited superior performance compared with other comparison methods (p < 0.05). Our method also yielded minimal time delay during computation, with only a delay of 12.5 ms when the input signal block size was set to 0.1 s. The CORSS method enables real-time BSS with both improved separation performance and low computational latency. Our work offers a valuable tool for real-time separation of meaningful electrophysiological sources towards their advanced processing and applications in the realm of neural-machine interaction and healthcare monitoring.
Article Title: Constrained online recursive source separation framework for Real-Time electrophysiological signal processing

Abstract: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a prevalent neurodegenerative disorder characterized by progressive memory loss and cognitive decline, and achieving disease-stage classification can facilitate timely medical intervention. The purpose of this study is to develop an effective deep learning-based approach for AD diagnosis. To achieve this, we propose a novel deep learning framework that integrates multi-task learning and multi-modal data for AD diagnosis. Our method employs a multi-task architecture in which a segmentation branch performs gray matter segmentation as an auxiliary task to improve feature extraction and reduce overfitting. Meanwhile, the classification branch is designed to achieve multi-modal fusion by jointly processing structural Magnetic Resonance Imaging (sMRI) data and clinical data: it extracts multi-scale features from sMRI and encodes clinical data using specialized methods, and then integrates both types of information through a multi-modal feature fusion module to complete the classification. Extensive experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves competitive diagnostic accuracy, reaching 96.43% and 86.10% on the AD vs. CN (Cognitively Normal) and MCI (Mild Cognitive Impairment) vs. CN tasks, respectively, and 71.87% on the AD vs. MCI vs. CN task. In conclusion, our framework shows strong potential as an effective tool for AD diagnosis, thereby supporting timely clinical intervention.
Article Title: An integrated multi-modal and multi-task learning method for Alzheimer's disease diagnosis

Abstract: Airway segmentation plays a critical role in medical image analysis. However, existing airway segmentation methods still face numerous challenges. Traditional U-Net models often suffer from the loss of high-frequency information in deeper layers due to continuous pooling operations in the encoding phase, making it difficult to preserve fine structural details accurately. Moreover, the local receptive field characteristic of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) limits their ability to capture long-range dependencies in the complex topology of the airways, hindering the model's ability to understand the global shape and distribution of the airways. Additionally, the class imbalance between large and small airways poses a persistent challenge that affects segmentation performance. These issues lead to lower airway recognition accuracy and incomplete airway topology in the segmentation results. To address these challenges, this study proposes an innovative airway segmentation method that integrates wavelet transform and cross attention mechanisms. First, wavelet transform is used to extract high-frequency features, and a Frequency Cross Attention (FCA) module based on Transformer is designed to model long-range dependencies, deeply integrating high-frequency features with the implicit encoding features of U-Net. Finally, a Balance loss function is introduced to alleviate the class imbalance problem through a weighted strategy. Experimental results on the ATM'22 challenge dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a Detected Length Rate (DLR) of 95.61%, a Detected Branch Rate (DBR) of 90.86%, and a Precision of 0.9849. Compared to current state-of-the-art methods, the proposed approach outperforms in key metrics. Code is available here: https://github.com/zzthaoshuai/WaTER.
Article Title: WaTER: Leveraging wavelet transform and transformer-based cross attention for airway segmentation from CT images

Abstract: Biomedical images play a crucial role in clinical diagnosis, patient detection and management. Traditional medical image classification methods usually rely on manual feature extraction, which is difficult to capture complex image features. Moreover, some traditional algorithms are computationally inefficient and have long processing time when dealing with large-scale medical image data. Given the limitations of traditional methods, deep learning, especially convolutional neural networks (CNNs), has become a powerful tool for modern medical image classification. By automatically learning image features, convolutional neural networks can significantly improve the classification accuracy and efficiently process complex medical image data. Despite the excellent performance of convolutional neural networks in medical image classification, their computational resource requirements are still high. To address this problem, we propose a novel model, a quantum-inspired medical scalable convolutional neural network (MSQCNN). The MSQCNN system consists of a number of smallscale quantum devices to achieve full utilization of quantum resources and alleviate the present-day difficulty of preparing large quantum computers. We train this network on an image dataset containing chest radiographs and benchmark its performance. Compared with other benchmark models, our model performs even better. MSQCNN not only achieves an average accuracy of 97.71% on the test set, but also obtains an F1-score of 98.46%, an AUC value of 99.47%, a recall of 98.43%, and a precision of 98.50%. Moreover, we conclude that MSQCNN models have excellent resilience to noise by numerical simulations.
Article Title: A quantum-inspired medical scalable convolutional neural network for Intelligent pneumonia diagnosis

Abstract: Higher-Order Interaction (HOI) theory offers a powerful framework for capturing complex, non-linear relationships within multidimensional systems, moving beyond traditional pairwise graph methods to encompass multi-way interactions. This study applies HOI analysis, specifically using hypergraph theory, to explore intricate connectivity patterns in electrophysiological signals from neuroscience. Hypergraphs were constructed from connectivity data across various frequency bands, characterized through metrics such as spectral entropy, hyperedge centrality, and vertex centrality, and compared using spectral and centrality distance measures. Three distinct neurophysiological datasets were analyzed: intracranial EEG signals from rats during different sleep stages, scalp EEG data to distinguish between epilepsy types, and MEG recordings of seizure dynamics. The findings highlight the effectiveness of hypergraph-based HOI analysis in mapping neural dynamics across normal and pathological brain states. In sleep studies, it reveals distinct connectivity patterns between REM and NREM stages, while in epilepsy, it differentiates seizure types and stages, identifying spectral entropy as a potential marker for seizure onset. Notably, HOI analysis captures differences between primary and secondary generalized epilepsy, suggesting enhanced diagnostic accuracy. This approach provides a powerful tool for understanding complex neural interactions in high-dimensional data.
Article Title: Higher-order interaction analysis via hypergraph models for studying multidimensional neuroscience data

Abstract: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (PAF) detection based on routine electrocardiogram (ECG) signals is still one of the most challenging problems in research community, since non-episodic ECG fails to diagnose PAF. In this paper, a new PAF detection algorithm based on non-episodic ECG data using multi-dimensional feature representation and learning is proposed. Mean amplitude spectrum (MAS), mel-frequency cepstrum coefficients (MFCC), wavelet packet features (WPFS) and statistical wavelet packet features (SFS) are derived and represented as multi-dimensional image features. These four kinds of cardiac time frequency representations reflect dynamical characteristics during heart beating from four different aspects, which has shown to be more sensitive to detect latent PAF even before visible ECG pathologic changes can be observed. The extracted cardiac representations and deep learning technique are then incorporated, and a parallel DenseNet based feature learning scheme are proposed. Deep features underlying these four kinds of cardiac representations are fused on the decision level to improve classification performance. The appearing ECG test signals can be finally classified according to the min rule based decision-making principle. Experimental results show that accuracies of 81.66%, 85.41%, and 91.25% are achieved on PHY-PAF EEG database under two-fold, five-fold, and ten-fold cross-validations, respectively.
Article Title: Detection of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation from non-episodic ECG data using multi-dimensional feature representation and learning

Abstract: Background and Objective: The development of assistive technology has enabled people with disabilities live more independent and fulfilling lives. One such technology leverages the concept of silent speech assist individuals with speech disabilities, enhancing their ability to communicate. The emerging field of silent speech technology includes cutting-edge techniques for interpreting and converting non-vocalized speech clues into clear communication. Due to its potential to change communication for those with speech difficulties enabling them to express their thoughts and ideas without vocalization, silent speech technology has gained popularity. This technology can close the gap between silent intents and meaningful expression by utilizing neural signals, muscular movements, and other physiological cues. This technology can have a transformative impact on enhancing communication accessibility and redefining conventional speech interfaces. This paper aims to build a speech synthesizer for the Hindi language to determine silently articulated words by proposing classification model that learns from Surface Electromyography (sEMG) data and predicts the words articulated with acceptable accuracy. Methods: We proposed the ConVbi framework that combines the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (biLSTM) for the precise recognition of Hindi words in the developed silent speech dataset by extracting temporal, frequency and local structure features. We created a novel dataset of 10,166 recordings for silent speech Hindi words after getting it pre-processed that act as input for the proposed framework that transcribe silently articulated words or phrases in real-time by patients with functional dysphonia. Results: We conducted extensive experiments and evaluated the performance of the proposed framework both quantitatively and qualitatively. The experimental results demonstrate an accuracy of 98.72%, average precision of 98%, recall with 98% value and F1 score value of 98% that confirms the versatility of the ConVbi comparison to the other traditional deep learning approaches. Conclusion: The proposed framework is designed for an automatic silent speech recognition system Hindi words utilizing electromyographic signals, neuromuscular movements, and deep learning models. Given the lack of a public dataset, a new dataset was created, pre-processed for feature extraction, and used high-accuracy word classification.
Article Title: ConVbi-Ensemble deep learning based silent speech detection for dysphonia patients from electromyographic signals

Abstract: Retinal vessel segmentation is an essential step in the early diagnosis of ophthalmic diseases. However, due to the complexity of the vascular tree structure, the imbalance of vessels at different scales, the loss of information in low-contrast regions, and noise interference, achieving accurate segmentation remains a challenge. To this end, this paper proposes a Dual-Layer Semantic Fusion Network for Retinal Vessel Segmentation (DSFN-Net), which improves segmentation accuracy and the connectivity of small vessels through multi-level feature enhancement and a cross-stage attention mechanism. Specifically, we propose an enhanced convolution dual-layer semantic fusion network to strengthen the extraction of both local and global vessel features; optimize the encoder structure by introducing hierarchical feature fusion to alleviate the imbalance in vessel information extraction at different scales; design a cross-stage fusion attention mechanism to enhance vessel extraction in low-contrast regions; and employ a multi-level semantic fusion module to enhance the complementarity of features across different layers, thereby improving vessel connectivity and microvessel segmentation performance. Experimental results show that on the DRIVE, CHASE_DB1, and STARE datasets, DSFN-Net achieves F1-scores of 83.2%, 82.06%, and 84.78%, respectively, and ACC values of 97.11%, 97.64%, and 97.66%, while demonstrating strong generalization capability in cross-validation. Source code is available at https://github.com/Lrsm-sudo/DSFN_et.
Article Title: A Dual-Layer Semantic Fusion Network for Retinal Vessel Segmentation

Abstract: Radiology report generation plays a vital role in computer-aided diagnosis, serving as a bridge between medical image interpretation and clinical decision-making. Although attention-based methods have shown promising results, they often fail to effectively capture global context, potentially leading to the omission of subtle yet clinically significant findings. Furthermore, Transformer-based frameworks frequently suffer from high computational complexity, which hinders their deployment in clinical environments. Additionally, existing approaches incorporating disease labels via multi-label classification are typically limited to binary outputs, failing to model disease severity and inter-symptom dependencies. To tackle the aforementioned challenges, we introduce a novel framework for automated radiology report generation that integrates graph-guided disease-symptom modeling with multi-level context fusion. Our approach introduces a graph-structured topic classifier that explicitly captures semantic correlations among disease-related topics. To improve efficiency and modeling capacity, we replace the traditional Transformer encoder with a Mamba-based encoder, which better captures long-range dependencies and ambiguous pathological features. Furthermore, a multi-level context fusion decoder is proposed to proficiently combine global and local visual representations for accurate and coherent report generation. Extensive evaluations on the IU-Xray and MIMIC-CXR benchmark datasets reveal that our approach reliably surpasses state-of-the-art baselines in both natural language generation and clinical efficacy metrics. Notably, our model achieves relative improvements of 3.68% (precision), 3.80% (recall), and 3.88% (F1-score) in Clinical Efficacy (CE) metrics, highlighting its strong potential for practical deployment in medical reporting applications.
Article Title: Graph-guided topic modeling and multi-level context-aware framework for automated radiology report generation

Abstract: To achieve an accurate registration of brain medical image, we propose a multi-scale registration architecture called MCANet, which enables the perception of both local and global anatomical structural information. First, to effectively capture local features of brain structures at different scales, three different convolutions are adopted to extract different types of features, including fine-grained features, lightweight channel features and large-scale contextual information. To further establish the global dependencies of deep features, Swin Transformer is embedded into the bottleneck module. Finally, the deformation field can be accurately estimated by comprehensively utilizing global and local features. Extensive experimental results on the OASIS, LPBA40, and IXI MRI brain datasets show that our model achieves an average improvement in registration accuracy of over 5.68%, 2.4%, and 6.69%, respectively. This confirms the effectiveness and advancement of our model.
Article Title: MCANet: Hybrid multi-scale network for deformable brain medical image registration

Abstract: Vascular interventional surgical robots have shown great potential to achieve more precise and stable surgeries, yet their assistance is limited as they are fully controlled by surgeons. To enable more intelligent and efficient robotic surgery, it is crucial for machines to understand the surgical scene from intraoperative X-ray images. However, this task faces several challenges. Firstly, interventional instruments are difficult to distinguish due to their similar appearance and elongated structures. Secondly, most existing methods focus on endoscopic videos with higher resolution and clearer instruments, while ignoring the noisy X-ray images. Lastly, unlike humans, current approaches lack the confidence assessment of predicted results, reducing the reliability of intelligent systems. In this paper, we propose an evidential surgical scene understanding network (Evi-SSUNet) to achieve accurate and reliable scene understanding. This multi-task network performs both surgical step recognition and target instrument segmentation. To enhance the reliability of step recognition, we introduce a confidence estimation (CE) module based on evidential deep learning to assess the confidence of the predictions and improve performance by constraining uncertainty. Moreover, we design a confidence-gated class attention (CCA) module that generates a dynamic class attention map related to specific surgical steps, which helps highlight target locations for more precise segmentation. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our Evi-SSUNet surpasses other state-of-the-art methods in classification, segmentation, and multi-task learning, providing a significant advancement in the development of intelligent and trusted surgical robots for vascular interventions.
Article Title: Evi-SSUNet: A multi-task network for reliable surgical scene understanding in X-ray images

Abstract: Background: Core body temperature (CBT) plays a pivotal role in determining the prognosis of patients with neurological impairments. This study aimed to develop and evaluate a machine learning (ML) algorithm capable of forecasting CBT, as well as predicting fever and hypothermia, several hours in advance. Methods: We conducted a multicenter retrospective observational study in three mixed intensive care units (ICUs): two university hospitals in France (Hopital de la Timone and Nord), and one teaching military hospital in France (Sainte-Anne). We evaluated several prediction methods, including Neural Networks, Gradient Boosting, Random Forests, linear regression models, LSTM, and XGBoost. Inputs consisted of past temperature measurements, blood pressure, heart rate, and time of day. Results: Data from 10,189 ICU patients were analyzed. A training cohort (n = 5,146) from two ICUs was used to develop the models, and an independent evaluation cohort (n = 5,043) from the third ICU was used for testing. XGBoost consistently demonstrated the highest predictive performance for both fever and hypothermia. Sensitivity for fever (and hypothermia) prediction was 93.2 % (90.2 %) at 1 h, 86.6 % (82.3 %) at 2 h, and 76.8 % (70.3 %) at 4 h. Prediction of CBT values yielded Root Mean Square Errors of 0.19 degrees C, 0.31 degrees C, and 0.46 degrees C at 1, 2, and 4 h, respectively. Conclusion: This is the first large multicenter study to evaluate the contribution of ML to CBT prediction in ICU patients. Our findings show that fever and hypothermia can be reliably detected up to four hours before their occurrence, paving the way for more proactive and personalized patient management.
Article Title: Early prediction of fever and hypothermia in adult ICU patients using machine learning: A multicenter study

Abstract: Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by gradual deterioration of the neurological system that impairs cognitive and physical skills. Early detection is critical to management. Neurodegenerative diseases provide obstacles due to their progressive nature, unknown origins and difficulty in early detection. In this Manuscript, early diagnosis of neurodegenerative diseases using temporal inductive path neural network in medical imaging (NDD-TIPNN) is proposed. Initially, the input images are collected from the Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's Progression (ADPP) dataset. The collected images are then processed using Confidence Partitioning Sampling Filtering (CPSF) to remove image artifacts. The pre-processed image is subsequently fed into the Temporal Inductive Path Neural Network (TIPNN) for the classification of neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's, Alzheimer's and Healthy control. Generally, TIPNN does not show adopting optimization approaches to define the weight domains needed for accurate classification. Therefore, the Secretary Bird Optimization Algorithm (SBOA) is used to optimize the weight parameter of TIPNN which accurately classifies neurodegenerative diseases. The proposed NDD-TIPNN approach contains 99.19% higher accuracy, 99.43% higher sensitivity and 99.23% higher precision related to existing methods, like Spatially informed Bayesian neural network for neurodegenerative diseases classification (SBNN-NDC), Comparative analysis of machine learning algorithms for multi-syndrome classification of neurodegenerative syndromes (CNS-SVM) and Neurodegenerative diseases-Caps: a capsule network based early screening system for the classification of neurodegenerative diseases (CND-CNN) respectively. These results suggest that the proposed approach offers a highly effective and computationally efficient solution for the early diagnosis of neurodegenerative diseases, with a potential impact on clinical decision support systems.
Article Title: Early diagnosis of neurodegenerative diseases using temporal inductive path neural network in medical imaging

Abstract: The teacher-student network is a useful learning method and has been increasingly applied to fulfill semi-supervised medical image segmentation. However, in the face of the limited labeled data and a large amount of unlabeled data, how to adequately consider the discrepancy between teacher and student networks, as well as greatly guarantee their consistency through learning, is always a big challenge. To overcome this challenge, a so-called Competitive Grouped teacher-student Network (CGTS-Net) is proposed, which integrates the stability of pseudo-label generation in the conventional mean teacher framework with the discrepancy learning through a cross-network correction mechanism. Specifically, the CGTS-Net adopts a dual-branch network architecture, where each subnet group maintains the quality of the pseudo labels of the teacher network within the group through the exponential moving average method. Between groups, a dynamic competition strategy is developed for cross-group knowledge transfer, that is, the teacher network from the better-performing subnet group provides pseudo-supervision signals to the student network of the other group. To alleviate the distribution shift between labeled and unlabeled data, a cross-group and copy-paste enhancement strategy is proposed, which dynamically merges the real labels and pseudo-labeled data from the dual-branch network, effectively mitigating the distribution discrepancy. For the purpose of tackling the widespread boundary ambiguity in medical images, an edge-aware consistency loss function is designed to enhance the prediction consistency of segmentation boundaries, improving the model's ability to discern fine structures. Finally, experiments conducted on four datasets (LA, Pancreas, KiTS, and LiTS) show that the proposed CGTS-Net method outperforms current state-of-the-art semi-supervised learning methods in both segmentation accuracy and boundary prediction ability.
Article Title: CGTS-Net: Competitive grouped teacher-student network for semi-supervised medical image segmentation

Abstract: Allergen immunotherapy (AIT) is an effective treatment for allergic rhinitis (AR); however, some patients do not respond optimally. This study aims to identify the factors influencing the efficacy of subcutaneous specific immunotherapy (SCIT) for AR in children and to develop a predictive model for treatment outcomes using machine learning techniques. Data were collected from 272 children aged 4-15 years with AR, excluding those with asthma, who underwent more than three years of mite SCIT at two hospitals in southern Zhejiang. Patients were categorized into effective and ineffective groups based on the improvement in the Combined Symptom Medication Score (CSMS) before and after treatment. The data were split into a training set and a testing set, and the bIRSCA algorithm was applied to identify optimal feature subsets in the training set. The selected features were then used in a support vector machine (SVM) model to assess performance on the testing set, with ten-fold cross-validation applied to evaluate the model. The final results were based on the average performance metrics across ten iterations. The bIRSCA-SVM model identified key biomarkers, including the sIgE/tIgE (Der p) ratio, sIgE (Der p), eosinophil count, eosinophil ratio, and the sIgE/tIgE (Der f) ratio, as significant predictors of therapeutic efficacy. The model achieved an accuracy of 88.992 %, sensitivity of 99.736 %, and specificity of 86.872 %, outperforming other models. In conclusion, a positive response to SCIT is associated with baseline levels of the identified biomarkers. The bIRSCA-SVM model provides an effective and accurate method for predicting the efficacy of mite SCIT in children with allergic rhinitis.
Article Title: The efficacy prediction of subcutaneous immunotherapy for pediatric allergic Rhinitis: Application of machine learning methods

Abstract: Super-resolution reconstruction of CT images is essential for enhancing diagnostic accuracy while minimizing radiation exposure. Although deep learning has recently shown great promise in this field, current methods still face key challenges: transformer-based models often achieve high-quality reconstruction but suffer from high computational cost due to their quadratic time complexity, while CNN-based models, lacking global context modeling, struggle to deliver satisfactory image quality. To address these limitations, we propose a novel CT image super-resolution framework called MambaCT, which introduces the Mamba state space model into this domain. Leveraging Mamba's linear time complexity and inherent global attention capabilities, we design two core modules: the State Space Module (SSM), which uses a lightweight asymmetric dual-branch architecture for efficient long-range dependency modeling, and the State Space Block (SSB), which integrates SSM and convolution operations within a dual-path residual framework to flexibly fuse local and global features. Experimental results demonstrate that MambaCT achieves state-of-the-art performance across multiple public datasets. Specifically, on the ADNI-4C dataset at x4 scale, it achieves the largest PSNR improvement of 1.60% over the second-best method. On the COVID-CT dataset at x3 scale, it yields the highest SSIM improvement of 1.61% and the greatest LPIPS reduction of 20.5%. Moreover, due to its linear complexity, MambaCT significantly reduces runtime and memory usage. For an input size of 120, GPU memory consumption is only 9.6 GB, which is 1.2 GB less than SRFBN and significantly lower than the transformer-based ViT-B model. This makes the method practical for deployment in resource-constrained clinical environments.
Article Title: MambaCT: A Mamba-based method for super-resolution of CT images

Abstract: Medical image fusion is essential for merging functional metabolic data and structural tissue properties, which are exceptionally difficult to record in a single image because of intrinsic sensor constraints. Through the provision of more comprehensive images, this fusion improves healthcare diagnosis and patient care. Despite the widespread usage of deep learning-based methods, their inability to simultaneously learn long-range and shortrange interdependence impairs fusion capabilities. This study introduces new hybrid multimodal healthcare image fusion system that combines Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with Swin Transformer (ST) architectures to tackle this issue and improved feature representation. In addition, a new PCA-based block is shown to choose high-gradient features, therefore enhancing image quality and generating better fusion results with 6% fewer feature component. An attention-based fusion technique guarantees the best combination of diverse characteristics from different modalities of healthcare imaging. The proposed method outperforms all existing comparison models with the lowest mean metric error score of 9.99. It outperforms current benchmark approaches by a minimum of 2.25%. Furthermore, the system is robust and reliable, as evidenced by statistical testing and Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) approaches. The stability of our model guarantees a substantial enhancement in diagnostic accuracy, making it a priceless asset for the healthcare industry, especially for radiologists and physicians.
Article Title: Optimal feature selection for medical image fusion using deep learning with transformer

Abstract: Estimating brain age through structural Magnetic Resonance Images (sMRI) and comparing the estimated age with chronological age can help identify abnormal brain aging. This study employed transfer learning to address challenges of processing large datasets and high computational costs. To improve performance, following preprocessing, 3D volumes of Gray Matter (GM) and White Matter (WM), Jacobian map, and registered T1-weighted slices were obtained from sMRI and used in the transfer learning of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model with the residual basic architecture. The most accurate brain age estimation was achieved by combining WM and registered T1-weighted slices using Elastic Network regression, where the Mean Absolute Error and Coefficient of Determination were 1.82 and 0.97 in the IXI dataset, and 3.61 and 0.74 in the OASIS4 dataset, respectively. The registered T1-weighted slices of healthy people was also used in the transfer learning of the CNN model with residual basic architecture; then, the error of measurement of the brain age estimation of the healthy and epileptic people, and the sensitivity map of the model in the brain age estimation were extracted. The trained model could estimate the age of the epileptic people with a positive difference of 33 % more than that of the chronological age of the healthy people; the mean error of brain age estimation in the epileptic people was estimated to be 2.77 years more than that of the healthy ones. The temporal lobe was observed to be the most critical brain region for age estimation in the proposed CNN-based model.
Article Title: T1-weighted structural Magnetic Resonance Images-driven brain age estimation in epileptic patients using convolutional neural networks

Abstract: Medical Visual Question Answering (Med-VQA) aims to provide answers to clinical questions based on medical images, offering support in diagnostic decision-making. However, most existing methods frame this task as a classification problem, limiting outputs to predefined answers and lacking the ability to model complex, interpretable reasoning. In this work, we redefine Med-VQA as a conditional generative task and present DiffuVQA, a novel diffusion-based model that generates open-ended answers conditioned on multimodal information. DiffuVQA introduces two key strategies to enhance reasoning and contextual grounding. First, fused image-question features are embedded as conditional signals in the reverse diffusion process to guide answer generation. Second, to address the bias of reverse-only conditioning, we propose Conditional Information Gaussian Noising, which integrates the fused features into the forward process, enabling dual conditioning without altering the diffusion model's probabilistic structure. Extensive experiments on three public Med-VQA datasets show that DiffuVQA achieves state-of-the-art performance compared to existing generative approaches, demonstrating superior flexibility, accuracy, and interpretability. Code is available at https://github.com/ cloneiq/DiffuVQA.
Article Title: Redefining medical visual question answering using conditional generative diffusion models

Abstract: Fine-grained assessment of individual attention states from EEG is crucial for advancing BCI applications in complex cognitive settings. To address the limited cross-paradigm generalization of existing models, we propose a classification framework that fuses temporal, spectral and spatial features. The temporal branch (MSA-CTN) employs an improved deformable temporal-block encoder combined with multi-head self-attention to capture dynamic sequence patterns. The spatial-spectral branch (Spline-CBAM KANResNet) extracts power spectral density via Welch's method, maps it to electrode positions, and leverages spline-enhanced attention within a ResNet augmented by KANLinear to mine joint spectral-spatial representations.
