Finally, a learnable decision-level weighting scheme integrates outputs from both branches for collaborative inference. We evaluate our approach on two EEG benchmarks: Dataset1 (short dictation task) and Dataset2 (prolonged simulated-driving task). Ten-fold cross-validation yields classification accuracies of 91.53% and 88.47%, respectively-outperforming state-of-the-art methods. Band-contribution analysis further confirms that mid-to-high frequencies (alpha/beta) predominantly govern both transient and sustained attention, validating the efficacy and physiological consistency of our multi-domain fusion approach.
Article Title: EEG-based attention state classification via multi-domain feature fusion

Abstract: Purpose: Early diagnosis of cardiac ischemia using Electrocardiogram (ECG) signals plays a crucial role in reducing cardiovascular disease burden and improving patient outcomes. This study aims to advance ischemia detection by integrating advanced feature extraction and selection strategies to enhance both classification accuracy and efficiency. Method: Two public ECG datasets were employed: the Fantasia dataset (healthy subjects) and the European ST-T dataset (ischemic patients). A comprehensive set of classical features-including statistical, frequency, time-frequency, and temporal descriptors-was extracted, alongside deep learning-based features derived from Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN). To address the challenge of selecting the most informative features, we introduce a novel Self-Organizing Map (SOM)-based feature selection method and benchmark it against Principal Component Analysis (PCA), t-test, and wrapper-based techniques. Classification performance was evaluated using multiple machine learning models, including Support Vector Machine (SVM), Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA), Gaussian Na & iuml;ve Bayes (NB), and Logistic Regression (LR). Statistical tests were also conducted to assess the discriminative strength of the selected features. Result: Experimental results demonstrate that RNN-based feature extraction achieved the highest classification accuracy (99.4%), followed by CNN (98.4%). The SOM-based feature selection method consistently outperformed PCA, t-test, and wrapper methods across all classifiers, producing more effective and robust models. Among classifiers, SVM delivered the best performance. Statistical analyses confirmed the superiority of SOM, yielding the lowest p-values across feature categories. Conclusion: These findings highlight the value of combining deep neural network-based feature extraction with SOM-driven feature selection, offering a reliable and efficient framework for intelligent, real-time cardiac ischemia diagnosis.
Article Title: A Hybrid Approach for Early Diagnosis of Cardiac Ischemia from Electrocardiogram Signal: Combining Classical and Deep Learning-Based Features

Abstract: Accurate polyp segmentation is paramount for the diagnosis and treatment of colon cancer. However, the varying shapes and sizes of polyps and the low contrast with the surrounding tissue make polyp segmentation a challenging task. To tackle these challenges and achieve better segmentation performance, in this article we propose a multi-scale perception and global-local attention fusion network (MPGF-Net) for polyp segmentation. MPGF-Net consists of three novel modules: a multi-scale boundary perception module (MBP), a pyramid feature extraction module (PFE), and a global-local attention fusion module (GAF). Specifically, the MBP module, which is embedded at the skip connections, efficiently extracts global context information and multi-scale local context information by employing parallel multi-scale dilated convolutions and parallel pooling operations. The PFE module, designed at the junction between the encoder and decoder, can explore the multi-scale local context information further and pass its output to the decoder layer. The GAF module can adaptively select and fuse local and global context information, enhancing attention to important features through attention mechanisms. Leveraging top-down deep supervision, our MPGF-Net achieves coarse-to-fine polyp segmentation and ultimately pinpoints polyp regions. Extensive experiment results on Kvasir-SEG, EndoTect and CVC-ClinicDB datasets demonstrate that MPGF-Net outperforms state-of-the-art methods on several assessment metrics.
Article Title: MPGF-Net: A multi-scale perception and global-local attention fusion network for polyp segmentation

Abstract: Brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) provide an innovative communication method for individuals with language disorders. Current speech imagery BCI systems primarily focus on the classification of syllables and words, but still fail to achieve effective brain-to-text generation. Furthermore, existing BCI technologies often rely on invasive methods to record neural activity during imagined handwriting, which presents technical and ethical challenges that limit their widespread application. To address this issue, we propose a brain-to-text generation method based on imagined speech electroencephalography (EEG) signals, which integrates a time warping model with hidden Markov model (TH) for labeling and a long short-term memory (LSTM)-Transformer network for decoding, collectively referred to as Hybrid TH-LSTM-Transformer. First, we established datasets of character and sentence containing 26 lowercase letters and 3 common punctuation marks (",", "." and ">"), verifying the separability of 29 characters to tackle the incompleteness of imagined speech during text generation. Second, we developed the TH labeling module, which generates character templates via the time warping model and labels the corresponding neural activity using the hidden Markov model. Finally, we introduced the LSTM-Transformer decoding network, which leverages LSTM's capability to handle variable-length character information and the Transformer's advantage in capturing long-range dependencies to generate text from EEG signals. The experimental results indicate that the average character precision of the generated sentences reaches 77.82%.
Article Title: A hybrid TH-LSTM-Transformer Model for text generation from EEG signals during imagined character speech

Abstract: Accurate and timely classification of brain tumors from magnetic resonance (MR) images is crucial for improving patient outcomes and treatment planning. However, manual diagnosis can be time-consuming and prone to errors due to subtle differences between tumor types. To address this issue, CNN-based brain tumor classification methods have been widely adopted in automatic diagnostic systems. Unlike most conventional linearly stacked single-branched architectures, which struggle to capture multiscale features effectively and preserve spatial information, we propose MDFE-Net, a novel multiscale dense feature extraction CNN for multiclass brain tumor classification. A multiscale dense feature fusion (MDFF) module containing specially designed Multiscale Feature Extraction (MFE) blocks is incorporated to capture multi-level features at various receptive field sizes while mitigating spatial detail loss through dense connections. Additionally, a global feature extraction attention (GFEA) module is introduced to enhance both channel-wise and position-wise representations via parallel dual attention mechanisms. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that MDFE-Net outperformed 24 state-of-the-art methods, including classical CNN architectures (EfficientNetB0, VGG-16, ResNet-50, InceptionV3), recent attention-based and multiscale CNNs, and vision transformers, achieving accuracies of 97.23 % and 98.17 % on CE-MRI and BTMD datasets, respectively. Significantly, this superior performance was achieved with only 10.04 M parameters, fewer than competing methods (20-160 M parameters), making it highly suitable for clinical deployment. Ablation studies validated the effectiveness of the MDFF and GFEA modules, demonstrating a practical and efficient solution for automated brain tumor diagnosis from MR images. Our model and code can be found at https://github.com/WU-HAOTIAN34/MDFE-Net.
Article Title: MDFE-Net: Multiscale dense feature extraction CNN for brain tumor classification from MRIs

Abstract: Coronary angiography remains the main diagnostic tool for coronary artery disease (CAD), the world's leading cause of death. The severity of CAD is determined by the site, extent of narrowing (stenosis), and the number of affected arteries. This paper presents a 2D Swin UNETR architecture for automated coronary artery stenosis detection in XCA images, employing fine-tuning and adapter-tuning strategies to optimize accuracy and computational efficiency. The model integrates binary segmentation as a pre-processing step and small segment elimination as post-processing to enhance precision, with label smoothing applied during training to reduce overfitting and improve generalization. The 2D Swin UNETR model demonstrated superior performance compared to existing models ,achieving a Dice score of 0.5375 with fine-tuning and 0.5519 with adapter-tuning, offering greater computational efficiency and accuracy in detecting stenoses and segmenting coronary arteries, making it suitable for clinical use.
Article Title: Stenosis detection of coronary arteries in X-ray angiography images using Swin UNETR with self-supervised pre-training approach and PEFT strategy

Abstract: Breast cancer analysis is vital for women's health, directly affecting mortality rates. Mammography, the most reliable diagnostic method, can be subject to inaccuracies due to manual interpretation by radiologists. Digital mammograms, along with computer-aided diagnostic (CAD) systems, improve diagnostic accuracy by reducing false positives and increasing survival rates. This research proposes an enhanced method for mammogram classification in breast cancer detection using an Optimized Explicit Feature Interaction Aware Graph Neural Network (EFIAGNN-LWO). Initially, the input image is gathered from the Curated Breast Imaging Subset of Digital Database for Screening Mammography (CBIS-DDSM) dataset. The image undergoes pre-processing with an Adaptive Two-Stage Unscented Kalman Filter (ATUKF) to improve contrast, reduce noise, and improve histogram distribution in low-contrast mammograms. The preprocessed images are fed to the Multi-Hypothesis Fuzzy-Matching Radon Transform (MHFMRT) to extract texture features. These features are then passed to the Explicit Feature Interaction Aware Graph Neural Network (EFIAGNN), which classifies the mammograms as benign or malignant. The method is further optimized using Leaf in Wind Optimization (LWO) to improve classification accuracy. The proposed method is implemented in Python, achieving better performance with a F1 score of 97.33 %, precision of 99.39 %, an accuracy of 99.20 %, an and a sensitivity of 99.80 %. The proposed method shows notable recall improvements over existing methods like Inception-V4, Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM), DenseNet121, and attaining 98.23 % for benign instances and 99.01 % for malignant cases. The model also achieves a reduced computational time of 61 s, enabling quicker diagnosis and more efficient decision-making in clinical environments.
Article Title: Enhancing diagnostic precision and mammogram classification in breast cancer detection utilizing an optimized Explicit Feature Interaction Aware Graph Neural Network

Abstract: Recent advances in machine and deep learning have significantly enhanced the automatic classification of medical images, particularly in brain tumor detection. Despite the high accuracy achieved by deep neural networks, current methods often struggle with misclassification and require extensive computational resources and training time. To address these challenges, this study proposes a novel brain tumor classification model, RAET, which integrates a rejection recognition mechanism with deep fusion of ResNet, attention-enhanced EfficientNetb0, and Transformer modules. The model comprises three key components: a feature extraction module that employs ResNet and attention mechanisms to optimize EfficientNet-b0, a deep fusion module that leverages deep fully-connected layers and a Transformer to integrate and refine extracted features, and a rejection recognition mechanism that classifies images only when confidence scores exceed a preset threshold, thereby excluding uncertain cases. Evaluated on two brain tumor datasets (A and B) and compared with 20 representative deep learning models, RAET achieved accuracies of 99.07% and 96.56% on datasets A and B, representing improvements of 6.28% and 3.54% over the best-performing alternatives. Furthermore, applying a confidence threshold above 99.60% allowed RAET to classify 96.98% of images in dataset A and 91.04% in dataset B with 100% accuracy among accepted cases, ensuring that over 90% of the images are classified with complete reliability. The experimental results demonstrate that RAET reduces fusion process complexity through model optimization, while achieving excellent and reliable classification performance. The proposed RAET model offers a promising solution for clinical applications, ensuring robust performance under constrained computational resources and scalability.
Article Title: Rejection recognition deep fusion method of ResNet-attention-EfficientNet-b0-Transformer for brain tumor classification

Abstract: Despite significant advancements in technology, cancer diseases remain a formidable global health challenge, necessitating effective diagnostic and prognostic methodologies of biomedical image analysis. The objective of this paper was to develop machine learning-based computer-assisted techniques for cancer diseases. By leveraging technological advancements, this method facilitates early detection and management of cancer conditions, which is critical for improving patient outcomes via biomedical image processing. In this study a novel methodology for developing an interpretable Computer-Assisted Medical Diagnosis System (CAMDS) for cancer disease detection by biomedical image analysis through two steps: In the first step, we use a new image feature extraction technique by proposing two new sets of orthogonal moments, are respectively called, the orthogonal Rademacher-Fourier moments (RFMs) for gray-scale biomedical images and the quaternion orthogonal Rademacher-Fourier moments (QRFMs) for color biomedical images. In the second step, we use DNN deep learning method for image recognition and prediction. The experimental results confirm the superiority of our proposed method CAMDS, demonstrating its potential as a powerful tool for the automatic classification of biomedical images. Also, with RFMs or QRFMs, our models achieved a high accuracy image recognition accuracy of 100% for the three datasets, precision of 98.98%, recall of 98.67%, accuracy of 99.56%, and F1-Score of 97.27%. This approach not only enhances the accuracy of cancerous disease diagnostics but also offers a robust framework for recognizing complex and nonlinear characteristics of serious illnesses data, promising significant contributions to clinical practices and research in cancerous diseases.
Article Title: A computer-assisted medical diagnosis system for cancer diseases based on quaternion orthogonal Rademacher-Fourier moments and deep learning

Abstract: Background Pressure injuries (bedsores) remain a significant and costly healthcare concern, particularly for bedridden or mobility-impaired patients. Early detection and continuous monitoring of sleep posture are essential for effective prevention; however, existing systems are often expensive, intrusive, or lack sufficient accuracy. Research question This study investigates whether a wearable IMU sensor-based system integrated with a lightweight deep learning model-SleepPosNet-can accurately classify five common sleeping postures and outperform traditional learning models. Methods & results Data from 100 participants (18-65 years; 16 male/84 female) were collected using three IMU sensors (chest, right leg, left leg). Tri-axial accelerometer, gyroscope, and magnetometer data were fused into nine Euler-angle channels and labeled into five posture classes. A lightweight 1D-CNN (SleepPosNet) was trained (Adam, lr = 1e-3, batch = 64, 30 epochs) and evaluated with stratified 70-30, 80-20, and 90-10 splits, achieving up to 98.94 % accuracy, consistently surpassing MLP, Na & iuml;ve Bayes, and Logistic Regression. In a 10-fold cross-validation with deep learning baselines (BiLSTM, LSTM, GRU), SleepPosNet reached 97.39 % accuracy with only similar to 13 k parameters, the shortest epoch time (similar to 28.6 s), low latency (similar to 0.239 ms/sample), and high throughput (similar to 4.19 k samples/s). While BiLSTM achieved slightly higher accuracy (98.34 %), it required far greater computation. SleepPosNet thus offers the best accuracy-efficiency trade-off for embedded and real-time applications. Significance SleepPosNet offers a non-invasive, low-cost, and highly accurate solution for real-time sleep posture monitoring. Its lightweight structure makes it suitable for deployment in hospital and home care settings, with the potential to reduce healthcare costs and improve outcomes by aiding in the prevention of pressure injuries.
Article Title: Transforming patient care: AI-powered sleep posture classification for pressure injury prevention

Abstract: The study of human activity recognition systems based on wearable sensors is crucial in medical rehabilitation training, game entertainment, sports analysis and other fields. A new-style hybrid deep learning model based on graph convolutional network, gated recurrent unit and attention mechanism is first proposed to recognize human activity in real-time. In order to demonstrate the superiority of the proposed hybrid model, this paper trains and verifies the proposed model, convolutional neural network model and graph convolutional network model on the open source daily life activity dataset. The experiment results indicate that the accuracy and average recall rate of the proposed model is 97.8% and 97.3% respectively, which higher than convolutional neural network model and graph convolutional network model. In addition, the accuracy of the proposed model also exceeds other state-of-the-art recognition models. Therefore, the proposed novel hybrid model with higher accuracy and stronger robustness is favorable to the practice application of human activity recognition system based on wearable sensors.
Article Title: Application of graph convolutional spatial temporal fusion model based on gated recurrent unit and attention mechanism in inertial signal human activity recognition

Abstract: Background: Brain-computer interfaces have the potential to transform society by enhancing brain function. These electronic devices could enable the rapid acquisition of knowledge, preserve memories, and detect neurological conditions affecting memory in their early stages. Their capacity to store and retrieve experiences could bridge generational knowledge gaps. In order to develop such devices, significant challenges need to be overcome, including the need for a deeper understanding of brain mechanisms, ethical concerns about privacy and control, and socio-economic barriers to accessibility. Addressing these challenges is essential for their widespread adoption, which could eliminate inequalities in education. This study searched the scientific literature on brain-computer interfaces and memory enhancement in order to detect scientometric trends. Methods: A Boolean search was conducted in Scopus in July 2025. Results: This identified 1148 publications. Most were written in English (98.3 %), were articles (55.7 %), and were published in the Journal of Neural Engineering (5.1 %). There was a gradual increase in the number of publications from 2000 to 2018, with a sudden increase from 2019 onwards. The most frequently co-occurring words in the abstracts were "interface", "feature", "technology", and "training". The median page count was 9 and the median number of citations was 5. More citations were received by publications that were older, had more authors, or were articles. Only 75 publications were written by a single author, most of whom resided in the United States. Conclusion: With continued advancements, fully functional memory-enhancing brain-computer interfaces may be realized within the next 100 years, profoundly impacting human life.
Article Title: Brain-computer interfaces for memory enhancement: Scientometric analysis and future directions

Abstract: Human emotion recognition seeks to facilitate machines in comprehending human emotional states. EEG signals, being non-invasive measurements, are among the signals that most accurately represent human emotions. Nevertheless, the abundance of channels in EEG signals leads to heightened computational complexity and a greater risk of overfitting the model. In this research, eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) was employed to choose the suitable EEG channel, and a unique model named convolutional block attention module - long shortterm memory - attention module (CBAM-LSTM-Attention) was introduced for emotion recognition. The model combines residual blocks, LSTM networks, and attention mechanisms to efficiently incorporate important channel-spatial and temporal domain features of EEG signals. To achieve high prediction accuracy in emotion recognition, the following innovations can be implemented: (i) Integrating XGBoost algorithm to evaluate each channel based on power spectral density (PSD), and selecting the channel with the highest score as the input for the model. This approach reduces the computational complexity of the model and minimises the risk of overfitting. (ii) Introducing a channel-spatial attention module in the residual block to enhance the model's ability to extract channel-spatial domain features in the convolutional block attention module (CBAM) model. (iii) Utilising a multi-head attention mechanism to improve the model's capability to extract temporal domain features, enabling global feature perception and input to the LSTM layer for decoding. The results indicated that the proposed CBAM-LSTM-Attention model achieved 95.108 % accuracy for arousal and 94.862 % for valence on the DEAP dataset using single-channel data. Using multi-channel data, the model achieved 98.790 % for arousal and 97.249 %for valence. This suggests that the model effectively enables correct classification of human emotion recognition.
Article Title: CBAM-LSTM-attention enabled human emotion recognition using EEG signals

Abstract: Real-time monitoring of Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) quality is crucial for the resuscitation of patients with cardiac arrest (CA). However, most of the parameters measured by existing monitoring devices are fixed absolute metrics, overlooking significant individual variation feedback metrics such as thoracic cross-sectional area. To address this, we propose a non-contact CPR quality monitoring method based on a depth camera, which measures compression depth, rate, and changes in the patient's thoracic cross-sectional area in real time. The method first uses the depth camera to create a spatial point cloud and track the compression position, then calculates the monitoring parameters based on depth changes in the point cloud within the region of interest. Experiments conducted in different scenarios demonstrate the accuracy and effectiveness of the proposed method. Furthermore, experiments on CPR manikins of different body sizes reveal that the same level of compression results in different compression effects depending on the body size, suggesting that personalized compression strategies may improve the success rate of resuscitation in real-world scenarios. This study is the first to achieve real-time monitoring of thoracic cross-sectional area during CPR, incorporating a new indicator into CPR quality monitoring.
Article Title: Non-contact, real-time monitoring of patient thoracic cross-sectional area during CPR based on depth camera

Abstract: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a brain disorder that can be fatal and is marked by a progressive loss of cognitive function. It has become a global health concern and is the most frequent type of dementia in the elderly. Although there is currently no effective treatment, there are medications that can halt its progression. For this reason, identification of AD is vital for controlling and limiting the progression of the illness. Here, a machinelearning approach is suggested for detecting AD by examining the alterations in the Default Mode Network (DMN) functional connections. The study utilizes fMRI data from the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) dataset. We extract time-series signals from 11 voxel regions of the DMN, compute functional connectivity using both Pearson correlation and instantaneous phase synchronization, and train various classifiers. A 10-fold cross-validation strategy was employed to ensure robustness and generalizability. Among the classifiers, the linear SVM model achieved the best performance, with an accuracy of 93.33%, sensitivity of 95.56%, and specificity of 91.11% on 10-fold cross-validation. These results outperform prior DMN-based approaches and demonstrate the utility of dynamic synchronization features in early AD diagnosis.
Article Title: Classifying Alzheimer's disease using machine learning: Insights from default mode network alterations

Abstract: Brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) convert brain activity patterns into commands for external devices, is especially valuable in medical science and rehabilitation. In non-invasive BCIs, motor imagery electroencephalogram (MI-EEG) is a commonly used method for collecting brain signals. However, decoding MI signals faces the fundamental challenges of inter-subject variability and overlapping spectral-spatial features across different motor imagery classes. The proposed model is a novel strategy for decoding MI tasks multi-scale feature extraction and a frequency-guided temporal convolutional network with transfer learning. The model extracts features using three key components: a temporal block, a multi-depth block, and inception block. A channel attention mechanism is integrated into a temporal block to focus on the informative channels. The multi-depth block captures multi-scale features by aggregating information convolutional layers of varying depths. This enhances feature representation by capturing both fine-grained and abstract spatial patterns, which are crucial for accurate MI-EEG decoding. The frequency attention the temporal convolutional block enhance temporal consistency and frequency-specific pattern recognition amplifying task-relevant frequency information. A task-specific pretraining strategy is employed, where model is first trained on data from all nine subjects to learn general MI-related EEG patterns, followed subject-specific fine-tuning. On the BCI Competition IV-2a dataset, our model achieves an average classification accuracy of 81.33% (kappa: 0.75) for four classes, outperforming the state-of-the-art method by 2.05%. results provide a precise and objective evaluation of the model's effectiveness.
Article Title: A frequency-guided temporal convolutional network with transfer learning for motor imagery classification

Abstract: In this paper, a deep learning-based skin lesion segmentation hybrid model approach is proposed. A hybrid model of the convolutional neural network that significantly enhances the performance in the application of medical image segmentation in dermatological imagery. FFUM-Net stands for the balance created between precision localization and feature extraction as well as multi-scale feature resolution through the interaction of U-Net, Feature adaptive Transformers (FatNet), Feature fused model (FFNet), and MultiResUNet architecture's respective strengths. Utilizing ISIC 2016, ISIC 2017, and CVC ClinicDB datasets for training and validation through improved preprocessing methods along with reducing overfitting by using data augmentation techniques such as transpose and rotation, FFUM-Net demonstrated superiority over each model in all complex segmentation tasks under test evaluation metrics, encompassing a Jaccard Index of 0.75 and a Dice Coefficient of over 0.80. Such findings point towards high accuracy of FFUM-Net's diagnosis and, to a larger extent, the possibility of its applicability to other medical imaging challenges. Thus, the study at least sets a basis for continuing the development of these innovations, inviting further algorithmic refinement and clinical validation.
Article Title: FFUM-Net: Feature fusion unified model for biomedical image segmentation

Abstract: This research work aims to predict the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) among patients with Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) employing machine learning and deep learning techniques. Given the complexity and heterogeneity of T2DM, accurate identification of patients at risk for CVD is crucial to guiding treatment decisions and improving health outcomes. The dataset has been collected from a diabetic center in eastern India, containing 495 records with 24 attributes. It is passed through some preprocessing techniques like MICE; to handle missing values and SMOTE; to handle imbalanced data with the KS test for validation. Feature selection is performed using graph-based risk score calculation and p-value computation to identify the significant factors of the T2DM patients and how much the CVD is affected in the (CVD+T2DM) and (CVD-T2DM) groups. The proposed model is developed using Enhanced TabNet specially designed for tabular data. It utilizes sequential attention mechanisms to dynamically select important features at each decision step enhancing interpretability and predictive performance. To optimize the model, hyperparameters are systematically tuned, as the decision layer output and attentive feature dimensionality are adjusted between 8, 16, and 24 to balance complexity and generalization for 3 levels with 2187 possible combinations. The proposed model achieved the highest accuracy of 97.67% for the (CVD+T2DM) group and 98.53% for the (CVD-T2DM) group in k-fold cross-validation on the validation dataset.
Article Title: MICE based enhanced TabNet modeling for CVD risk prediction in T2DM patients: A graph-based approach with KS validated SMOTE and class weight optimization

Abstract: Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is the primary diagnostic imaging technique for gastrointestinal stromal tumors. However, accurately identifying these tumors through EUS imaging alone remains challenging, even for experienced clinicians. They often rely on additional data, such as white light endoscopy (WLE) and EUS text reports, to aid in the diagnosis. Unfortunately, in practice, these supplementary modalities are sometimes overlooked during patient evaluation. To address these issues, we propose the Cross-modal Feature Reconstruction Network (CFRN), which integrates multimodal data modeling for medical diagnostic processes and performs specific learning for different modalities with missing data. The network fuses the multi-modal features based on the clinical medical process, realizes the feature-level missing modality reconstruction, and learns the refined features of different modal true cases by decoding the mode-specific missing. We trained and tested the model on two publicly available datasets, Audiovision-MNIST, MM-IMDb, and data sets collected from real clinical scenarios at three hospitals. Our results show that CFRN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving higher prediction accuracy than using EUS alone. By simultaneously incorporating multimodal or reconstructed modal data for disease diagnosis, our single-modal EUS model proves to be more suitable for clinical scenarios.
Article Title: Reconstructing missing modalities in multi-modal endoscopic ultrasound via cross-modal feature replacement representation

Abstract: Motion intention prediction is crucial for enabling natural and responsive human-robot interaction (HRI) in wearable exoskeletons. However, traditional methods for motion intention prediction struggle to adapt to dynamic gaits and lack real-time responsiveness. Therefore, we proposed a novel Ankle Motion Intention Prediction Network (AMIP-N) based on inertial measurement units (IMUs) using the Temporal Convolution Network (TCN), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network, and our proposed Wavelet Multi-Head Self-Attention (WMSA) module. Integrating the frequency-domain emphasis of Discrete Wavelet Transforms (DWT) with the parallel computation and long-range dependency capturing abilities of Multi-Head Self-Attention (MSA), our model can precisely predict the future 0.25 s sagittal angle trajectory of the ankle joint, utilizing just 1 s of historical IMU data. Extensive experiments on a public dataset and our collected dataset have demonstrated that AMIP-N has superior prediction performance compared to baseline models, with a reduction of more than 19.4% in the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and an average time to predict once of only 7.16 ms. We further elucidated the effect of IMU placement on prediction accuracy and delineated the optimal trajectory prediction interval. Finally, preliminary human-in-the-Loop validation experiments using a real exoskeleton system demonstrated the practical feasibility of our method, yielding an average absolute error of only 2.73 degrees between predicted and actual ankle joint trajectories. These findings demonstrated the model's practical applicability and its potential for robust exoskeleton control. The source code is available at https://github.com/BioRob-Lab/AMIP-N.
Article Title: AMIP-N: Ankle Motion Intention Prediction Network combined TCN, LSTM, and Wavelet Multi-Head Self-Attention based on IMUs

Abstract: In the field of medical image segmentation, the introduction of Transformers to assist in medical image segmentation has proven to be effective in recent years. Compared to traditional CNN methods, Transformers have excellent global context information extraction capabilities. However, using a purely Transformer-based architecture for image segmentation not only increases the overall network parameters but also decreases the ability to extract local features. The accurate extraction and integration of local and global features are crucial for achieving medical image segmentation. Therefore, we propose TUTNet, an improved medical image segmentation network. TUTNet features a dual encoder architecture, consisting of a CNN-based encoder and a Transformer-based encoder. The former effectively extracts local information, while the latter captures global information. Skip connections simultaneously receive information from both encoders, eliminating semantic differences between the two encoders through a cross-attention mechanism. Skip connections are also of high importance for medical image segmentation. In our network, the skip connections utilize a purely Transformer mechanism, fully leveraging the information extracted by encoders at all levels, utilizing a self-attention mechanism to focus on channel information, and then employing a cross-attention mechanism to query and filter global information with local information, thus extracting valuable information for decoders at each level. We conducted extensive validation on four datasets, demonstrating the effectiveness of our network across different feature datasets. Our work can be viewed on https://github.com/whycantChinese/TUTNet.
Article Title: TUTNet: Leveraging transformers for comprehensive extraction and preservation of global information in medical image segmentation

Abstract: Instance segmentation of nuclei in histopathological images is hindered by three critical challenges: overlapping nuclei, domain shift caused by staining variability, and generalization across diverse multi-organ datasets. To address these issues, we propose a unified multi-task learning framework for nucleus instance segmentation that integrates style transformation and distance map-guided segmentation. Our architecture employs multi-dilated residual blocks and encoder-decoder attention gates to capture multi-scale features and preserve fine nuclear details, while a transformer in the bottleneck enhances contextual understanding and models long-range dependencies. The network incorporates dual heads for semantic segmentation and distance-map prediction, effectively addressing overlapping nuclei. Additionally, a histogram-based, reference-guided stain normalization module mitigates domain shift caused by staining variability, and when combined with our robust model architecture, it enhances the overall generalization ability across multi-organ datasets. Experimental results demonstrate our method's superior performance over existing segmentation approaches. The source code is available at https://github.com/eyob12/MTL-NucleusSeg.
Article Title: Style transformation and distance map guided nucleus instance segmentation via multi task learning

Abstract: Tooth segmentation from panoramic dental X-ray images plays a key role in diagnosing and evaluating oral diseases. However, due to blurred boundaries between teeth, most current studies increase network complexity to improve performance, but unfortunately, the results are unsatisfactory. Through research, we found that they often overlook the importance of frequency information in the segmentation of objects with blurry edges. Therefore, we propose a frequency-guided multi-scale U-Net for tooth segmentation. Specifically, we designed a multi-scale nested structure with a multi-branch double-cross frequency sensitive mask module as the main functional component. Moreover, we propose a frequency-sensitive cross-fusion strategy aimed at efficient result restoration and reconstruction. Additionally, to eliminate disturbances at the source data level, we incorporate a multifunctional data preprocessing module. It serves as a plug-in module with high flexibility. Finally, in addition to conducting traditional comprehensive experiments on the publicly available Tufts Dental Database, we innovatively employ distributed experiments to better align with real dental treatment processes. Results from both types of experiments demonstrate that our model significantly surpasses the current state-of-the-art methods.
Article Title: Efficient panoramic dental X-ray image segmentation model based on dual-domain transformation processing

Abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a multifactorial neurological condition defined by cognitive impairments. The symptoms of ASD involve behavioral changes, indistinct speech, social impairment, and so on. As a result, detecting ASD at an early stage is essential to lessen the disorder's impact. Various ASD detection approaches have been devised over the past decades for detecting ASD from Magnetic Resonance Image (MRI). Meanwhile, these detection schemes measured low detection accuracies and attained low generalization ability in detecting ASD. A deep learning-based optimization model, Fractional Hiking Optimization Algorithm combined with Dense WideResNet (FHOA + DenWide-Net), is proposed in this article for detecting ASD from brain MRI images. Initially, the MRI images are denoised using the Wiener filter, followed by the extraction of the relevant regions from the denoised image through Region of Interest (ROI) extraction. The Fractional Hiking Optimization Algorithm (FHOA) is designed for the selection of optimal grid during nub region extraction from the extracted ROI image. Following this, the ASD is detected from the nub region using the designed DenWide-Net technique. In addition, DenWide-Net exceeds the performance of other baseline models, delivering a sensitivity of 91.385 %, specificity of 91.175 %, and accuracy of 91 %.
Article Title: DenWide-Net: Dense WideresNet for autism spectrum disorder detection using MRI image

Abstract: Deep learning (DL) approaches leveraging multi-parametric magnetic resonance imaging (mpMRI) hold significant promise for the preoperative assessment of rectal cancer T-stage. In this study, we investigate whether a mpMRI fusion-based DL model can effectively evaluate the T-stage of rectal cancer. To enable robust development and comprehensive evaluation of an automated T-staging system, we assembled the largest mpMRI cohort to date, comprising 756 patients from three institutions with nine distinct imaging sequences. We introduce a multi-view multi-parametric (MVMP) MRI fusion model for this purpose. The strategy for effective sequence fusion involves grouping different MRI sequences based on scanning directions and integrating features from each group using an attention module. During evaluations, the MVMP model achieves performance comparable to that of two radiologists in both the internal test cohort (AUC: 0.84 vs. 0.79 vs. 0.79) and the external test cohort (AUC: 0.83 vs. 0.81 vs. 0.75). Moreover, it outperforms other DL competitors in both the internal (AUC: 0.840 vs. 0.766 vs. 0.787) and external test cohorts (AUC: 0.826 vs. 0.792 vs. 0.821). The validity of our design is further substantiated through ablation studies on backbone networks, view-specific branches, and individual sequences. In summary, our DL model based on mpMRI and multi-view fusion accurately evaluates the preoperative T-stage of rectal cancer and shows great promise as a valuable tool for clinical assessment.
Article Title: Deep-learning-based 3D multi-view multi-parametric MRI fusion model for preoperative T-staging of rectal cancer

Abstract: There is an increasing need for the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of cardiovascular disease (CVD). Reduced cardiac output (CO) is frequently associated with CVD. Thus, accurate measurement of CO aids its diagnosis and helps to guide treatment. A convenient, real-time, noninvasive way to estimate CO is the Pressure Recording Analytic Method (PRAM). It is based on the non-invasive detection of the pressure wave in a peripheral artery and does not require invasive measurements to calibrate the model parameters. Unfortunately, its accuracy is limited due to its dependence on the patient's height, weight, heart rate, and the mechanical properties of each individual's arteries. Furthermore, compared to the peripheral arterial pressure wave, the aortic pressure wave provides a more accurate and efficient means of estimating CO. Therefore, to improve the accuracy of the original PRAM method, this study incorporates height, weight, and heart rate measurements, as well as an AutoRegressive with eXogenous input (ARX) model, enabling adaptive estimation of the aortic pressure waveform from radial artery pressure wave measurement. The CO estimations of the original peripheral PRAM (COPRAMper), the improved peripheral PRAM (COIPRAMper) and the improved central PRAM (COIPRAMcen) were compared to MRI results (COMRI), as the ground truth. The correlation coefficients (R2) between the CO estimates using the 3 algorithms and COMRI were 0.271, 0.548 and 0.757, respectively. These R2 values were statistically significant and showed that COIPRAMcen performed best. The mean difference between the CO estimates using the 3 algorithms and COMRI were -0.15 f 0.44, -0.07 f 0.24 and -0.04 f 0.17 L/min, respectively.
Article Title: Estimation of cardiac output based on PRAM algorithm and ARX model from noninvasive radial pressure wave

Abstract: Epilepsy is one of the most common chronic neurological disorders, affecting over 50 million people worldwide. The unpredictability of seizures and the challenges in accurately detecting harmful brain activity through EEG analysis place a heavy burden on both patients and clinicians. Traditional methods are time-consuming and require expert interpretation, often delaying timely intervention. This study proposes a deep learning-based solution to automate the classification of harmful brain activities such as seizures, using EEG spectrograms. This study aims to automate seizure detection by leveraging deep learning techniques for classifying harmful brain activities using EEG spectrograms. The proposed method utilizes the HMS EEG dataset sourced from Kaggle, comprising expert-annotated EEG recordings categorized into six classes: Seizure, LPD, GPD, GRDA, LRDA, and Others. To improve model performance and generalization, a carefully designed preprocessing pipeline is employed: (1) Non-overlapping training protocol ensures that each EEG ID appears only once in the training data, preventing data leakage and ensuring that the model does not learn from multiple crops of the same EEG recording. (2) Logarithmic transformation and normalization reduce dynamic range variations and standardize data distribution. (3) Multimodal integration converts EEG signals into spectrograms, creating an 8-channel input representation for richer spatial and temporal feature extraction. (4) Data augmentation using horizontal flipping increases model robustness against variations in EEG recordings. We fine-tune an EfficientNet-B0 model, originally trained on ImageNet, by modifying the input layers and replacing the classification head with a Softmax-based six-class output layer. To ensure reliable training, we use Group K-Fold cross-validation and a step-based learning rate scheduler. Our model is evaluated using Kullback-Leibler Divergence (KL-DIV) as the primary performance metric. It achieves a training KL-DIV of 0.4353 and a significantly lower testing KL-DIV of 0.0007, indicating strong generalization to unseen data and minimal divergence from the true label distribution. Comparative evaluations of several existing state-of-the-art models show that our approach outperforms GoogleNet in both accuracy and computational efficiency. In conclusion, this study showcases the effectiveness of deep learning, specifically EfficientNet-B0 for reliable and scalable EEG-based seizure detection. It provides a promising foundation for real-world clinical applications in neurological monitoring and diagnosis.
Article Title: Advanced EEG-based brain monitoring for early detection of harmful neural activities using EfficientNet architecture

Abstract: Medical image segmentation is crucial in disease detection and diagnosis, especially in applications like lesion segmentation and tumor identification. However, existing approaches often struggle to simultaneously capture multi-scale local and global information, reserve high-frequency information, and facilitate transmission of information flow with high generalization ability. To address these challenges, an advanced medical image segmentation network (MSFB-Net) based on Multi-Scale Frequency Compound Attention and Cross-Layer Boundary Optimization is proposed. Firstly, a Multi-Scale Frequency Compound Attention (MSFCA) is introduced to effectively integrate fine-grained details and global contextual information by fusing multi-level features from spatial and frequency domains. This strategy enhances segmentation precision handling complex structures while maintaining computational efficiency. Subsequently, a Cross-Layer Boundary Optimization (CLBO) integrating Gaussian convolution and Laplacian pyramid techniques is introduced concentrate on boundary regions and merges background and boundary features, compensating for high frequency details loss during extensive upsampling stages. Finally, design an Interactive Fusion module (IF) is designed in the bottleneck layer between the encoder and decoder to extract deeper feature and suppress noise and redundant information by employing residual connection with multi-layer convolution and channel interaction mechanism, thereby facilitating information flow in the network. Extensive experiments are conducted on several publicly available medical imaging datasets, including Kvasir-SEG, CVC-ClinicDB, CVC-ColonDB, ETIS-Larib, CVC-300, the 2018 Data Science Bowl (DSB), ISIC 2018, and Breast Ultrasound Image (BUSI). Comprehensive experimental results demonstrate that the proposed MSFB-Net outperforms state-of-the-art methods. confirming its effectiveness and wide applicability in medical image segmentation.
Article Title: MSFB-Net: Multi-scale frequency compound attention and cross-layer boundary optimization for medical image segmentation

Abstract: Medical image segmentation is emerging as a hot research topic due to its promising application prospects in disease diagnosis and treatment. While deep learning-based medical image segmentation has made significant progress, most of them rely on fully supervised learning, requiring extensive expert annotations. To mitigate this limitation, there has been a growing interest in the study of semi-supervised medical image segmentation, which leverages a small amount of labeled data and abundant unlabeled data to achieve accurate segmentation. In this paper, a novel confidence-aware semi-supervised medical image segmentation method is proposed to construct precise and reliable supervision by designing an adaptive pixel-wise weighting approach for different regions. Specifically, for uncertain regions, an entropy-weighted consistency optimization mechanism is proposed to enable more focus on challenging pixels, thereby making the network reduce prediction errors. Besides, for certain regions, a dynamic weighting pseudo supervision strategy is proposed to emphasize reliable pixels within the pseudo labels, thus obtaining more effective pseudo supervision. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method, with a Dice score of 86.33% on the BraTS 2019 dataset, under the 20% labeled data setting.
Article Title: Semi-supervised medical image segmentation with confidence-aware learning

Abstract: Exercise Stress Test (EST) is a non-invasive method widely used to diagnose Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). It generates a substantial amount of multi-modal data, which is crucial for diagnostic research. However, previous research has tended to ignore textual modalities such as patients' subjective symptoms and clinicians' interpretations during the diagnostic process. This research aims to improve CAD diagnosis by combining multi-modal data, including patients' ECG, physiological data, subjective symptoms, and clinicians' notes. This research used data from 404 patients who underwent EST. After preprocessing, a multi-modal model was developed to distinguish CAD negative, CAD positive, and suspected CAD cases. This model consisted of a Time-aware convolutional network (TACN) for extracting temporal features from ECG images and a finetuned pre-trained BERT model for textual modality. The proposed method demonstrated strong performance in accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and positive predictive value, achieving macro-average scores of 87.43%, 77.06%, 91.13%, and 73.89%, respectively. This research proposes a multi-modal model that combines TACN and a fine-tuned BERT model, and improves the model's classification accuracy for CAD by introducing textual modalities and improving ECG processing. The implementation helps clinicians diagnose CAD more accurately and better allocate medical resources.
Article Title: Synergizing ECG and textual features: A multi-modal method for coronary artery disease classification

Abstract: Ensuring robust security measures for Electronic Health Records (EHRs) is essential to prevent unauthorized access. Here, blockchain facilitates secure data sharing. In blockchain, if the full node is compromised, then the data transferred to the light node will be incorrect. The existing studies didn't concentrate on full node authentication in blockchain. Thus, this paper proposes a blockchain-based Incremental Provable Data Possession (IPDP) for a secure Electronic Healthcare System (EHS) using Zero Exponential Mikhail's Hash Knowledge Proof (ZEMHKP) and Transport Layer Security (TLS). Primarily, the patients and doctors register with the EHS. Next, the key generation, login, and doctor consultation are done. Further, the EHR is selected, followed by encryption using Homomorphic Encryption (HE). At that time, to mitigate the Structured Query Language (SQL) injection attacks, regex pattern generation and pattern matching are carried out using Thompson's Extended Transition Construction Algorithm (TETCA). If patterns are matched, then the data is stored in the Interplanetary File System (IPFS) and blockchain; otherwise, access is denied. Likewise, IPDP and TLS protocols are employed to ensure data integrity and secure communication in blockchain. Next, full node authentication is verified by using ZEMHKP. If the full node is authenticated, then one condition is checked; otherwise, the full node is reselected. If the conditions and the hash code are verified, then data access is granted. As per the outcome, the proposed ZEMHKP took a minimum time of 3561 ms for authentication, and the proposed TETCA achieved a high efficiency of 98 % during pattern matching.
Article Title: An efficient blockchain-based incremental provable data possession for a secure electronic healthcare system

Abstract: Ensuring secure communication of biomedical data has become increasingly important due to its sensitive nature. Chaotic systems, with their inherent unpredictability and sensitivity to initial conditions, offer a promising approach for secure data encryption. This study introduces a novel five-term chaotic system that includes two squared nonlinearities, a unique configuration not previously reported in the literature. The system's dynamics are analyzed through equilibrium points, stability, bifurcation diagrams, and Lyapunov Exponents (LEs), where the Kaplan-Yorke dimension is found to be 2.1471 under selected parameters, confirming strong chaotic behavior. An electronic implementation of the system is achieved using standard analog components, validating its physical feasibility. The system is then applied to encrypt biomedical signals and images. In secure ECG signal transmission tests conducted on a Raspberry Pi, synchronization is achieved within 4 s using Sliding Mode Control (SMC). The encryption algorithm demonstrates high key sensitivity and a large key space. For biomedical image encryption, the proposed method achieves a Number of Pixels Change Rate (NPCR) of 99.56% and a Unified Average Changing Intensity (UACI) of 33.31%, indicating strong encryption performance. These results confirm that the proposed chaotic system is efficient, lightweight, and highly suitable for secure biomedical communication.
Article Title: A novel five-term 3D chaotic system with two squared nonlinearities and its secure communication application for biomedical data

Abstract: Automatic seizure prediction is crucial for developing new therapies for patients with refractory epilepsy. Throughout the development of deep learning, numerous methods for automatic epileptic seizure prediction have been proposed. Existing deep learning-based seizure prediction networks struggle to capture the temporal information of Electroencephalogram (EEG) signals while effectively integrating spatial information. To overcome these limitations, we propose a memory cached vision transformer with Kolmogorov-Arnold network (KAN-MemViT) for seizure prediction. Our model employs a spatial information block (SI-block) and a CNN module to integrate the spatial information of EEG signals. Subsequently, a multi-layer memory cached encoder (MCE) is utilized to capture the long-range temporal dependencies in the EEG signals. The hierarchical federation (HF) module further processes the information after each MCE layer to capture shortterm event dependencies. By combining both long-range and short-range dependencies, discriminative features are obtained. The Kolmogorov-Arnold network (KAN) is then chosen as the classifier, enabling the model to thoroughly explore the characteristics of epileptic signals. Event-based patient-specific and cross-patient experiments are conducted on the CHB-MIT database. The patient-specific experiments achieve a sensitivity of 97.857%, a false positive rate of 0.028/h, and an AUC of 0.951. These results demonstrate the superior performance and strong potential of KAN-MemViT for accurate and reliable seizure prediction.
Article Title: KAN-MemViT: A memory cached vision transformer with Kolmogorov-Arnold network for seizure prediction

Abstract: Automated retinal disease diagnosis has emerged as a pivotal innovation in modern ophthalmology, promising to enhance clinical workflows and patient management. While existing diagnostic systems show potential, they often lack the precision, generalizability, and computational efficiency needed for real-world deployment. This study aims to overcome these limitations by developing an advanced deep learning framework for robust and efficient retinal disease classification. The proposed methodology integrates three key components: a Transformer-based VesselNet (T-VesselNet) for enhanced feature extraction, ChannelNet for optimized information flow, and a Graph-Enhanced Multi-Scale Fusion Network (GEMFNet) to capture hierarchical retinal patterns. Furthermore, a novel Neuroweb Optimizer dynamically adjusts hyperparameters-including filter size, kernel dimensions, and layer-wise neuron allocation-to maximize model performance. When evaluated on four benchmark datasets (DRIVE, STARE, CHASE_DB1, and HRF), the model achieves state-of-the-art performance, with accuracy (98.7 %), sensitivity (96.2 %), specificity (99.1 %), and Dice coefficient (97.4 %). The system's real-time segmentation capability (0.23 s per image) demonstrates strong clinical applicability. These findings establish the framework as a transformative solution that bridges the gap between algorithmic innovation and clinical implementation. By enabling earlier, more reliable disease detection, this research not only improves diagnostic outcomes but also sets a new benchmark for AI-assisted ophthalmology practice.
Article Title: T-VesselNet and GEMFNet: A transformer-based multi-scale fusion framework with graph enhancements for accurate and efficient retinal disease classification

Abstract: Medical image segmentation plays a vital role in assisting clinical diagnosis and treatment. However, thyroid ultrasound images often suffer from low contrast, severe noise interference, and blurred boundaries, making accurate and robust segmentation a challenging task for conventional methods. To address these limitations, we propose a novel segmentation model, CS-Net, which integrates multi-scale feature fusion with feature reconstruction convolution. The model introduces a Spatial and Channel Reconstruction Convolution module (SCConv) to suppress redundant features and enhance the extraction of fine-grained details in low-quality regions. Additionally, a Channel-wise Cross Fusion Transformer (CCT) module is incorporated to align and integrate multi-level semantic features, effectively bridging the semantic gap between encoder and decoder stages. Furthermore, a Pixel-attention-guided fusion and Upsample module (PagU) is designed to dynamically reweight fused features, improving boundary delineation and localization accuracy. Extensive experiments on two public thyroid ultrasound datasets, DDTI and TN3K, demonstrate that CS-Net outperforms representative models including UNet, TransUNet, and SwinUNet in terms of Dice coefficient, mIoU, precision, and recall. Specifically, CS-Net achieves Dice scores of 87.36 % and 86.47 % on the DDTI and TN3K datasets, showcasing excellent robustness. Ablation studies further confirm the effectiveness of each module. These results suggest that CS-Net offers a promising and reliable solution for automatic segmentation of low-quality medical images.
Article Title: Medical image segmentation model based on multi-scale fusion and feature reconstruction convolution

Abstract: Rectal cancer is widely regarded as one of the most prevalent malignant tumors because of its high incidence and mortality rates. The use of medical examination for precise preoperative staging is of paramount importance for patients because it enables the establishment of effective surgical treatment strategies. To support clinical diagnosis, a novel AI-based approach was developed to accurately predict the preoperative stage of rectal cancer via computed tomography (CT) images. An adaptive attention multiscale feature fusion network (AMFNet) is proposed, which couples adaptive multibranch attention modules and multiscale feature fusion technologies for processing and analyzing image data collected by CT instruments, to improve the diagnostic performance of CT instrument-based methods. This approach captures global details with an adaptive attention mechanism and effectively fuses features across scales. The effectiveness of the model was verified via a dataset of 3,090 abdominal CT images from 318 patients by leveraging 10-fold cross-validation and small-sample experiments. Cross-validation experiments show that AMFNet is superior to other deep learning models. Compared with mainstream convolutional neural network models, the superiority of this method is that it involves limited samples. The proposed method demonstrates stability, generalizability, and high performance for rectal cancer Tstage diagnosis via CT imaging, presenting a novel and potential approach in the field.
Article Title: Preoperative prediction of rectal cancer stage via CT imaging and an adaptive attention multiscale feature fusion network

Abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel cross-fusion model, CDMT-Unet, which leverages the MobileNet and Transformer architectures for precise segmentation and diagnosis of skin cancer images. This model integrates the strengths of the Haar wavelet transform, capable of capturing global texture and edge information through multiscale analysis, with an attention mechanism that focuses on more pertinent information. By combining these methodologies, the model effectively utilizes both high-frequency detail and low-frequency structural information to comprehensively characterize the skin lesion area. Building upon this foundation, the CDMT-Unet model adopts a hybrid architecture encompassing CNN, Transformer, and Unet components. The CNN module is employed to extract local spatial features, while the Transformer module captures global contextual information via a self-attention mechanism. Furthermore, the Unet structure facilitates the fusion and reconstruction of multilevel features through skip connections. Utilizing a dual-frequency cross-fusion strategy, the model adeptly integrates features extracted by the discrete Walsh transform and Haar wavelet transform, thereby enhancing its ability to segment complex skin lesions. Experimental results demonstrate that CDMT-Unet achieves remarkable performance across two public skin cancer datasets (ISIC2017 and ISIC2018). Specifically, on ISIC2017, it achieves mIoU of 80.51%, DSC of 87.88%, ACC of 95.68%, Spe of 96.98%, and Sen of 92.13%; on ISIC2018, it reaches mIoU of 80.31%, DSC of 87.60%, ACC of 95.37%, Spe of 97.93%, and Sen of 89.64%. These results highlight the model's excellence in accurate segmentation of lesion edges and preservation of small-scale features. This model offers an efficient and reliable solution for the automated diagnosis of skin cancer, demonstrating significant potential for a wide range of clinical applications. Our source code is publicly available at: https://github.com/zzhzd/CDMT-Unet.
Article Title: CDMT-Unet: a dual-frequency cross-fusion model for skin cancer segmentation

Abstract: Medical image segmentation remains a fundamental challenge in computer vision, requiring precise delineation of anatomical structures while handling complex multi-scale features and long-range dependencies. Traditional convolutional neural networks often struggle with capturing both fine-grained local details and global contextual information simultaneously. To address these limitations, we propose WKPNet, a novel deep learning architecture that synergistically integrates three complementary mechanisms: Haar wavelet decomposition for multi-scale frequency analysis, Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) layers with learnable activation functions, and Polarized Linear Attention (POLA) for efficient long-range dependency modeling. Unlike existing approaches that treat these components separately, WKPNet establishes a unified framework through WaveletKAN blocks and CombinedWaveletPola blocks that enable seamless information flow between multi-resolution analysis and adaptive feature learning. The architecture employs a novel polarized attention mechanism that reduces computational complexity from O(N2d) to O(Nd2) while maintaining modeling capacity for global dependencies. Extensive experiments on three challenging medical image segmentation datasets (BUSI, GlaS, CVC) demonstrate that WKPNet achieves a favorable trade-off between segmentation accuracy and computational efficiency, delivering competitive or superior performance in both Intersection over Union (IoU) and Dice coefficient metrics with substantially reduced computational cost. The results validate the effectiveness of combining wavelet analysis, learnable activations, and efficient attention mechanisms for dense prediction tasks in medical imaging.
Article Title: WKPNet: A novel wavelet-KAN-POLA network for medical image segmentation

Abstract: Gene regulatory networks (GRNs) have revealed the internal mechanism and complex relationship of gene expression regulation, and its research is of great significance for the in-depth understanding of life activities and accurate disease diagnosis. Although the existing methods can realize the expression analysis at the cell level with the promotion of single-cell RNA sequencing(scRNA-seq) technology, most focus on the interaction between local genes, and it is difficult to capture the overall organizational structure and long-term regulatory effects. In this study, we present a novel supervised method named KA4GANC, which integrates the Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) with a Graph Attention Network (GAT) to address the critical limitations in capturing global regulatory architecture from scRNA-seq data. KA4GANC's novelty lies in two key components. First, it leverages a Fourier KAN for nonlinear feature transformation via adaptive, multi-scale Fourier basis functions, thereby generating highly expressive gene embeddings. Second, it replaces linear transformations in graph attention layers with a KAN-based convolution, enabling the model to learn complex nonlinear local interactions and effectively preserve neighborhood topology in the latent space. Benchmark evaluations on seven scRNA-seq datasets across three ground-truth network types demonstrate KA4GANC's state-of-the-art performance, achieving average AUROC of 0.84 with 34.6% faster convergence.
Article Title: KA4GANC: A Kolmogorov-Arnold graph attention network approach for predicting gene regulations using single-cell RNA-sequencing data

Abstract: Coronary angiography (CAG) serves as the gold standard for diagnosing coronary heart disease, but its poor image quality and high levels of noise interference have consistently affected the diagnoses of physicians and hindered the development of intelligent auxiliary diagnosis for coronary heart disease. To address these problems, we propose a real-time coronary angiography image enhancement network based on multi-frame dynamic information fusion and vascular structure constraint (MFSC-Net), which is a conditional generative adversarial network. First, we introduce multi-scale attention block (MAB) to reduce network parameters, achieving realtime image processing. The generator network includes optical flow information extraction block based on RAFT, feature extraction block (FEB), multi-frame dynamic information fusion block (MDIF), and image reconstruction block (IRB). MDIF fuses the optical flow information of key-frame with key-frame itself at the feature level, thereby enhancing image with low vascular contrast and suppressing the background. The vascular structure constraint (VSC), present in the discriminator, is divided into vascular morphology constraint (VMC) and vascular intensity constraint (VIC), which ensure the continuity, integrity, and realism of the vessels in the enhanced results. Extensive experiments based on our proprietary dataset demonstrate that the coronary angiography image enhancement effect of our proposed MFSC-Net is superior to other state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods. Additionally, our method is of significant importance for reducing surgical risks, improving diagnostic efficiency, and promoting the intelligent auxiliary diagnosis of coronary heart disease. The code is available at https://github.com/yuhui0416/MFSC-Net.
Article Title: Multi-frame dynamic information fusion and vascular structure constraint for real-time enhancement of coronary angiography images

Abstract: To address the limitations of traditional methods in capturing subtle anatomical changes, we propose an axial interpolation network that leverages multi-slice feature fusion and edge prediction to restore fine details of pancreatic tumor and enhance segmentation accuracy. The network includes an Inter-slice Feature Fusion module that utilizes spatial consistency between adjacent slices to calculate shape change gradient, simulating the morphological evolution of tumor. Through the Residual Global Context Attention Block module, the network refines feature representations while utilizing residual structures to preserve low-frequency information, ensuring the smooth transmission of image details during the reconstruction process. In the up-sampling stage, the network uses pixel-wise attention mapping results from the feature map as weights for weighted fusion. This method allows the network to adaptively combine features based on spatial changes between slices, thereby accurately restoring tumor contours and the boundaries of surrounding tissues. Additionally, we have designed an edge-aware composite loss function that enhances the contrast between tumor and surrounding tissue, improving boundary accuracy by jointly constraining brightness, structure, and edge gradient. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms existing methods in both detail restoration and segmentation accuracy, achieving clearer edges with a 3% average improvement in the Dice coefficient on the nn-UNet framework (1% for pancreas; 5% for tumor).
Article Title: MSA-Net:Axial interpolation network based on Multi-Slice feature fusion and edge prediction

Abstract: Dementia has no cure, but if diagnosed in early stages, its progress can be slowed. For this reason, it is necessary to implement and improve the techniques that aid the diagnosis of this disease. Electroencephalography has been shown to be a potential candidate to support the diagnosis of dementia. Applying correct processing to the EEG signal and a good selection of features will allow a more accurate diagnosis. This paper presents a methodology to discriminate healthy subjects from subjects with Alzheimer's disease and mild cognitive impairment. The work focuses mainly on the pre-processing stage and feature selection to establish a robust methodology that addresses inter-subject variability. In the pre-processing, a spatial filter is applied conditionally based on a threshold derived from the Signal-to-Noise ratio of the EEG signals; additionally, independent component analysis is used to remove noise present in the signal. For feature extraction, different techniques widely used in the frequency and time domains such as relative power and entropy were employed, obtaining a total of 133 features. Feature selection is performed through particle swarm optimization, where the objective function is based on the distance between the correlation matrix of the two classes considered; out of the 133 extracted features, 26 were selected, with relative power and entropy in the frontal and parietal electrodes being the most relevant in the detection of Alzheimer's disease. The results obtained demonstrate that the methodology is successfully applied to different datasets achieving an accuracy greater than 95% in most of the tests carried out.
Article Title: EEG-based classification framework for the detection of Alzheimer's disease and mild cognitive impairment
Unified approach for accurate brain tumor Multi-Classification and segmentation through fusion of advanced methodologies (vol 100, 106872, 2025)

Abstract: One of the most prevalent and dangerous malignant neoplasms in women is breast cancer, and early identification is key to therapy. Histopathological imaging is used to diagnose breast cancer. The proposed model has introduced novel triplet spatial attention model for Mask Region Based-Convolutional Neural Network (RCNN) that enhancing the feature learning efficiency while ensuring the high-level detection performance. This architecture has introduced a Densely-connected Shuffle-grouped Dilated Convolutional layer (DSDC), Denselyconnected Late Stacked layer (DLS), and Densely-connected Early Stacked Layer (DESL) are parallelly interconnected with the spatial-channel attention that helps to fetch significant information simultaneously. Thus, the proposed model is named as triplet fused Triplet Fused Spatial-Channel Attention Based Mask RCNN (TFSCA_MRCNN). The proposed model is trained with the Self-Adaptive Osprey Optimization (SA_OO) algorithm. The performance is evaluated based on accuracy, precision, specificity, sensitivity, Intersection Over Union (IoU).
Article Title: TFSCA_MRCNN: A dense shuffle-grouped dilated convolutional framework for efficient breast cancer image segmentation

Abstract: Multimodal signal fusion technology has been widely applied in affective computing, human-computer interaction, medical diagnosis, and behavior analysis due to its complementarity, robustness, and noise resistance. EEG reflects intrinsic physiological responses, while facial expressions capture external emotion manifestations. The combination of these modalities offers a more comprehensive view of emotions, but challenges arise due to the susceptibility of EEG data to interference and variability across subjects, as well as the influence of environmental conditions and posture on facial expressions. Moreover, significant feature differences between EEG and facial expressions pose a complex fusion challenge. In this study, we propose a novel systematic approach to address these challenges. For EEG, we conduct thorough preprocessing to minimize environmental noise and muscle artifacts, and we introduce the ST-Mixer model, which effectively extracts and integrates spatiotemporal features. For facial expression analysis, we utilize Action Units (AUs) for emotion recognition, as they provide a robust feature set. We design the Resformer model to extract both deep spatiotemporal and global features from facial expressions, and innovatively incorporate face video confidence into Resformer to mitigate the impact of low-quality facial video data on model training. Furthermore, we introduce a Cross-Modal Feature Enhancement Fusion Module (CMEF) that enhances the interaction between EEG and facial expression features, enabling effective multimodal fusion. Extensive experiments on multimodal datasets-MAHNOB-HCI, AMIGOS, and DEAP-demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of our approach in emotion recognition.
Article Title: EA-FUSION: A multimodal emotion recognition model using EEG and facial expression data

Abstract: Semantic segmentation techniques significantly aid in identifying and localizing lesion regions in medical images, thereby enhancing diagnostic accuracy and efficiency. However, conventional convolutional methods primarily model local features, making it challenging to effectively capture global contextual information. While existing solutions, such as transformers and Mamba, aim to tackle the challenge of global contextual information, they are often associated with significant computational complexity. To address these limitations, this paper proposes the Medical Semantic Segmentation Model based on Multiscale Fusion Perception (MSSM-MFP). First, a multiple class fusion module is proposed, which employs a combination of three convolutions with varying padding and dilation rates to sequentially perform down-sampling operations. This approach enables the capture of image features at multi-scales, thereby enhancing segmentation accuracy. Second, a multiscale attention gate mechanism is innovatively proposed to realize feature fusion and enhance the perception of different-scale information. Finally, the local feature enhancement module is proposed to enhance the ability to capture local features in medical images, to enhance the model's grasp of image complexities. Experimental results on the BUSI and Glas datasets show that the proposed model achieves better prediction than existing mainstream methods. The code is available at https://github.com/zpl181/MSSM-MFP.
Article Title: MSSM-MFP: Medical semantic segmentation model based on multiscale fusion perception

Abstract: Classification of bone marrow cells is important for diagnosing hematopoietic diseases such as leukemia and lymphoma. Traditional methods, such as complete blood count and peripheral smear analysis, focus mainly on mature blood cells. However, bone marrow analysis is critical to understanding all stages of blood cell development. Manual bone marrow analysis is time-consuming, error-prone and requires expertise. In addition, the classification of bone marrow cells is complicated due to changing cell lineages and morphological variation, leading to data imbalance. This study introduces a new Embedding-Space Re-sampling Technique (ESRT) integrated into a feature extractor model to address data imbalance and improve classification. This algorithm generates synthetic samples for minority classes in the embedding space instead of relying on image data pixel space. The ESRT approach improves computational efficiency and expands decision boundaries by focusing on challenging samples to classify near decision boundaries and extract key embeddings. This method enhances the model's ability to distinguish between classes by highlighting adversarial examples from opposing classes. Using a large 21-class bone marrow cytology dataset, the proposed framework achieved an impressive classification accuracy and Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC) of 89.90% and 73.19%, respectively, surpassing existing methods. Also, the accuracy and F1-score of the inference on the unseen test dataset are 75.58% and 76.11%, respectively. This framework provides a solution to data imbalance with significant efficiency, increasing model and classification performance without the need for extensive preprocessing.
Article Title: Deep learning-based bone marrow cytology classification: A solution to class imbalance

Abstract: Emotional disorders and psychological health issues are increasingly prominent. The accurate identification of EEG signals-based emotional states is crucial for early intervention and personalized treatment, since EEG signals are widely considered as an important biomarker characterizing emotion expression.
