However, mutual labeling in EEG signals is expensive and time-consuming, resulting in the insufficiency of labeled data. To address this issue, this work proposes a self-supervised learning-based framework of EEG emotion recognition based on spatial-temporal attention networks and contrastive learning called STAtt-CL. The proposed STAtt-CL consists of a coarse-refined temporal feature extractor, a spatial feature extractor, and a spatial-temporal attention fusion module. The proposed STAtt-CL is performed in a two-stage process: a pre-training stage using contrastive learning, and a fine-tuning stage for emotion classification. Experiments are conducted on the DEAP and SEED datasets, and the results indicate that the proposed STAtt-CL achieves a four-class classification accuracy of 93.89% on the DEAP dataset, and a three-class accuracy of 95.83% on the SEED dataset. This demonstrates the superiority of the proposed STAtt-CL over other used approaches in EEG-based emotion recognition tasks.
Article Title: Self-supervised learning-based EEG emotion recognition using spatial-temporal attention networks and contrastive learning

Abstract: This study presents a novel image segmentation method termed Fractional Coati Optimization Algorithm-Pulse-Coupled Neural Network (FCOA-PCNN), which synergistically integrates a Fractional Coati Optimization Algorithm (FCOA) with a Pulse-Coupled Neural Network (PCNN). FCOA introduces a fractional-order calculus mechanism into the original Coati Optimization Algorithm (COA), leveraging its inherent memory characteristics to enhance global search capability and convergence speed. Furthermore, an adaptive order control strategy is proposed, enabling dynamic adjustment of the fractional order during iterations to improve robustness and optimization efficiency. To optimize the key parameters of the PCNN, researchers construct a composite fitness function based on image information entropy and edge matching metrics, effectively capturing both global structure and local edge features. Experimental results from the CEC2005 benchmark suite demonstrate FCOA's superior optimization performance over state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of convergence precision and stability. Moreover, extensive evaluations on the ISIC 2016 skin lesion dataset validate the superior segmentation performance of FCOA-PCNN, which achieved a Dice Coefficient of 92.01% and a Jaccard Index of 85.40%, outperforming both deep learning-based and traditional segmentation methods. Ablation studies further confirm the critical role of fractional-order components in enhancing the segmentation accuracy and model robustness. These findings highlight the potential of FCOA-PCNN as an effective and efficient tool for medical image segmentation applications.
Article Title: Adaptive fractional-order Pulse-Coupled Neural Networks with multi-scale optimization for Skin Image Segmentation

Abstract: Focal cortical dysplasia (FCD) is a congenital malformation of brain development that is the most common cause of intractable epilepsy in adults and children. Automating the identification and segmentation of FCD lesions from magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) volumes is useful for neuroradiologists in pre-surgical evaluations. The prevailing methods in FCD segmentation using two-dimensional (2D) convolutional neural networks (CNNs) largely overlook the potential of utilizing three-dimensional (3D) MRI volumes, thus neglecting the valuable inter-slice information inherent in the MRI volumes. We propose a novel 3D deep learning model employing a multi-view dual encoder-decoder architecture to precisely segment FCD lesions within MRI volumes. Our approach is based on a 3D CNN framework with integrated residual connections, serving as the backbone for the segmentation network. The model also incorporates various architecture-wise enhancements. Firstly, we integrate multi-view training, a concept drawn from the methodology employed by neuro-radiologists when examining 3D MRI volumes. Here, the model processes fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) MRI volumes and their corresponding cortical thickness maps. This information is channeled through a dual-encoder network, wherein the individual encoders are interlinked through a 3D attention mechanism. Additionally, the model implements a dual-decoder stage to facilitate dual-task learning, leveraging the distance map derived from the ground truth data. The model achieved Dice similarity coefficient (DSC) that were 4.8% and 2.3% higher compared to state-of-the-art 2D and 3D FCD segmentation methods, respectively.
Article Title: A dual encoder-decoder multi-task 3D deep learning framework for the segmentation of focal cortical dysplasia lesions

Abstract: Proficiency and expertise are required for radiologists to accurately detect brain tumors, a process that requires a significant amount of time. Deep learning technologies are being used and more to automate the diagnosis of brain tumors, resulting in outcomes that are more precise and efficient compared to previous methods. Attention-based models possess an advanced feature of dynamic refinement and amplification, which improves their diagnostic capabilities. The efficacy of channel, spatial, or combined attention methods in the convolutional block attention module (CBAM) for the classification of brain cancer has not yet been investigated. This study integrated a neural network (CNN) with CBAM to categorize brain cancers by highlighting pertinent characteristics and reducing interference. The model is trained and evaluated on a dataset of 7023 brain MRI images collected from three publicly available sources including Figshare, SARTAJ and Br35H comprising four classes namely glioma, meningioma, pituitary tumor and no tumor. The CBAM-SMK model achieved superior performance compared to other deep learning methods such as conventional CNNs and CNNs enhanced with Sparsity and Multiresolution (SM), with an accuracy of 97. 0%, a recall of 96. 73%, and a precision of 96. 61% on the identical dataset. The fusion of CBAM-SMK has successfully captured the spatial context and enhanced the representation of features. This enables physicians to use it on brain classification software platforms, thus improving clinical decision-making and the classification of brain tumors.
Article Title: CBAM-SMK: Integrating Convolution Block Attention Module with separable multi-resolution kernels in deep neural networks for brain tumor classification

Abstract: Purpose: Computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems have greatly improved the interpretation of medical images by radiologists and surgeons. However, current CAD systems for fracture detection in X-ray images primarily rely on large, resource-intensive detectors, which limits their practicality in clinical settings. To address this limitation, we propose a novel lightweight CAD system based on the YOLO detector for fracture detection. Methods: The proposed system, named ghost convolution-based YOLOv11 (G-YOLOv11), builds on the latest version of the YOLO detector family and incorporates the ghost convolution operation for feature extraction. The ghost convolution operation generates the same number of feature maps as traditional convolution but requires fewer linear operations, thereby reducing the detector's computational resource requirements. The performance of G-YOLOv11 was evaluated on the GRAZPEDWRI-DX dataset using an NVIDIA A10 GPU. Results: The G-YOLOv11 detector achieved an mAP@0.5 of 0.535 with an inference time of 2.4 ms. Compared to the standard YOLOv11l, G-YOLOv11l demonstrated a 13.6% reduction in mAP@0.5 while achieving a substantial 68.7% reduction in model size. Conclusion: The results establish a new state-of-the-art benchmark in efficiency, demonstrating that G-YOLOv11 outperforms existing detectors in terms of computational resource requirements. The proposed system enhances the practicality of CAD-based fracture detection in clinical settings by offering a more lightweight and efficient alternative. Code and models are available at https://github.com/AbdesselamFerdi/G-YOLOv11.
Article Title: Lightweight G-YOLOv11: Advancing efficient fracture detection in pediatric wrist X-rays

Abstract: Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSC) is a common fundus disease characterized by serous retinal detachment in the macular region, which significantly impacts patients' visual function. In recent years, with the continuous development of deep learning and image processing algorithms, remarkable progress has been made in algorithmic research based on CSC OCT images, particularly with a surge of innovative work and outstanding achievements in the areas of classification and segmentation. Through a systematic review of 62 research papers on CSC OCT algorithm development, this article summarizes multi-class algorithms such as binary and three-way classification, as well as algorithm optimization methods. It also reviews segmentation techniques for structures including serous retinal detachment (SRD), pigment epithelial detachment (PED), retinal vasculature, and the choroidal layer. Progress in CSC prediction, assessment, and assisted analysis algorithms is also summarized. Furthermore, the transition from classification to segmentation in CSC OCT algorithms is analyzed, along with the challenges and limitations in this research field. This review aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the current state and future directions of CSC OCT image algorithm research for investigators in this domain.
Article Title: Review: Algorithmic advances in central serous chorioretinopathy OCT: From classification to segmentation

Abstract: Background and objective: Auditory brainstem response (ABR) is routinely used in clinical practice for objective hearing assessment, yet its visual interpretation is subjective and time-consuming. This study aims to propose a novel and interpretable deep learning (DL) model, CWT-ViT, based on time-frequency analysis to objectively detect ABR using large-scale and diverse clinical datasets. Methods: ABR waveforms are transformed into time-frequency images via continuous wavelet transform (CWT). The proposed CWT-ViT model captures clinically relevant features for ABR detection, trained and evaluated on a large clinical dataset, and externally validated on an independent cohort with varying equipment and protocols. Gradient-weighted class activation mapping (Grad-CAM) and SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) methods are used to interpret the model's decisions. Results: CWT-ViT achieves 91.83% accuracy and an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) of 0.976 on the held-out test set, and 93.54% accuracy and an AUC of 0.976 on the independent dataset, outperforming several state-of-the-art methods. Grad-CAM and SHAP visualizations reveal that peak V and its subsequent negative slope are crucial for ABR detection, while peak III also aids detection in cases where peak V is less evident, aligning with established medical knowledge. Conclusion: The proposed CWT-ViT demonstrates robust performance across diverse clinical settings, providing a reliable and interpretable tool for ABR detection. This framework could streamline clinical workflows and enhance diagnostic accuracy in hearing assessments.
Article Title: An interpretable deep learning framework based on time-frequency analysis for automated auditory brainstem response detection

Abstract: Globally, cardiovascular disease causes heart attacks and strokes that threaten human life. The development is due to risk factors like physical inactivity, smoking, and unhealthy diets etc. In the majority of heart disorders, early detection of the disease results in extended patients' lives and permanent recovery. Moreover, the quick and accurate prediction of heart disease utilizing deep learning models is crucial. However, the existing techniques failed to accurately analyzethe massive data, ignored the security impacts, and required more training time. Consequently, the integration of key technologies such as the Internet of Things (IoT) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) transformed the traditional healthcare system into an advanced Healthcare Monitoring system. Hence, this research proposes the IoT-Driven Smart Cardiac Health Monitoring utilizing the Interactive Hunt optimized Deep Convolutional Neural Network (IntHDCNN), which assesses the patient data from the heart disease database, captures the intricate disease patterns from the input cardiac data. Further, the utilization of Interactive Hunt optimization optimally tuning the IntHDCNN model, which boosted the prediction performance. Besides, the inclusion of the Modified Attribute-based Diffie-Hellman (MAtr-DH) Algorithm facilitates data security within the healthcare monitoring environment. Moreover, the incorporation of IoT and Deep Learning predictive analytics ensures the accurate and timely prediction of cardiac diseases, crucial for providing medical emergency services for people at risk. More specifically, the evaluation results show that the proposed model achieves high efficiency with an accuracy of 96.92%, sensitivity of 97.11%, and specificity of 97.12% using the DSCH Database, which can be used for smart healthcare monitoring systems.
Article Title: IntHDCNN: IoT-driven remote cardiac health monitoring with interactive hunt-based deep convolutional neural network

Abstract: Anterior Segment Optical Coherence Tomography (AS-OCT) images can capture clearly the lens nucleus region and quantitatively measure the opacity of nuclear cataracts (NC), which is of great significance for clinicians to grade the pathological changes of NC. Clinical studies have shown that the severity of NC is positively correlated with the opacity of the nucleus, and the opacity changes progressively and continuously, resulting in low interclass variance and increasing the difficulty of accurate grading. To address these challenges, we propose a novel fine-grained network (CDRFF-Net) with ordinal regression to diagnose the severity of NC using AS-OCT images. The network consists of a complemental discriminative region extractor (CDRE) block and a graph-enhanced feature fusion (GFF) module. Specifically, to fully exploit the features of discriminative regions, we propose the CDRE block to extract the most salient discriminative region features as well as those less obvious but equally important regional features, thereby obtaining complementary discriminative region features. Subsequently, the GFF module aggregates these two parts of features while avoiding redundant information, thus effectively fusing these features. Consequently, our network can focus on discriminative region features, thereby improving the classification accuracy of NC. Additionally, to fully utilize the ordinal nature of NC grading, we incorporate soft labels containing ordinal information between classes in the loss function, instead of the commonly used one-hot labels in NC grading. Experiments on a local clinical AS-OCT dataset and two public datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of our proposed method.
Article Title: Complementary discriminative region feature fusion network with ordinal regression for fine-grained nuclear cataract grading in AS-OCT images

Abstract: Deep learning-based pathological image classification has emerged as a promising tool to aid pathologists in diagnostics. However, two critical challenges hinder its accuracy and generalization: noisy labels in datasets due to annotation errors or subjective judgments, and unique image characteristics such as multiscale textures and staining variations. This study aims to address these challenges by proposing a novel framework that combines noise-robust learning and feature-specific attention mechanisms. A noise-resistant algorithm integrating noisy sample self-screening and hard sample color normalization (NSS-HSCN) was proposed, along with a dual-stream spatial and texture attention (DSSTA) framework. In the NSS-HSCN stage, a self-screening network filtered out noisy samples, and hard samples were subjected to color normalization. The DSSTA framework utilized a multi-scale spatial attention module and a texture-enhanced attention module to extract and fuse features. Experiments were carried out on the Chaoyang and HITAFH datasets. The method outperformed other leading methods on both datasets. On the Chaoyang and HITAFH datasets, our method achieved 86.02% and 90.16% accuracy, respectively, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in all metrics. Grad-CAM visualization verified the model's ability to focus on target areas and extract valuable features. The noise-screening network strengthened model robustness, and the dual-stream network effectively integrated features. Integration with the automated diagnostic system optimized the diagnostic process, thereby highlighting its potential for improving pathological image classification accuracy in real-world applications.
Article Title: Self-screening of noisy labels and hard sample color normalization in histopathology image classification with spatial-texture attention networks

Abstract: Objective: Neurovascular coupling (NVC) assessed through amplitude-integrated electroencephalography (aEEG) and near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) has emerged as a potential biomarker for evaluating and predicting prognosis in neonatal encephalopathy (NE). However, existing studies are mostly single-center, focusing on moderate-severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE). We aim to find early NVC markers for NE assessment and prognostic prediction. Methods: In this study, we conducted a prospective multicenter study in Ningxia, selecting the highest-volume childbirth centers from five cities, covering all regions of Ningxia. Neonates with GA >= 35 weeks and highrisk factors for NE were enrolled. Continuous 6-hour monitoring of EEG (C3 to C4 were analyzed) and NIRS began within 6 h of birth. Wavelet coherence was used to analyze NVC. Finally, we explored the frequency bands with significant differences in NVC and its utility in NE assessment and prediction of MRI abnormality at 7-14 days. Results: This study enrolled 72 neonates, including 33 without NE and 39 with NE, of which 29 had HIE (21 mild, 8 moderate to severe) and 10 had ICH. Significant NVC differences could be detectable within 6 h of monitoring. Evaluating NE and its severity of the enrolled neonates, within the frequency range of 1.5-2 mHz, decreased NVC showed superior sensitivity for NE evaluation (87.5 % vs. 62.5 %) and MRI injury prediction (90.0 % vs 70.0 %) at 7-14 days compared to the use of aEEG alone. Conclusion: This multicenter study on use of NVC in NE highlighted its potential for better identifying and assessing NE severity in at-risk neonates within 6 h of birth.
Article Title: Neurovascular coupling as a novel biomarker for neonatal encephalopathy A multicenter clinical study

Abstract: Colorectal Cancer (CRC) has become the second deadliest cancer in women and the third most hazardous ailment for men. Owing to the rapid increase in cases of the disease, diagnosis and detection play a major role in the medical industry, helping practitioners treat patients without delay. To attain personalized treatment, predictive and prognostic biomarker data should be considered to optimize the disease detection process. During the assessment of biomarkers, inter-and intra-variability are included in the pathology laboratory to achieve the appropriate image representation. Conversely, multiple methods have been developed and implemented for disease identification. The image format of Whole Slide Images (WSI) is considered due to its high resolution. However, informative annotated features are not analyzed by prior models. The advent of deep learning models helps address existing issues when designing a model for CRC detection. To address the researcher's challenges, an innovative CRC detection framework using deep learning techniques along with a heuristic algorithm is proposed. Initially, the images required for the experiment are gathered from a standard database. After the image collection, the Adaptive Vision Transformer-based Multi-scale Recurrent Dilated Densenet (AViT-MRDD) is used to perform the detection process. Moreover, the parameters in the AViT-MRDD are optimized using the Position Revised Nuclear Reaction Optimization (PRNRO). Numerous baseline techniques are adopted to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed model over other models. The comparison of the developed PRNRO-ViT-MRDD model with several existing models, and demonstrates its superior performance across different datasets. In Dataset 1, the accuracy of the proposed PRNRO-ViT-MRDD is 94.33%. Similarly, in Dataset 2, the accuracy is 96.16%, highlighting the consistent and superior accuracy of the model. These results provide strong evidence that PRNRO-ViT-MRDD delivers better performance in terms of accuracy, making it a more reliable and effective model for colorectal cancer detection compared to other established methodologies in the field. It also highlights the potential of integrating deep learning techniques like ViT with advanced optimization strategies, offering a compelling alternative to traditional methods.
Article Title: An efficient colorectal cancer detection model using adaptive vision transformer-based multi-scale recurrent dilated DenseNet integrating with histopathological data

Abstract: In medical sector, the medical image registration is the significant approach for managing multiple medical images, volume, and surface in the coordinate system. In medical images, discovering a precise match between multi-modal images is still difficult because distinct image modalities are obtained by various acquisition techniques. Based on their different properties, it receives an incorrect registered output. To tackle these problems, this research work introduces an adaptive deep-learning method for accurate image registration using patient data. The proposed work is processed in two phases like image collection and image registration. Firstly, the real patient scan image is collected from the publically available data resource and then subjected to an image registration process. For the image registration process, the new model is suggested named as Adaptive Transformer-Unet with Multi-Dilated Convolution (ATUN-MDC) for offering superior performance. The adaptation of the proposed model is integrated with the Transformer and U-Net model along with the multi-dilated convolution layer. This network processes the multi-modal image registration that shows precise outcome promptly. For further enhancement, the hyper-parameters present in the model are tuned by Iteration-based Walrus Optimization Algorithm (IWOA). Finally, the proposed model is compared with another conventional model to know the efficiency of the result. This result analysis shows the developed model offers effective performance when compared with other classical methods. Hence, the PSNR achieves a higher value than 6.97% of DDMReg, 11.7% of CNN, and 5.98% of HCN, respectively. Therefore, the simulation analysis helps the designed method offer better performance.
Article Title: ATUN-MDC image registration: Performance enhancement of medical image registration using adaptive TransUNet with multi-dilated convolution model

Abstract: The field of sports action recognition has attracted substantial interest recently because of the growing requirements for automated video analysis in training sessions and performance assessments as well as broadcast media. The present research develops a strong action recognition system for football (soccer) through the implementation of cutting-edge machine learning and computer vision methods. Our research focuses on categorizing basic football actions like passing and kicking utilizing open datasets SoccerNet and Sports-1 M. The research uses pre-trained deep learning models such as Inflated 3D Convolutional Neural Networks (I3D) and Temporal Segment Networks (TSN) which have been fine-tuned with football video data to effectively detect spatiotemporal patterns. We improve action detection accuracy by combining pose estimation methods with a multi-stage feature extraction process. Our approach achieves high recognition accuracy across multiple actions as shown by experimental results which demonstrate potential applications in match analysis, player performance monitoring, and coaching support. Our research advances sports analytics through an innovative approach to tackle football's action variability problems while delivering a scalable automated action recognition system.
Article Title: Deep learning-based spatiotemporal action recognition in football using I3D and TSN with pose estimation

Abstract: Emotions are a way through which people express their internal states, and good emotion recognition involves correctly identifying and interpreting these emotional expressions. It helps us to better understand the emotions of others, thus helping them to get better emotional value. Voice emotion recognition, as an inseparable part of emotion recognition, aims to perform voice emotion recognition by voice parameters using either existing publicly available datasets or homemade datasets, where the voice itself contains both speech and non-verbal parts. In this paper, a correlated positive feature vector for non-verbal emotion recognition is presented. The IEMOCAP dataset, the group of feature vectors meaningful for non-verbal emotion recognition is identified by improving the support vector machine correlation algorithm, combined with the weighted average weight calculation. The full-dimensional feature vectors are examined by combining the metrics of recall and accuracy. Thus, the positive direction three-dimensional feature vectors are filtered. Thirteen-dimensional MFCC 86.6%, F0 90.8%, and entropy value 80.1% of the three-dimensional positive direction feature vectors. These works can help to give direction to the subsequent work on feature vector extraction for non-verbal emotion recognition.
Article Title: An exploration of feature vectors based on non-verbal emotion recognition

Abstract: Ischemic Heart Disease (IHD) stands as the leading cause of mortality worldwide, underscoring its critical status as a significant global health challenge. Early detection is crucial for effective treatment and improved patient survival rates. This review paper examines advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), specifically machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL), for the detection and diagnosis of Ischemic Heart Disease (IHD), a leading global cause of mortality. The analysis, guided by the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) framework, focuses on the accuracy, clinical feasibility, and potential of AI to improve global healthcare outcomes by integrating various data sources. These sources include clinical records, medical imaging modalities such as Electrocardiogram (ECG), Magnetocardiography (MCG), Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), and Coronary Computed Tomography Angiography (CCTA), as well as data from wearable sensors. The findings highlight AI's capacity for accurate IHD detection but underscore the necessity of overcoming challenges related to data quality, model overfitting, clinical acceptance, and patient privacy to facilitate wider adoption and realize the full potential of AI in transforming cardiovascular healthcare and patient outcomes.
Article Title: Data-driven based approaches for early diagnosis of Ischemic Heart Disease (IHD): A review of recent advancements, challenges, and opportunities

Abstract: Sleep apnea (SA) is a typical sleep disorder that, if untreated, can lead to severe health complications. Snoring is a key symptom of SA and can be used to develop a non-contact automatic SA detection method. However, due to inter-subject variability, the acoustic characteristics of snoring can vary significantly across individuals. This inter-subject variability poses a significant challenge for model generalization and often leads to degraded performance when applied to unseen subjects. To address this challenge, we propose an unsupervised domain adaptation framework based on Wasserstein Generative Adversarial Network (WGAN) and introduce a lightweight Subject-Invariant Feature Refiner (SIFR) module. A two-stage training strategy is adopted. In the first stage, we pretrain a feature extractor, which integrates CNN and Transformer Encoder, using snoring data of existing subjects to extract a generalized snoring feature representation. In the second stage, the pretrained feature extractor is frozen. The SIFR module is introduced and combined with adversarial training to conduct domain adaptation with a small amount of unlabeled data from new subjects. We evaluate the model performance on three main SA-related tasks: SA event detection, SA patient diagnosis, and Apnea-Hypopnea Index (AHI) estimation. On the subject-independent dataset, our model achieves 74.24% accuracy in SA event detection and 83.59% accuracy in SA patient diagnosis. For AHI estimation, our model achieves a mean absolute error (MAE) of 10.430 and a Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC) of 0.86, indicating a strong correlation between the estimated and real AHI values. This study provides an effective solution for SA detection in new subjects in practical applications.
Article Title: Learning generalizable representations with adversarial domain adaptation for snoring-based sleep apnea detection

Abstract: Accurate brain tumor segmentation from multi-modal MRI is critical for clinical diagnosis and treatment planning, yet remains challenging due to large variations in tumor size, shape, and location, as well as the hierarchical relationship among whole tumor (WT), tumor core (TC), and enhancing tumor (ET). In this paper, we argue that instead of statically dividing the model into three parts for one-shot segmentation, the entire model should dynamically focus on each of the three spatially-related tumor targets progressively, using their distinct features. To this end, we propose a novel Target-aware Self Region-prompting Network (TSRNet), the first framework to introduce prompt-based learning into brain tumor segmentation. TSRNet incorporates two key modules: (1) a Static-Task-Prompt (STP) that dynamically activates target-specific feature channels and spatial regions based on preset textual prompts, and (2) a Self-Region-Prompt (SRP) that progressively segments WT, TC, and ET by explicitly leveraging their natural inclusion relationships. Extensive experiments on two public datasets (BraTS2021 and BraTS2020) and an in-house clinical dataset (Xiehe) demonstrate that TSRNet consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods. TSRNet achieves average Dice scores of 91.24%, 89.97%, and 88.41% on the three datasets, respectively, with fewer false positives in highly entangled subregions such as TC and ET. TSRNet effectively combines prompt learning with progressive target-aware segmentation, offering improved accuracy and robustness across different datasets. The proposed approach has strong potential to support real-world clinical applications such as neurosurgical planning, radiotherapy, and tumor growth monitoring.
Article Title: TSRNet: Target-aware Self Region-prompting Network for brain tumor segmentation

Abstract: Pilot control intentions reflect the subjective desire to manipulate aircraft attitude through specific maneuvers. Accurate recognition of pilot control intentions is crucial for the development of autopilot systems and active safety technologies in flight control. A significant challenge arises from the similarity in workload between takeoff and landing, which complicates the identification of climb and descent intentions. This paper proposes an approach using a spatial attention EEGNet (SA-EEGNet) to identify pilot control intentions based on electroencephalography (EEG) signals. To address issues related to convolutional kernel sharing and network complexity, receptive field attention and spatial convolution were incorporated to enhance feature extraction and reduce redundancy. Designed for three-class classification, SA-EEGNet achieves 95% accuracy in subjectdependent data (5-fold cross-validation) and 93% accuracy in subject-independent data (7-fold cross-validation).
Article Title: A pilot control intention recognition method based on EEG in simulated flights

Abstract: Early detection of Atrial Fibrillation (AF) is crucial foreventing severe complications such as angina pectoris, thromboembolism, and even sudden cardiac death. Most existing studies utilizing deep learning techniques to extract electrocardiogram (ECG) automatic features for AF detection still suffer from weakened local feature characterization and insufficient analysis of potential AF signatures during sinus rhythm (SR) intervals. To address these limitations, this study proposes an AF detection method integrating Multi-Scale Bands and Spatio-Temporal features of ECG signals. Multi-scale waveform extraction and re-annotation of AF patients are performed through ECG preprocessing. A multi-scale convolutional network is employed to capture the morphological features of P-waves and QRS complexes. At the same time, a long short-term memory (LSTM)+Transformer architecture is utilized to model the spatio-temporal dependencies in ECG sequences. The hybrid cross-feature fusion strategy enhances the synergistic representation between atrial and ventricle activities, enabling the detection of latent AF precursors within SR segments while focusing on fibrillatory rhythms. Experiments conducted on multi-source databases demonstrate that the MSB-ST framework achieves state-of-the-art performance, with accuracy (98.98%), sensitivity (99.48%), and F1-score (98.99%). This approach provides a highly robust automated solution for early AF detection, effectively addressing the limitations of conventional methods in multi-scale feature extraction and nonlinear spatio-temporal relationship modeling.
Article Title: Atrial fibrillation detection method combining multi-scale bands and spatio-temporal features of ECG

Abstract: In the event of pain, the autonomic nervous system reacts by affecting different physiological parameters such as blood pressure, heart rate, skin conductance, and perspiration levels, among others. This research presents an innovative approach to pain intensity recognition through a multimodal system that fuses bio-information from the skin (Electrodermal Activity or EDA) and heart (Photoplethysmograph or PPG) signals. The study involved a self-collected dataset from 61 healthy participants and encompassed two pain intensity levels (low and high) experienced at different anatomical locations (hand and forearm). Employing IIR bandpass filters, the collected EDA and PPG signals were preprocessed. A novel feature extraction method named Ternary Textures of Derivatives (TTD) is proposed, which, when fused with statistical features, exhibited robust potential as a pain intensity biomarker. Feature selection using Joint Mutual Information preceded the utilisation of an Ensemble classifier. The developed multimodal fusion-based pain recognition system outperformed the unimodal (PPG and EDA) approaches by achieving notable accuracies: 83.1%+/- 8.8% for No Pain vs. Low Pain, 87.1%+/- 6.7% for No Pain vs. High Pain, and 74.5%+/- 6.8% for the No Pain vs. Low Pain vs. High Pain scenario. This approach offers an objective means of pain assessment that can furnish valuable insights to clinical teams, aiding in treatment evaluation, surgical decision-making, and overall patient care quality assessment.
Article Title: Pain intensity estimation via multimodal fusion: Leveraging ternary textures of derivatives in EDA and PPG signals

Abstract: Breast cancer has become the most significant form of cancer that affects women around the globe. Recently, several sophisticated Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) techniques have been created to aid in the development of a successful strategy for identifying and categorizing this severe form of cancer. However, there are several drawbacks to the current DL models, including low accuracy and ineffective feature extraction. Therefore, the proposed work introduced an Attention Integrated EfficientNet with depth-wise dilated separable convolution (AttIn-EffD2SepC) Network to perform the classification process on mammogram images. Initially, the input images are augmented by performing the Rotation, Cropping, and Flipping on the dataset, and then it is pre-processed using the Hybrid non-local Bilateral Filtering (HNBF) technique to remove the noises. To extract the hand-crafted features, two feature extraction techniques are used: Windmill Graph (WG) and Bi-dimensional Multi-scale Entropy (BiMsE) methods. Then, deep features are extracted using the InceptionV3 network. The Attention-based Feature Pyramid Fusion model (Att-FpF) is used to fuse the extracted features, and the AttInEffD2SepC model given the fused features to complete the classification process. The performance of the proposed network is evaluated using the INBreast and Curated Breast Imaging Subset-Digital Database for Screening Mammography (CBIS-DDSM) datasets. By using this proposed classification algorithm, higher classification accuracy will be accomplished with a lower error rate. The proposed method achieved 99.59% and 99.82% accuracy in the INBreast and CBIS-DDSM datasets, respectively. Thus, the proposed work outperforms other existing works.
Article Title: Automated breast cancer classification using a hybrid deep learning framework with attention-integrated EfficientNet

Abstract: Background: Early detection of sub-health mental states in college students is critical for timely intervention but remains challenging due to subtle neural signals. This study aimed to classify distinct mental health states (healthy, sub-healthy, abnormal) by integrating functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) signal processing with machine learning framework. Method: A total of 292 participants completed resting-state (Rest), verbal fluency (VFT), and emotional Stroop (PStroop, NStroop) tasks during fNIRS acquisition. Temporal and network topological features were extracted from whole-brain signals. Following preprocessing and feature selection, an adaptive stacking ensemble model using a one-vs-all strategy was developed and optimized via 10-fold nested cross-validation. A multi-layer perceptron ensemble served as the prediction assessment. SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) were applied to enhance model interpretability. Results: In single-task classification, the PStroop task achieved a balanced accuracy of 0.92. For multi-task classification, the Rest & VFT and Rest & PStroop combination yield the best performance, with a balanced accuracy of 0.94. SHAP revealed task-specific potential biomarkers (e.g., prefrontal hyperactivity in sub-healthy states). Limitations: The reliance on single modality fNIRS data and sampling from a single site may limit the generalizability. Future work should validate findings using multimodal and multi-site datasets. Conclusion: This study demonstrates that integration of fNIRS with adaptive machine learning approaches provides a scalable and interpretable framework for mental health classification, enhancing the detection of subhealth states-a key target for preventive mental healthcare.
Article Title: A cross-task fNIRS framework for multi-class mental health classification using adaptive stacking of temporal and network topological features

Abstract: Purpose: Accurate detection of fiducial points in electrocardiograms (ECG) is crucial for diagnosing heart diseases. However, traditional ECG devices require direct contact with the skin, which can cause discomfort for patients. Therefore, there is an increasing need for non-contact detection of ECG fiducial points, while research in this area remains limited. Methods: In response to this need, we proposed a millimeter-wave radar-based method for non-contact detection of ECG fiducial points. Initially, fiducial points from synchronously acquired ECG signals were annotated to serve as labels for network training. Subsequently, a radar cardiogram (RCG) was derived from radar radio frequency signals using a second-order differentiator. To enhance the detection process, we developed a one-dimensional semantic segmentation model by integrating a deep residual shrinkage network block (DRSN) into the U-Net architecture, which we term DRSN-Unet. Results: The results from the testing dataset demonstrate that the proposed method accurately detects the five fiducial points, achieving an average precision of 0.986, an average recall of 0.986, and an average F1-score of 0.986. Notably, the network's parameter count is only 2.042 Mega, with a computation amount of 0.086 GFLOPs. Conclusion: This method effectively detects the onsets of the P-wave and QRS complex, the peak of the Rwave, and the offsets of the QRS complex and T-wave without direct contact with the human body, laying a solid foundation for the automated diagnosis of complex cardiac diseases.
Article Title: Non-contact detection of electrocardiogram fiducial points with millimeter-wave radar

Abstract: Purpose: Classical compressed sensing magnetic resonance imaging (CSMRI) utilizes an open-loop architecture from subsampling Fourier components to reconstruction images. High-quality recovery images have always been the pursuit of CSMRI because under-sampling results in the quality degradation of restoration images. Method: According to the theory of automatic control, a closed-loop framework achieves superior dynamic and static performance compared with the open-loop counterpart. This paper proposes a closed-loop infrastructure, circular CSMRI (CCSMRI), to enhance the quality of reconstruction images. The proposed CCSMRI contains three critical modules: front-path, reconstruction and subsampling. The front-path module implements traditional proportional-integral control. The proposed architecture is described by a nonlinear loop equation and the stability is proven by matrix representation-based Taylor series approximation. Findings: The stability of the proposed framework holds ideal and practical conditions and the steady-state error is close to zero. The strategy of Plug-and-Play enables the reconstruction module takes advantage of any existing advanced open-loop CSMRI algorithms. Results: Experimental results on six open datasets and diverse subsampling trajectories show that the proposed method outperforms eight state-ot-the-art model-based and learning-based CSMRI algorithms in the performance of image reconstruction. The maximum increments of peak signal-to-noise ratio and structural similarity are respectively more than 5 dB and 0.2. Conclusions: The proposed method can dramatically improve the quality of image recovery on various MRI datasets and subsampling trajectories. The proposed CCSMRI will upgrade the accuracy of MRI-based clinical diagnosis by providing high-quality MRI reconstruction images.
Article Title: CCSMRI: Circular compressed sensing MRI

Abstract: Electrocardiogram (ECG) processing systems based on deep learning offer potential for advanced cardiac analysis. However, these systems often encounter significant challenges, such as the scarcity of labeled data, which affects their performance, reliability, and integration into clinical practice. This study aims to address these challenges by proposing an Active Learning (AL) methodology to optimize data labeling, reducing annotation effort while improving model performance. We evaluate the AL approach across three distinct applications: (1) sinus rhythm beat classification using synthetic data; (2) clinical severity of noise classification with a long-term ECG monitoring repository acquired under real conditions; and (3) cardiac wave delineation using a gold-standard dataset with expert annotations from the publicly available PhysioNet QT Database (QTDB) and the Lobachevsky University ECG Database (LUDB). In each classification task, our proposed AL framework integrates a neural network based on an autoencoder that generates a visualizable latent space for explainability into the decision-making process. The system iteratively selects the most informative instances using a margin sampling strategy in the latent space and incorporates them into the training process to refine performance. Results demonstrate that the AL approach consistently outperforms random sample selection in precision, recall, and F1-score. Additionally, ECG in-line analysis shows that models trained with the AL strategy outperform those from previous studies, even when trained on smaller subsets of the experimental datasets. This approach can reduce the labeling workload of clinicians, helping to efficiently increase labeled data, improve model performance, foster confidence in decision support systems, and advance ECG analysis applications.
Article Title: Active learning in latent spaces for long-term ECG monitoring: Morphology and rhythm analysis

Abstract: Previous research on the dynamic interactions between the brain and the heart during sleep has mainly focused on phasic cortical events, such as arousals and K-complexes. However, little is known about spontaneous and continuous brain-heart coupling during sleep. The current study investigated the instantaneous phase-phase synchronization of cardiac cycles with brain electrical activity across sleep stages, without relying on internal or external events as triggers. Electrocardiography (ECG) and electroencephalography (EEG) data from ten neurosurgical patients during different sleep stages were utilized. EEG was recorded from intracranial hippocampal and neocortical electrodes, as well as from scalp electrodes. EEG phase was computed using complex wavelet analysis, and ECG phase was modeled based on the R-peaks. Phase-phase synchronization was quantified within 10-s windows for coupling factors of 1: m, where m (ranging from 1 to 10) is the multiplier for the ECG phase. Surrogate data were employed to ensure that the observed synchronization was physiological rather than random. The findings demonstrate statistically robust EEG-ECG synchronization within the delta, theta and alpha EEG bands across different brain sites. phase-phase coupling was stronger in scalp EEG than in intracranially recorded EEG signals. The predominant EEG coupling frequency was significantly lower during N2 sleep compared to the waking state, indicating sleep-dependent modulation of EEG-ECG phase-phase coupling.
Article Title: Assessment of central and cardiac oscillatory phase-phase coupling during sleep

Abstract: Background: Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) is a major cause of childhood blindness worldwide, particularly affecting premature infants. Early diagnosis is critical to prevent irreversible vision loss. Objective: This study aims to develop an automated, non-invasive system for early ROP risk classification using advanced deep learning techniques. Problem: Conventional ROP screening relies heavily on expert ophthalmologists and invasive diagnostic methods, which are resource-intensive and not always feasible in low-resource settings. Methodology: This study proposes a novel deep learning framework combining Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) units, and an attention mechanism referred to as the CNN-LSTM-Attention model to classify infants as high-risk or low-risk for ROP. Model performance is evaluated using Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curves and Area Under the Curve (AUC) metrics. Findings: The proposed CNN-LSTM-Attention model achieved an AUC of 73%, significantly outperforming traditional methods, which yielded an AUC of 63%. This indicates enhanced capability in accurately identifying infants with normal vision and detecting those at high risk for ROP. Conclusion: The model demonstrates strong potential as a non-invasive and scalable tool for early ROP detection, reducing dependence on specialized medical personnel. Recommendations: Future work should focus on expanding the dataset, incorporating additional clinical features, and validating the model across diverse populations to further improve its accuracy and generalizability.
Article Title: Early detection of retinopathy of prematurity using a CNN-LSTM-attention model: A non-invasive risk classification approach

Abstract: Background and Problem Formulation: To handle huge data for diagnosis of data, Medical healthcare centers are recognized as an advantageous construction. Medical data privacy is in danger as in the case of traditional machine learning algorithms. These algorithms faced challenges in securing data from leakage. Federated learning ensures privacy while contextualizing critical data to protect user information in smart healthcare. Methods: This paper proposes a novel Blockchain based federated learning approach to network security analysis using blockchain and Federated learning to enhance data privacy and integrity in healthcare IoT environments. Initially, the gathered Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) data is fed as input to the novel Blockchain based federated learning. This method involves Cluster-Based Aggregation Scheme at the edge node to effectively detect and mitigate faults. To ensure the confidentiality of the model parameters and client data, a mutual key agreement is incorporated. The implementation of a secure common session key computation and mutual authentication paradigm enables secure communication between data owners and recipients. Using blockchain, global updates are managed and propagated to offer a transparent, tamper-proof, and decentralized mechanism. Furthermore, it explores discrete-time continuous-dilation wavelet transforms and quantum neural networks for data processing and analysis, showcasing their potential to enhance security and efficiency in cloud network environments. By leveraging discrete-time continuous-dilation wavelet transforms, healthcare data can be processed in a way that preserves its integrity while safeguarding it against unauthorized access. By combining the principles of quantum computing and neural networks, quantum neural networks process and analyze complex healthcare data with unparalleled efficiency and accuracy. Results: At last, the superiority of the proposed method is highlighted by performing comparative analyses in terms of accuracy, precision, recall, F1-measure, latency, and throughput. The results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves high reliability in securing healthcare data and is superior to existing techniques. Conclusion: The efficacy of the proposed method is ensured, displaying that it can enhance the security of data, and minimize drawbacks related to traditional healthcare data-sharing approach. Therefore, the combination of federated learning, blockchain, and edge computing offers an extensive solution to share healthcare information securely. Significance of the achieved results:: The achieved results are highly significant and demonstrate the robustness and effectiveness of the Blockchain-based Federated Learning approach in securing IoT healthcare systems. The achieved accuracy value of 98.73% indicates that the proposed model is highly reliable in making correct predictions. The achieved high precision (98.62%) ensures the ability of the proposed model to minimize false positive rates to reduce unnecessary alarms and interventions. The obtained high recall value of 98.23% is essential to minimize missed diagnoses. High throughput is essential to process more data. The low latency indicates a quick response of the proposed model, and it is essential to monitor emergency cases.
Article Title: A novel blockchain-federated learning framework with quantum neural networks and wavelet transforms for secure IoT healthcare monitoring

Abstract: Surface electromyography (sEMG) signals provide rich information about muscle activity and human motion, and have been widely employed in wearable systems for gesture recognition and human-machine interaction. However, commercially available sEMG armbands often exhibit limited hardware performance, constrained recognition capabilities, or come at a very high cost. To overcome these limitations, we present the alpha Armband, a high-performance wireless sEMG acquisition device. It features 16 recording channels, a 12-bit analog-to-digital converter, and an adjustable sampling rate of up to 2000 Hz per channel, covering a broad bandwidth of 2-1000 Hz. The device supports low-power Bluetooth communication, configurable acquisition parameters, and is cost-controlled at approximately 150 USD. To validate its performance, sEMG data were collected from the forearms of 25 subjects performing ten distinct hand gestures. Classification was evaluated using three algorithmic approaches: support vector machines (SVM), convolutional neural networks (CNN) based on time-domain features, and CNN based on spectrum-domain features. The alpha Armband achieved an overall classification accuracy of up to 87 % for the ten hand gestures, demonstrating robust signal quality and practical applicability. The primary contribution of this work lies in the development of the alpha Armband. Its enhanced hardware specifications and reliable signal acquisition demonstrate significant potential for advancing wearable sEMG systems in gesture recognition and human-machine interaction domains.
Article Title: A wearable electromyography armband for gesture recognition

Abstract: Background: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a progressive respiratory condition with significant global health implications. Abnormal lung sounds are key indicators of lung diseases, and their analysis offers potential for early and accurate diagnosis. This study introduces a deep learning framework for diagnosing COPD using lung auscultation sounds, addressing challenges like imbalanced datasets and differential diagnosis. Methods: Lung sound recordings were obtained from the International Conference on Biomedical and Health Informatics and King Abdullah University Hospital databases. Preprocessing steps included resampling, denoising using the Butterworth filter and empirical mode decomposition, and extracting Mel spectrograms as features. A Vision Transformer-based spectrogram model (ViT-S1) was used to classify lung sounds into COPD, healthy, and non-COPD. Additionally, data augmentation was performed using Vector Quantized Variational Autoencoder-2 (VQVAE-2) to address dataset imbalance. Results: The ViT-S1 model without data augmentation achieved a sensitivity of 0.9171, specificity of 0.8390, and an F1-score of 0.9094. After applying VQVAE-2 for data augmentation, these metrics improved significantly, with the model achieving a sensitivity of 0.9659, specificity of 0.9631, F1-score of 0.9662, and AUC of 0.9896. Conclusions: This study proposes a non-invasive, portable deep learning framework for diagnosing COPD with auscultation lung sound, offering accurate early detection and differential diagnosis. The results demonstrate that the performance of the classification model is significantly enhanced through the application of data augmentation, highlighting its potential for accurate and reliable COPD detection in clinical settings.
Article Title: Diagnosis of Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease based on deep learning and auscultation lung sound

Abstract: Breast cancer continues to be one of the most perilous diseases, necessitating precise and prompt detection for effective intervention. Despite the potential of deep learning approaches in mammogram-based diagnosis, they encounter ongoing obstacles such as dataset imbalance, data scarcity, subpar synthetic augmentation, and duplicate feature inclusion, all of which diminish detection performanc
Article Title: Adaptive deep Q-GAN framework for enhanced breast cancer detection in medical imaging

Abstract: Efficient and accurate identification, localization, and segmentation of polyp tissues are critical steps in colonoscopy, essential for the prevention and early intervention of colorectal cancer. Current CNN-based methods are limited in modeling long-range dependencies while transformer-based methods cannot capture sufficient contextual dependencies. Hybrid networks are prone to overfitting the convolutional features, leading to the dispersion of attention in the Transformer. Addressing the existing issues, we propose an approach for polyp segmentation with Hierarchical Interworking Decoder (HID) that fully utilizes hierarchical features to establish multi-scale discriminative criteria. HID leverages Interworking Attention Module (IAM) to refine single-level features, where the globally shared attention mechanism in IAM concurrently integrates affinity information from all different hierarchical features, facilitating global information exchange. Adjacent Aggregation Module (AAM) to refine and integrate adjacent-level features. Through the refinement of single-level features and the integration of different-level features, HID simultaneously captures global information and local contextual information. Extensive experiments demonstrate that HID exhibits outstanding generalization performance and achieves state-of-the-art accuracy on multiple polyp segmentation benchmarks.
Article Title: Polyp segmentation for colonoscopy images via Hierarchical Interworking Decoding

Abstract: Surface electromyography (sEMG)-based control systems offer a promising hands-free interface for individuals with severe motor impairments, enabling intuitive operation of assistive mobility devices. However, generating a large number of reliable control commands using a minimal number of electrodes remains a significant challenge. This study introduces a novel dual-movement classification strategy that utilizes sEMG signals from only three neck muscles-right trapezius, left trapezius, and left sternocleidomastoid-to generate nine distinct control commands. Data were collected from 29 able-bodied participants and one polio-affected individual with severe upper and lower limb impairments. The able-bodied participants were evaluated under subject-independent conditions, while the polio-affected participant was assessed under both subject-independent and subject-dependent settings to simulate real-world usage. The raw sEMG signals were decomposed using Empirical Mode Decomposition (EMD), and a Genetic Algorithm (GA) was applied for feature selection. A k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN) classifier was used for classification. The proposed system achieved similar to 99 % accuracy using similar to 20 GA-selected features, compared to similar to 97 % using all 48 features. For the polio-affected participant, the system achieved 100 % accuracy under the subject-dependent method even without GA. With GA, it reached 100 % accuracy under both subject-dependent and independent conditions. These results demonstrate the system's efficiency, robustness, and generalizability. By enabling nine reliable control commands using only three non-invasive, this work significantly advances the development of practical, scalable sEMG-based assistive technologies.
Article Title: Evaluation of multi-channel EMG for enhancing control in mobility assistive devices using neck/shoulder movement classification

Abstract: Microcalcification segmentation plays an important role in the detection and diagnosis of breast cancer. While many deep neural network models perform well on standard datasets, their generalizability is often limited due to variations in data sources, device types, and other factors, leading to reduced accuracy in practical clinical applications. The Segment Anything Model (SAM), known for its zero-shot generalization capability, has recently gained significant attention in natural image segmentation tasks. Although the enhanced High-Quality SAM (HQ-SAM) model has achieved remarkable success in improving segmentation accuracy for ambiguous boundaries, it still struggles with precisely delineating small targets like microcalcifications. Therefore, this study proposes a Yolo-HLSAM-based approach for segmenting breast cancer microcalcification clusters. By integrating the precision of Yolov7 with the advanced segmentation capabilities of the HLSAM model, our method not only ensures accurate lesion detection but also significantly improves segmentation precision, while maintaining the scalability of the original SAM architecture. Additionally, a semi-automatic annotation technique is incorporated into the Yolo-HLSAM framework to further improve segmentation performance. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach substantially outperforms existing methods in segmentation accuracy, with Dice coefficients of 89.19 +/- 0.26% and 88.76 +/- 0.32% for the private and VinDr-Mammo datasets, respectively. Our code is available on https://github.com/ccchg/yolo-hlsam.
Article Title: Yolo-HLSAM: Adapting foundation segment anything model for semi-automatic detection and segmentation of breast cancer microcalcification clusters

Abstract: Knee osteoarthritis (KOA) is a prevalent orthopedic condition affecting the knee joint. Early detection facilitates timely medical interventions to effectively manage symptoms. The helical axis may aid in identifying early gait abnormalities in KOA. Despite this potential, no studies have examined the variability of the helical axis during gait in KOA patients compared to healthy individuals. Inertial measurement units (IMUs) provide a practical solution for capturing joint motion in clinical settings. This study investigates differences in helical axis variability during gait among KOA patients, healthy young adults, and healthy middle-aged adults using IMUs. Ten KOA patients, eleven healthy young controls, and ten healthy middle-aged controls participated in this study. Gait analysis was conducted on a 6-meter walkway with IMUs placed on the tibial tuberosity and lateral epicondyle of the femur. Helical axes were computed at 0.05-second intervals across four gait phases. Variability in axis orientation was quantified using standard deviations of spherical coordinate angles and mean deviations from the best-fitting plane. Statistical analyses were performed using the Kruskal-Wallis test, followed by posthoc tests where appropriate. KOA patients exhibited reduced helical axis variability during the stance phase compared to controls, reflecting stiffer knee joint movement rather than instability. This diminished variability could serve as a sensitive marker for early KOA detection and its functional progression. These results underscore the potential of IMU-based helical axis analysis in both clinical settings and daily life.
Article Title: Assessment of knee joint motion during gait using IMU-based helical axis analysis for early detection of knee osteoarthritis

Abstract: Diagnosing brain tumors in MRI scans is challenging and prone to errors, even for experienced radiologists. Computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems can significantly assist in these situations. However, many existing approaches rely on single learning networks, which may not adequately capture the complex features needed for accurate disease prediction. This study introduces a novel ensemble-based framework, FHD-HybridNet, for brain tumor classification from MRI images. The framework utilizes three base learners-DenseNet121, MobileNet, and ResNet50-along with additional layers designed to capture data-specific features, which serve as base models to improve performance. FHD-HybridNet incorporates Fuzzy Hellinger Distance (FHD) to effectively combine the strengths of these base models, enhancing classification accuracy and robustness. The FHD measure quantifies the dissimilarity between the probability distributions of the base models, allowing for an efficient integration of their complementary features. We conduct experiments on three different brain MRI datasets, demonstrating that FHD-HybridNet outperforms traditional ensemble methods and existing state-of-the-art (SOTA) approaches. In addition, validation is extended through cross-modal experiments on oral and skin disease datasets. Model interpretability is assessed using Grad-CAM visualizations, which highlight tumor-focused regions of interest. The statistical reliability of the results is confirmed through Cohen's kappa and McNemar's test. The results show that FHD-HybridNet achieves an accuracy of 98.78%, outperforming traditional ensemble methods and SOTA approaches, providing robust and clinically applicable solutions for brain tumor detection.
Article Title: FHD-HybridNet: A fuzzy hellinger distance-guided hybrid deep learning framework for robust multiclass brain tumor classification

Abstract: The growing demand for advanced computer-aided diagnosis systems in medical imaging is increasing for accurately detecting diseases, like COVID-19, pneumonia, tuberculosis and lung nodules. In spite of advancements, a research gap remains in developing models that offer high precision and transparent decision-making. To address this, this paper proposes an EfficientNetV2 for Lung Disease Diagnosis and Treatment by Harnessing the Synergy of Verifiable Convolutional Neural Network optimized with Nutcracker Optimizer Algorithm (ENLDD-VCNN). Here, the images taken from Chest CT-Scan dataset are used. Then High Accuracy Distributed Kalman Filter (HADKF) is used for image resizing and pixel normalization. Afterwards, the pre-processing images are given into the Verifiable Convolutional Neural Network with EfficientNetV2 (VCNN-ENetV2) for classifying lung diseases, like adenocarcinoma, large cell carcinoma (LCC), squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), normal. Finally, the Nutcracker Optimizer Algorithm (NOA) is employed to optimize the weight parameters of VCNN. The performance metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, error rate, Matthew's Correlation Coefficient (MCC), ROC is analyzed. The proposed technique achieves 20.73%,13.79% and 16.47% higher accuracy; 14.44%, 34.28% and 24.14% higher MCC; 12.16%, 18.39% and 26.27% higher precision compared with the existing techniques: Deep learning-dependent method to diagnose lung cancer by using CT-scan images (DL-DLC-CTI), Attention Enhanced Inception NeXt dependent Hybrid Deep Learning Method for Lung Cancer Diagnosis (AEI-HDLM-LCD) and Detection with categorization of lung disorders utilizing machine learning and deep learning strategies for pneumonia and Covid-19 (DC-LD-PC-DL) respectively.
Article Title: Efficient NetV2 for Lung Disease Diagnosis and Treatment by Harnessing the Synergy of Verifiable Convolutional Neural Network optimized with Nutcracker Optimizer Algorithm

Abstract: Accurate segmentation of lung nodules from chest CT images is critical for early lung cancer diagnosis and treatment. However, challenges like nodules overlapping with blood vessels/bronchi, variable nodule size/shape, and blurred boundaries reduce the accuracy of existing segmentation algorithms. To solve these issues, this paper proposes a novel multi-level feature aggregation network (MFA-Net) for lung nodule segmentation, which includes three core components: a front network tailored for lung nodule CT grayscale images to extract and fuse preliminary semantic features into the encoder and edge-aware network, an edge-aware network integrating central difference convolution (CDC) to capture fine-grained edge context and alleviate inaccurate edge prediction, and a multi-scale cascade decoder network that fuses cross-level encoder features and edge features and reshapes deep semantic information via sub-pixel convolution to handle scale variations. Quantitative and qualitative experiments on the Lung Image Database Consortium (LIDC) public dataset demonstrate that MFA-Net outperforms 13 state-of-the-art medical image segmentation methods, achieving 92.35% Dice coefficient and 88.01% IoU on grayscale CT images, while ablation experiments verify the effectiveness of each key component, and the source code and segmented images will be published at https://github.com/XiaoBai-Lyq/MFA-Net.
Article Title: MFA-Net: A novel multilevel feature aggregation network for lung nodule segmentation

Abstract: The timely and accurate classification of brain tumors from Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is paramount for effective treatment planning, yet conventional radiological assessment is often confounded by inter-observer variability and procedural delays. While Deep Learning (DL) models have shown promise, they frequently struggle to simultaneously capture fine-grained local features and extensive global context without incurring significant computational costs or sacrificing interpretability, which limits their clinical translation. To address this gap, we propose T-FSPANNet, a novel and computationally efficient DL architecture. Our model integrates a Tri-Attribute Block (T-Block) for multi-scale local feature extraction with a Feature Summarized Pyramidal Attention Network (FSPAN) for global contextual modeling. An adaptive Rescale Global Average Pooling (RGAP) layer further refines the feature representation, creating a synergistic and efficient architecture. Evaluated on a composite dataset created from three public sources (Figshare, SARTAJ, and Br35H), T-FSPANNet achieves stateof-the-art accuracy of 99.89 % with an F1-score of 0.9989. It significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods, demonstrating a marked reduction in clinically critical false positives and achieving near-perfect class-wise ROC-AUC scores. By balancing high performance with built-in interpretability, T-FSPANNet offers a robust and clinically viable solution that advances the field of automated neuro-oncological imaging.
Article Title: Towards accurate and interpretable brain tumor diagnosis: T-FSPANNet with Tri-Attribute and pyramidal attention-based feature fusion

Abstract: Electroencephalogram (EEG) signals provide valuable biological information for a wide range of brain computer interface (BCI) tasks. However, existing EEG studies often rely on complex preprocessing pipelines that require researchers to manually process data and select features, which is time-consuming and demands considerable expertise. Moreover, the lack of standardized preprocessing procedures introduces a high degree of subjectivity different researchers adopt different criteria making it difficult to reproduce results or apply these methods across domains. In this work, we present a joint time-frequency representation and spatial-filtering framework(TwoM) for end-to-end depression recognition. By jointly learning spatial structures and time-frequency features, TwoM adaptively filters informative signals and mitigates overfitting issues arising from small sample sizes and the low signal-to-noise ratio of EEG data. Furthermore, a bidirectional cross-attention module fuses time-frequency and spatial features information to enhance performance and generalization. Extensive evaluations on three EEG-based depression datasets, including MODMA, demonstrate that TwoM achieves competitive accuracy and robustness.
Article Title: TwoM: A model for joint time-frequency representation and spatial filtering for EEG-based depression recognition

Abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) is a chronic neurodegenerative disorder, and freezing of gait (FoG) represents a common motor impairment among PD patients posing safety risks to their daily lives. Wearable devices with FoG recognition models have the potential to provide external intervention during FoG episodes, assisting patients in regaining normal gait patterns. However, the specificity of Parkinson's patients has been observed potential decrease in model recognition accuracy, highlighting the need for generalization capability of recognition models across unseen patients. Recent studies have explored the impact of patient specificity by leveraging local information from video-based data. In this study, with sensor-derived local information from patients, we propose a one-dimensional convolutional neural network leveraging a multi-view branch structure and a view-attention mechanism for FoG detection. Additionally, we implement a data augmentation strategy with an autoencoder-based discriminator, which aims to provide high-quality supplementary data. The standard leave-one-out cross-validation and independent validation experiments, conducted on real-world Parkinson's patient datasets provided by Ruijin Hospital (Shanghai, China) and GYENNO SCIENCE CO., LTD., suggest that the proposed method may achieve relatively higher accuracy, improved generalization ability, and faster inference speed compared to current state-of-the-art approaches within the scope of this study. The method demonstrates promising stability across different patients, along with apparent adaptability to computing resource-constrained devices and sensor dropout environments. These findings imply that such capability could potentially contribute to help a broader range of patients reduce the risk of secondary injuries, such as falls associated with freezing-of-gait.
Article Title: Shallow multi-view network for sensor-based recognition of Parkinson's freezing of gait

Abstract: Medical image segmentation plays a vital role in clinical diagnosis and disease prediction. Deep learning models based on CNN and Transformer have been widely applied in image segmentation. However, CNNs struggle with global information extraction due to their limited receptive field and insensitivity to low-frequency image information. Although transformer-based models excel in global feature extraction, their quadratic computational complexity limits their use in real-world medical applications. This paper proposes a hybrid CNN-SSM framework, which utilizes low-frequency information, as well as local and global information to boost the precision of segmentation while maintaining the model's linear complexity. More specifically, the WTC-VSS block is proposed as the core module of the encoder-decoder, which combines wavelet transforms, CNN, and visual state space (VSS) model. This block not only boosts the network's attention to low-frequency information but also effectively extracts global information and long-range dependencies. Additionally, the Spatial-Channel attention fusion (SCAF) block is proposed, which enables the network to efficiently fuse highlevel features while preserving low-level features. The integration allows the network to leverage detailed information from the original input during the decoding stage, thus enhancing segmentation accuracy. To determine the effectiveness of the proposed method, this study conducted experiments on the ISIC2017 and ISIC2018 datasets, achieving dice coefficients of 88.34% and 89.05%, respectively. The results highlight the effectiveness of our approach in enhancing the precision of image segmentation.
Article Title: WTCM-UNet: A hybrid CNN-SSM framework combining wavelet transform for medical image segmentation

Abstract: Medical image analysis often involves time-consuming annotation processes. Pediatric image analysis introduces additional complexity due to the scarcity of data, noise, and growth-related anatomical variations, particularly in bone analysis, where bone structures evolve more slowly compared to other organs. This study aims to develop a segmentation model that scales across different age groups, reduces annotation effort, and ensures high accuracy, particularly in low-quality images. To address these challenges, we propose a segmentation pipeline (PedVision) that first uses a Region of Interest (ROI) network to identify relevant regions, followed by a foundation model that translates each region into meaningful instances. These instances are then mapped to segmentation classes through an instance classifier (IC) network. To initiate rounds of the training of ROI and IC networks, we developed a fast, semi-automated annotation framework that leverages foundation models to annotate a subset of images using an object-level approach. In subsequent rounds, a human discriminator selects promising predictions from the last round, which are fed by unseen data, progressively enriching the model's training dataset for further fine-tuning of the networks. The networks are expanded from low-parameter to high-parameter models across rounds, incorporating a curriculum learning approach to capture increasingly complex features. We evaluated PedVision on 552 hand X-ray images of children, retrieved from the publicly available Radiological Society of North America (RSNA) and Digital Hand Atlas (DHA) datasets, which represent a diverse range of ages and racial backgrounds. PedVision performed segmentation of 19 hand bones, grouped in five classes, and was compared against U-Net and DeepLabV3+ models using ResNet34 and ResNet101 backbones, as well as the SegFormer model with four different encoder variants. For pediatric cases (i.e., 0-7 years), the PedVision pipeline outperforms the best-performing models, achieving an 11.08 % improvement in Dice score over U-Net in the RSNA dataset and a 7.68 % improvement in the DHA dataset. When compared to DeepLabV3+, the improvements are even more substantial, with gains of 14.43 % in RSNA and 14.78 % in DHA. Additionally, PedVision shows notable advantages over the best SegFormer model, with improvements of 8.16 % in RSNA and 1.91 % in DHA. The project is open source at github.com/mohofar/PedVision.
Article Title: PedVision: A manual-annotation-free and age scalable segmentation pipeline for bone analysis in hand X-ray images

Abstract: Retinal blood vessel segmentation is a significant task for diagnosing fundus lesions. Recently, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have been applied for automatic segmentation. However, due to the difficulty in handling long-term dependencies, CNNs can only capture local features in images, which reduces the accuracy of image segmentation. Additionally, the quadratic computational complexity results in long training and inference times. Recently, State Space Models (SSMs), such as Mamba, has been found to excel in longrange modeling, which effectively handles long-range dependencies with the benefit of linear computational complexity. Consequently, inspired by Mamba, we propose herein the Multi-scale Vision Mamba-UNet to provide enhanced retinal vessel segmentation. In the proposed model, a Multi-scale Visual State Space Block (MVSS) forms the encoder and decoder to capture the contextual information of retinal images, and a Dynamic Multi-functional Information Interaction (DMFII) module enables the interaction and fusion of high-level and low-level features, allowing contextual information at each layer to complement one another. Experimental results based on real life retinal image datasets, such as CHASEDB1, DRIVE, STARE and HRF, demonstrate that the proposed method achieves high accuracy in retinal vessel segmentation.
Article Title: Multi-scale Vision Mamba-UNet: A Mamba-based method for retinal vessel segmentation

Abstract: Breast cancer persists as a major health concern for women globally, and the best course of treatment depends on early detection. Although mammography is widely used as a monitoring tool, its limitations in accurately identifying subtle early-stage lesions and classifying malignant tumors persist.
